Very thick head. Nice brown color. Fruity aroma. For me the best beer I ever tasted, even better than the 10. Can recommend to everybody who likes sweeter beers with caramel taste.

330ml bottle. Cloudy dark amber to brown colour with average frothy rudimentarily lacing off-white head. Yeasty, caramel malty, slightly toasty aroma, a hint of dark fruit - overall decent, underdeveloped. Initially yeasty taste, dark fruity and caramel malty, touch of alcohol, a spicy touch in finish. Lacks expectable complexity and depth in relation to its high rating.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque caramel-brown, with a really thick head.  Mild aroma of fruit and a touch of yeast.  The flavor is nice, with malt notes of caramel, brown sugar, raisins, and dark fruits.  Yeast dominates the end of the sip, with a bit of a bitter aftertaste.  Not as good as I remembered - I wonder if this is a bad bottle.

Würziger aber noch verhalten dunkelmalziger Beginn mit gering süßen Noten. Angenehme Kräuternoten, durch die die Süße intensiver wirkt. Holzig, würzig. Kirsche, deutlich hefig. Rund, intensiv, das Verhältnis von Süße zu Würzigkeit könnte aber etwas besser sein. 13/11/11/11/12/11

Always thought of this as one of my favourites, but been a while since I last tried it. Great nose just as I remembered; spicy bread. More precisely brown bread ice-cream. Taste is deep and wine-like, but there is so much carbonation, it really, really gets in the way. It gets in the way so much that I struggle to enjoy it- the bubbles are huge. Nose is cherry, malt,raisins, sweet fruits.
Flavour is cherry, sweet caramel, plum.....apple.

The trio of 6, 8 and 10 are all excellent...each has its own character and all should not be missed.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2017 Bottle, served in the Rochefort glass. A brown colour with a bubbly white head. Sweetish, fruit cake, raisins, malt, touch of alcohol. Very nice, but cant help think its a bit overcarbonated which must detract from the taste a bit. Maybe I should let it age a bit. 

Re-rate. Didnt mind the carbonation this time. Really remarkable balance of malty sweetness, esters and spicy hop without being cloying.
The head is ok, the body dark brown. It smells sweet-cherry, alcoholic. The taste is oak aged-alcoholic, sweet-cherry, strong CO². Special flavor, good! 12/12/12/12/11/12

Ive had this before but never rated it. Sitting in my hotel bar in  Belgium and ordered one for 3 Euro. Poured into a slight pilsener glass at room temperature. Best by: 9/26/16

A - Half a finger, very light brown head. foggy brown ale with showing just a bit of light through just sitting here on the table. SRM is 30 maybe. Head dissipated at the time I finished writing this sentence.

S - Loads of dark fruits, figs and raisins especially with a hint of bread. sweet malty taste with a hint of cinnamon. I had the 10 earlier and this is not as sweet but still nice.

T - Really nice balanced sweetness with loads of dark fruits. Great solid malt backbone and just a tad bit more carbonated than I like. Im getting some coffee characteristics which is strange for a beer of this style.

M - 90% carbonation, medium body and the finish is sweet and quickly fades with a nice level of malts

O - Delicious. Not as great as 10 but stil very tasty.
Almost without bitterness, a good plum-raisin palate. Foam disappearing after 2 minutes. Brown colur. Solid Belgian ale.

Grape, honey and fig tastes. Medium mouthfeel, slightly sparkling. A good balanced dark Belgian

Bottle 330ml.
Pours brown with gassy brown head, quickly diminishing. Aroma is of dark fruits (plums), yeast, bread, malt, caramel, some alchool. Taste is of dark fruits, malt, caramel, sweetness, warming alchool. Overall: Good carbonation, nice balance. Interesting alchool feeling, not to bold nor too shy. Full bodied. Drinkable for the abv. A very good beer.

Aromas:  caramel, roasty, banana.  Appearance:dark brown, medium head that dissipates relatively quickly.  Taste:  sweet initial taste, with slightly bitter aftertaste.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Enjoyable with fairly strong alcohol content.

Number 8, to my way of thinking, tastes closer to number 6 than to number 10.   Either way, its outstanding.  It pours dark, slightly cloudy, with a big,  noisy head.  Caramel and apples in the aroma, and more strongly in the flavor.  Bready, too, really hearty.  Dry and hoppy in the finish.  Extraordinary.

Drinking this is like going on a long journey with your tongue. There must be a dozen flavours from start to finish... rating something as good as this, how can you go back to regular beer? Why cant this replace Bud Light with a third of the US market share?

Pours a cloudy dark brown with an off-white head. Nose is brown sugar, molasses, milk chocolate, orange marmalade, lemon peel, coriander, sweet biscuits, perfume, floral hops, and pepper. The taste is a sour dark fruit bomb with plum, raisin, cherry, and green apple, coupled with roasted, earthy, malty flavours. Very tart. Mouth feel is viscous and smooth with medium carbonation. Finish is dry, leaving coffee, grape, and dark chocolate. Very nice brew.

Medium brown cloudy beer with a long lasting small beige head.  Not much aroma at first, then sweet malts, fruit, and grassy notes.  Flavors of plums, sweet malt, a little cocoa, yeast. Very little apparent bitterness but is still extremely well balanced. Carbonation is very lively, more so than a bottle of the 6 next to it. Sticky and with silken feel.  It ends spicy, with some alcohol warmth and a little yeast tickle. Its pretty big but still very approachable.  Exceptional.  I should come back to it more often.

A deep translucent ruby brown color with an creamy tan head greets the eye. Little to no lacing detected.  The aroma is complex; raisins, Belgian yeast and notes of alcohol.  The pallet is, as the nose, complex. Dark fruit (prunes & raisins) and malt sweetness, up front followed quickly by balanced bitter notes. The aftertaste supplies some pleasing hints of alcohol. The mouthfeel is medium with just the right touch of carbination. A bery fulfilling beer. Would buy and drink again.

Botyle at eulogy in PHL. Pours a amber hue, off white head with good retention. Sweet nose, light toast in mouth. Light body despite abv.

Pours oaky colour with a retained one finger head. Smell is of stewed plums and rhubarb. Taste starts the same but transforms into dark fruity raisin and finally warms the mouth and throat with only the smallest taste of alcohol.

Originally reviewed: 12/8/11. Pours a ruby-hued mahogany with a thick finger-width creamy beige head. Nice wispy coating of the glass after each sip. The nose is sweet with notes of cider, strawberry, and a little yeast twang. 

The mouth is quite bubbly and effervescent, almost too much so. Id rather this be a little less spritzy, but thats just me. The fruit-like qualities carry over to the flavor as well. Apple, plum flavors noted. Candy-like sweetness on the finish. Yeast quality is mellow and not overbearing at all, which is how I like it. Adds just a touch of spice on the back end. All in all, this is a good beer. A pleasant sipper and treat to be shared.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2013 Pours a deep red with a large bubbly head which reduces down to a lacing quickly. In the aroma you have dark fruits, cherries, berries, raisins, candy sugar, caramel and chocolate, Sweet to finish with the fruity aroma disappearing quickly. The 9.2% alcohol is hidden well. Carbonation lively leaving a fruity cherry aftertaste. Great..

Bottle 330 ml. Well, one thing for sure: this beer is far from overrated! Nice brown color with lasting beige head. Aroma: mostly alcohol and fruits (bananas?). Sweet taste. Without a doubt one of the best Belgian Strong Ale!
Bouteille 330 ml. Une chose est sûre: cette bière est loin dêtre surévaluée! Belle robe brune et collet beige persistant. Arômes: surtout alcool et fruits (bananes?). Goût sucré. Sans lombre dun doute lune des meilleurs ales fortes belges!

Originally reviewed Dec. 20, 2006 (my first beer review):

mmmm. easily the best beer i've tasted to date. first impression was abundance of banana's. incredible flavour and drink-ability of a high alcohol content beer. first poured, head is minimal. not bitter at all. minimal aftertaste. mmmmm. better than old style. hahahahaha. further review of this after experience is in order.
From bottle in Chimay glass. Nice amber brown colour. Very fruity taste and smell. Quite heavily carbonated.
330ml bottle from Bierwerg. Dark brown colour with nice lasting head. Aroma is sweet, yeast. Flavour is sweet, malty, spicy with long lasting aftertaste.

A Rochefort, on est généreux ! En effet, la "10" fait 11,3 abv , la "6" fait 7,5,
et notre amie daujourdhui la "8" fait 9,2 % abv....
Donc on fait plus efficace que ce quon annonce sur létiquette.
Voilà une philosophie que beaucoup de brasseurs feraient bien de méditer !!! 
Pour ce qui est de la pratique du goût et des saveurs, jai toujours trouvé 
que cette "petite" soeur de la grande 10, navait rien à envier à elle.
Je la trouve hyper complète dans les sensations, parfois même, sous
certains côtés plus fine, plus capiteuse, plus ronde, plus déliée et somme toute plus équilibrée. 
Mais nous naviguons dans les très hautes sphères. Nous sommes au
sommet de lart du brassage, il faut le savoir, et nous parlons donc dinfimes détails qui peuvent constituer une petite différence...
Pour ce qui est du rating, puisque cest ce qui nous occupe, je suis pour ma part à 300 sur 100 pour la "10".
(voir ma critique de cette bière).  Donc en termes de nuances, la compétition va être difficile... Pour lanecdote, mais ceci vaut la peine dêtre mentionné, jai dégusté la dernière fois la 8 chez des amis
en Belgique avec un repas où la maîtresse de maison est une très fine
cuisinière, qui a touché aux repas professionnels etc., et jai choisi la 8 dans la cave de mes hôtes pour 
lassemblage de cette bière à un repas de belle composition. Cétait absolument sublime, et confinait à ce que lon trouve de mieux dans le 
mariage vins et plats. Encore une fois, soulignons que la 
bière na rien à envier au vin sur laccompagnement à la nourriture, et 
jai ce soir-là été en pure admiration de cette bière qui représentait une
sorte de plénitude, au sens propre du terme. Un état de béatitude.
Nous lavons comparée avec mes hôtes aux meilleures vendanges tardives, par exemple de lAlsace
ou du Pacherenc du Vic Bilh.
Nhésitons jamais à faire ce genre de mariage dans les beaux repas de
famille, et même bien sûr de cuisiner à la bière, qui est un ingrédient dune très grande noblesse pour parfaire les senteurs dun vrai repas.
Je rappelle que les grands chefs ont en tout des dizaines de recettes très fines avec les meilleures bières, et principalement avec les trappistes qui sont un sommet dans les arômes que lon peut trouver dans le domaine de la bière.... Fin de mon appel à ce bonheur de vivre !!
Revenons à la 8.
Cette bière est en fait une ambrée foncée. Donc elle est plus claire que sa grande soeur.
Rappelons aussi que Rochefort est la seule trappiste à sortir toutes ses bières en brunes, ce nest pas 
anecdotique...
Merveilleuse mousse beige et grande vitalité du pétillant.
Arômes dune finesse profonde et dune sorte de velouté, que lon ne trouve pas dans la 10.
La prise en bouche est extraordinaire, et révèle immédiatement le niveau auquel on se situe.
On est dans les tops du top... A ce propos, je dois dire que je ne comprends pas comment nous
navons que 24 notes maximales à 5/5 au rate, alors quil y en a 127 avec la mienne pour la 10 !!
A mon sens nous devrions avoir exactement autant de notes maximales pour cette 8, parce quelle
est en tous points comparables, voire supérieure...
Le problème est que supérieur au supérieur est très difficile en termes humains.
Heureusement, nous sommes ici en présence dune bière divine. Donc nous pouvons surenchérir !!
La 2ème et la 3ème bouche monte en amplitude... Donc nous avons la preuve matérielle que lon
peut faire mieux que mieux. La levure est sublime (je la connais dailleurs en version naturelle !)
La finale nous révèle une bière dun niveau astronomique... Nous sommes au 7ème ciel...
Léquilibre est magistral. La plénitude se retrouve à la dégustation, exactement comme dans le
repas chez mes amis. Preuve dune bière complète en elle-même.
Et en effet ne dit-on pas que la bière est du pain liquide ? 
Le degré dalcool est plus adapté ici à la dégustation que la 10 qui titre quand même à 11,3 !!
Ici à 9,2 abv, on est au niveau supérieur du qualitatif, sans être assommant.
De plus, on trouve ici des notes de miel de châtaignier, de dattes, damandes que lon ne trouve
pas dans la 10, et qui en font un fleuron du savoir-faire trappiste du plus haut niveau.
Un emblème de la bière belge.
Pour ma part, ma note sera denviron 330 sur 100.

Ar: Fresh mango, raisins, rum, and caramel.
Ap: Deep amber-red, hazy - large light tan head with decent retention.
T: Deep dark caramel, lots of toffee and raisin, medium sweetness - a touch of anise and fungal cellar flavor - luscious dark sugar flavor throughout with stone and tropical fruits.
P: Medium body with high carbonation - finish is medium-dry
O: Awesome beer - the depth of fruit and caramel flavor is really astounding and begs sip after sip.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Full bodied trappist with soft carbonation. Aroma of vanilla, licorice and caramel. Light brown appearance in the glass. Light sweetness, medium bitterness and medium sourness. Well balanced beer that growes on me from each time.

In May 2011 I wrote this: had this 33cl bottle for some time, but never opened it: I am now in possession of a 2007 Cuvee one and a half litre bottle, so its time for this small one to go!

Best before 8th Nov this year, I poured it slowly into a Westmalle chalice, ensuring no sediment left the bottle. The body was a deep amber brown colour, murky and moody looking, the thin head of small bubbles just about covered the whole glass, with stronger depth around the rim forming a collar.

The smell was of old sweaty, yet sweet molasses and treacle.

The taste is also old/sweet, a strange combination of flavours, difficult to differentiate or seperate without waffling.

The rich maltiness from those sweaty molasses contains the alcohol content very well, I had real problems picking up the 9.2% ABV this beer has.

To call it a classic is easy and almost unsporting, but it is exceptional in its simplicity and elegance: so a classic it is!

Intense aroma of alcohol, raisins, and grapefruit. Pours a dark shade of brown with a significant foam top. Flavors of creamy caramel, vanilla, and bready malts masking a large alcohol taste. Overall, very complex flavoring all balancing out perfectly to make for a stunningly delicious brew. Id give this an A+ rating.

Bottle.  Appearance: Pours a raisin brown color with a nice off-white head.  Aroma: Big aroma of red grapes mixed with plum and raisins.  Alcohol sneaks in. Very wine like. Taste: Immediately hit with red grapes with hints of dark figs, spice, and plums. Slight alcohol warming but it is very well masked. Finishes like a nice red wine. Palate: Slight alcohol warming but not anywhere close to burning. Nice lingering dryness that lingers red grapes on the tongue for a few minutes after the sip.

A: Pours a brilliant shade of dark ruby red with near perfect haziness. The head is an incredible light gray color with top caliber retention and lacing, and how the carbonation rises up from the body to form the head just looks right. Its almost impossible to fault the aesthetic presentation of this one.

S: Pear, clove, coriander, raisins, figs, and a hint of chocolate create an incredibly complex and grand aroma.

T: Taste follows the aroma, with impressive complexities yet top-notch balance. Tart pear, raisins, figs, black currants, touches of dark chocolate, and I swear theres some cherry notes in there somewhere. Its true hallmark is how each sip yields a subtle change in flavor. Also, the yeast profile is just right, it gives a backing contribution to the bodys complexity without getting too much in the way and becoming overly chalky. As great as this beer is, I kind of expected a little more, to be honest.

M: Medium-heavy bodied with a smooth, vaguely dry finish. The yeasty astringency is kept perfectly in check, giving it surprising drinkability factor. Lowish carbonation.

O: A fantastic creation - but it isnt the life changing revelation I expected it to be. This is the classic example of expecting raw perfection and only getting brilliance instead. Still, highly recommended for everyone to try at least once.
Bottle. Medium brown, off-white head, leaves lacing. Dark fruits, toast, spices, molasses, apple. Medium body, active/medium-high carbonation.

A - citrus and caramel
A - dark brown with frothy head
T - sweet and roasty
P - mid to full and soft
O - good
smell of spieces. A rich and dark taste. Long aftertaste. Spiecy aftertaste.

Bottle.  Pours medium brown with an immense off-white head, tons of lacing, and a little carbonation.  The aroma has a lot of dark fruit (mostly plum) and some dough in the background.  The taste is medium sweet with some dried fruit flavors and some mild bitterness on the finish.  The palate on this is fantastic and the brew lingers on the tongue without being too sticky.  Pretty darn good.

Pours a cloudy brown with tan head. Smells spicy, sweet and alcoholic. Taste is toasty, spicy, ripe dark fruits and alcohol. Med-full body. Med carbonation. After taste is warm sweet and spicy. Great stuff.
Very malty and smooth.  Nice foamy head eventually dissipates to a low frothy ring around the surface.  Malty and smooth.  (Did I say that already?)  Its very enjoyable.

A fully diminishing tan head. Slight raisins and figs. Effervescent. Very enjoyable. As it says, "a lower gravity cousin" to the 10. A terrific brew from a terrific brewery. The 4 pack with the chalice is fun. Brought one all the home from Belgium. Finer beer stores in Canada may carry it. It was worth the effort getting it home safe. A lovely and long finish. Yes layers of flavor make it simply delightful.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 (First Taste, Home, 330mL Bottle, Vintage Apr. 2011, Tulip, 9.2% ABV, Cellar Temp, 31/03/12. #30.)


Appearance (3/5): Pours a cloudy, muddy brown color, with an average sized, creamy brown head that fully diminishes and leaves little lacing. Lots of sediment.

Aroma (8/10): Incredibly complex. Dominant dried fruit and spices: raisin, fig, cloves, and cardamom. Additional notes of citrus, toffee, molasses, and rum. Alcohol is quite notable on the nose.

Taste (9/10): Initially acidic green apple, then very sweet raisin, fig, and chocolate, then roasty molasses, toffee, and spices grow into a lightly bitter finish that lasts quite a while and unfolds over time. Something here reminds me of rum, especially when it warms.

Palate (4/5): Medium body with lively carbonation. The texture is interesting; not quite thick enough to be creamy, but very slick and oily. Silky. Almost light, "vanishing" finish with a delightful warmth.

Overall (18/20): Surprisingly drinkable, especially considering the 9.2% ABV, which is well hidden on the tongue. The aroma is very good, but maybe a little too much alcohol presence. Appearance is honestly nothing special. The palate borders on excellence, but needs a little more body to get there. Taste is layers upon layers of goodness. Very well balanced, very delicious. Im excited to try the 10.

Drinkability: 3/5. Character: 5/5. Buy Again: Definitely Yes.

330 ml bottle into chalice, best by 5/11/2016.  Pours super murky dark reddish brown color with a nice 1 finger dense khaki head that reduces to a thin cap that lingers.  Spotty lacing on the glass, with a good amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of huge raisin, plum, grape, banana, molasses, pepper, clove, biscuit, toasted grains, and huge yeast spices.  Incredible aromas with a ton of complexity.  Taste of big caramel, molasses, plum, raisin, biscuit, banana, clove, pepper, and yeast spices.  Lingering notes of dark fruit, molasses, banana, pepper, and yeast spice on the finish for a good bit.  Great flavor balance and complexity.  Medium-high carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly creamy and slightly slick mouthfeel with a bit of prickly carbonation.  Quite smooth to drink at 9.2%, but is still a sipper.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming after the finish noticed.  Overall this is a fantastic Dubbel.  Big complexity and balance; and extremely enjoyable.

Aroma of spices, large head but surprisingly short-lasting in my glass. Roasted flavour with caramel, but more subtle spiced finish. Plenty of carbonation, makes a very interesting drink, but not my favourite Trappist.

[ASPETTO] 			
colore marrone scuro, opaca, residui sul fondo bottiglia			
[SCHIUMA]			
color beige, buona presenza, compatta e buona persistenza			
[OLFATTO]			
intenso, sentori di malti tostati, frutta rossa sotto spirito, lieviti ed evidenti note alcoliche			
[GUSTO]			
intensa, dominata da un dolce fruttale inziale e lieviti , subito inchinati ai piedi di note che tendono verso un amaro tostato, accentuato da una alcolicità evidente che aggiunge un tocco speziato. Retrogusto persistente, dominato da sentori liquorosi.			
[TEXTURE]			
corpo medio, morbida e vellutata in bocca, carbonazione dosata, alcohol evidente ma non invadente			
[COMMENTO FINALE]			
simile nel colore alle sorella 6, mostra una schiuma più solida e persistente. Molto meglio carbonata, dando un leggero brio al palato ma senza offuscare le prime sensazione gustative. Ne giova il corpo e la maltatura, dando una consistenza ed una morbidezza maggiore. lalcol sale a 9 % abbondanti ma non si sente, anzi si inserisce alla perfezione dando il suo meglio nel finale supportando  sapori amari e  speziati ed infodnendo una buona sensazione di calore. Ottima, preferita alla 6, avendo basi più solidi ed una maggiore armonicità... non vedo la ora di stappare la sorellona 10 !!

33cl bottle. Pours deep ruby/mahogany with small tan head, light lacing, good level of carbonation. Aroma full of dark fruit, figs, raisins, plums, lovely rich maltiness, slight roasted notes, yeast complexity. Taste is deep and complex, with the dark fruit taking centre stage - raisins and figs especially - excellently balanced with the dark rich malt and the spiced complexity of the yeast. Alcohol warmth as it goes down, lovely long finish. A classic.
Dark brown colour. Malty and dark fruit aroma. Taste is sweet, caramel, roasted malts and dark fruits
A true biere de Flanders. Makes no concessions to other styles. Best of class, or damn near it.
Bottle. Fruity, sweet malt, and musty yeast aroma. Hazy brown with a moderate, creamy tan head. Tart fruit, sweet malt, spice, funky yeast and alcohol flavor. Medium full body with light carbonation.

Pour murky dark brown, with a creamy white head that lasts all the way through. 
Aroma is quite malty, and plenty of fresh fruits. Also alot of of belgian yeast Going on. 
Taste is sweet, with a really bitter and dry aftertaste. 
Medium bodied, with an average carb.
Bottle pouurs hazy brown with a white head.  Aroma is caramel malt and spice.  Taste is sweet, roasted malts and a bit of cocoa.

Vintage 2010. Bottle at home. Has a very deep red brown colour with a very frothy and big beige head. Aromas of brown sugar, wood, sweet dried fruit, toffee, some cardamom, something burned, and hint of alcohol. The taste is dominated by sweet and spicy malt, leather, and with a round alcohol touch in the end. Slick and oily mouthfeel but a little bit light, and medium bitterness. A beer with a fantastic aroma, with the taste is following up, simpler than the aroma but pleasant. Much alcohol in the taste but is balanced out by the rich sweet malts.

Almost as good as the first sparge (rochefort 10). Brilliant toffee and brown sugar aroma and flavour. The hops, bitterness and carbonation are all more obvious here than they are in the 10, which overpowers the bitterness with pure deliciousness. A rochefort for someone who loves carbonation in their beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/8/2011.  Poured from a 33 cl bottle into a Rochefort chalice. It feels right that the inaugural pour into the glass is a Rochefort.

The color is a deep, murky cherry brown. The bubbles on the frothy off-white head visibly burst and the head fades to nothing quickly.

This is an exotic aroma. A strange tartness is not the most dominant, but it is the most noticeable. After thinking about it for a few minutes, I think it is green apple and tart cherries. Combined with some rum, red grapes, plums and figs, this is quite interesting.

The flavor starts sweet and boozy. Rum, plums, sweet cherries, and figs start out with some caramel malt. A light tartness in the middle, white grape, green apple, some tart cherries. The end has some ethyl alcohol.

The mouthfeel kind of irks me. It has the beginning of a creamy feel, but then some obnoxious heavy carbonation overwhelms everything. The body feels on the lighter side of medium despite the ABV.

This is interesting and different, but the carbonation and rum flavor really drop this for me. Kind of disappointed.

Bottle 330 ml [2011]. Appereance: Pours dark brown with an average light brown head. Aroma: Strong notes of dark fruits, malt and raisin(?). Taste: Quite complex. Sweet and round. Notes of caramel, dark fruits and a bit of alcohol. Overall: A classic to enjoy again and again. Great beer, very complex and well balanced.
caramel, vanilla, citrus, brown, cloudy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, slick feel, lively,

Aroma: caramel, hay, spruce, herbs, earthy, 
Appearance:  brown, cloudy, tan foam, 
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, 
Palate: full body, creamy, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter, long finish, 
I have been lucky to try it. Now I´m looking for number 10

Pours hazy brown, white foam.
Aromas: esters, chocolate, caramelized pear.
Taste:  malty, toasted.
Palate: sweet, smoothy, light bitter aftertaste.
Nice Belgian.
Bottled. Little dark color than the 6. more of a spice taste in the 8 vs the 6. smooth malt roasted taste.

poured a dark golden color. modest amount of head that quickly faded. caramel and the spicy Belgian yeast character comes across in the aromas of caramel. tastes of raisin, toffee, and the belgian yeast is definitely present in the flavor. very nice.

33cl bottle from Downer Wine & Spirit, best by 07 07 15.  Pours a hazy brown color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is raisin, brown sugar, nutty.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, lots of raisin, a little yeast, just a hint of booze, with sweet, nutty finish.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 poured from bottle into a chalice. Pours a medium brown color with a nice head.

deep and balanced with great malty aromas, caramel, some dark red cherries and a touch of chocolate. The aromas are a bit unyielding though.

extremely smooth with a fuller body. Well balanced with great flavors of dark red cherries, caramel, and a good bit of malts as well.

The flavors and feel end up winning out for this. Real classy and smooth with balance being what its all about. The alcohol isnt noticeable in the slightest either.

Poured into a snifter. Dark, cloudy brown with a thin white head. Spicy and toffee nose showing plenty of Belgian yeast and malt. The palate shows some sweetness and a whiskey-like flavor on the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2013 Best of all Rochefort beers. Dark colour and medium light brown head, its perfectly equilibrated concerning taste: sweet and malty, some cereals and no bitterness or alcohol (despite its 9.2%). Superb, a top class drink.

Aged 9 months. Pours a dark brown with lots of sediment. HUGE amounts of carbonation, even started bubbling out of the bottle before I poured it. I assume due to the fairly long storage of a bottle conditioned beer. Smelled and tasted of delicious malts across the spectrum. Lots of fruit, dark fruit, some yeast and a tinge of sweetness like toffee. Tasted hoppier than expected, but balanced. Nice palate. Delicious and refreshing.

Dark amber in color. Some red light peeked around the edges. Thick foamy head that receded to a sheer veneer of bubbles. Lace coated the inside. Flavor is very malty with a quick hit of some spices that does a great job concealing the alcohol--which there is a lot of booze.

Bottle enjoyed at home
Dark brown, big off white head. Smells of ripe fruits, yeast esters, apple and malts. Taste is not very malty, still very fruity with short sweetness. Some tart elements too, but not sour. Very dry on the palate. Nice bitter finish with apple. Lively carbonation+-----

Pours (unfiltered) dark chocolate with a sizable foamy cream colored head.  Smells bread and raisins.  Tastes dark dried fruit with just a bit of alcohol bite.  Somewhat highly carbonated.  Nothing stands out with this brew...but it is good across the board.

Dark copper, vibrant pour with a thin tan lid. You can smell the floral and dark fruit as you pour. A strong vinous aroma comes through along with toffee, dark sugar, banana leaves, malt, autumn, redcurrants. Taste: so complex. A multitude swirling around. Medium carbonation and alcohol heat are the initial sensations. Red wine and toffee malt. Next the fruit, hint of spice, hoppy bitter notes and banana leaves. Its so complex on a par with 10 in my opinion. Just fantastic. Big fan of the genre!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.
Dark brown beer with a ripe banana flavor. In taste this beer has again the ripe banana and of course hints of dark chocolate. The alcohol gives this beer a nice round  and full taste.

Wicked earthy taste.   Almost like sucking up  a dirty old monks cellar through a straw.   The cocktail seems to include some plum and the lightest sweet gloss that covers your mouth from teeth to tonsils.  Bottle at Castros Lounge.

Fles 33cl
Kleur: Koperbruin, met een lichtbruine dikke creme schuimkraag.
Geur: Meteen bij openen banaan. Daarna zoet/fruitig, rum/rozijn en mout (geroosterd).
Smaak: Bitter en zoet, wisselen elkaar af. Erg aangenaam prikkelend. Nasmaak is bitter met een toch sterk alcoholisch karakter.

Currently drinking while typing. After pouring you have a lovely aroma arising from the glass, one of brown sugars, malts, hops, blackcurrant, cranberries, gentle roses and sloe berries. Lovely appearance of a dark blunt muddy brown coloured murkiness with a good thick tan head of coarse bubbles and fine bubbles mixed which lasts very well. Very good taste of brown sugars, light caramel, vanilla, gentle well masked booze in the back, malts, buttery taste and texture with light resin style hops during the aftertaste. Full feel but also very gentle in terms of drinkability, good carbonation and also a subtle dryness to the finish. Very good beer, not as good as the Rochefort 10 but still very good and gentle enough to be a nice Belgian session beer. Go try some!
Una birra davvero meravigliosa!!!

Bottle. Pours brown with a nice creamy, quite light, head. A powerful and complex beer. Many flavours, dried fruits, chocolate, bread etc.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance:  dark brown color with thick, creamy head. Aroma:  bread, fig, dried fruit, slightly astringent. Taste:  raisins, sweet dried fruit, malt, caramel. Mouthfeel:  creamy, thick yet surprisingly high carbonation. Overall:  Im fairly new to the style but it is a pretty great beer with a unique, yet delicious, taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark cloudy brown with a thick creamy head. Aroma of figs, fruit, bread, and caramel. Dates and fig flavor with a warm toffee icing. Finishes with a nice caramel aftertaste. The flavors are not as bold as the 10, but still has warm fruits and is very tasty.

Bottle, Carrefour Express convenience store E1.20 Brussels. tasted around 15 degrees C.
Clear brown with minimal, evanescent head. Aroma of dried fruits which, after much debate we decided was dominated by fig and additional dark cereal notes, toast, hint of molasses cookie and soy. Second sniffs got us thinking about herbs and spices. Descriptors aside, the combination is beguiling-you want to smell it again and find out more. 
Theres a bit of sweetness balanced by barely enough bitterness. The palate is creamy and balanced by a generous carbonation. The finish is exceptionally long with malt dominating along with some sort of berry fruit.  I expect Ill still be tasting this beer tomorrow morning. 
The effect is like a wines without the sticky overreaching of most barley wines. This beer is not terribly showy-no fireworks or exotic hops-but it is one of the best things youll taste all year.

Bottle.

Dark with a creamy head. Dark fruits, yeast and spices. On the sweet side. Quite complex and with a nice full body. A robust and great beer.

330 ml bottle. Pours a bronze, very cloudy brown with a short-lasting white head. Smells of bread and yeast. Tastes of dry fruits, sweet bread, light caramel. Body is thick and creamy. Carbonation is a bit aggressive. Liked it!

Pour is a dark reddish-tinted brown with a creamy beige-colored head. Aroma is sweet - dark fruits: raisin, black cherry, plum. Taste is certainly alcoholic. Almost wine-like. Red grapes like a deep cabernet. Balanced with just a bit of an oak-like brandy flavor. This is a doosie. Very very good.

Perfect roasted brown color. Just before it touches your lips you smell rich figs and raisins. Taste doesnt disappoint.  Immediately the dark fruit sensations hit and last and last.  A pretty perfect beer. Maybe a notch below Rochefort 10 but when youre talking beers this good, it doesnt mean anything.
Bottle at Tria. Pours a dark brown. Nose is fresh figs, candy sugar and soy sauce. First sip is raisins,  brown malt and belgian yeast.  Finish is nice
Really the best beer in the world. Taste perfect, but gets you drunk quite fast. Definitely worth a try!

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2012 AROMA: dried fruits, chocolate notes, spruce, herbs, bread
APPEARANCE: brown, clear, frothy
TASTE: light sweetness, medium bitterness
PALATE: full body, slick feel, lively, long finish
OVERALL: bitterness and fruity notes well-balanced, long aftertaste, good depth of aromas. Favourite.

This bottle is a few years old already but not sure how old, pours dark brown with red hues with a small white head.   Nose is super complex.  Caramel, raisins, toffee and sweetbread.  Malty heaven.   Taste is balanced well.  Sweet and bitter up front with a more bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is thick and fizzy as hell.  Finish is just a tad astringent but lends its self to a long aftertaste.  My mouth feels like I had poprocks minutes after the sip.  This is a truly amazing example of a great trappist beer.

Bottle at Manchester Winter Ales Festival. Musky nose full of malts. Some banana. Mouth full of fruits, bananas raisins, toffee. Sherbert. A lot less of the alcohol burn than the 10 - and a lot easier on the palate. While still as complex, tasty and interesting.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2016 0,33ml bottle and 1,5 l Cuvee Vintage 2010. Piwo o wdziecznej kremowo bezowej piance, srednio trwalej. Struktura oleista pelno mazow pozostawia na kielichu Rochefort. Pieciotetnie spore piwo bylo mocne w smaku i bardzo owocowe. Dominowaly alkoholowe nuty sherry czy koniaku skompane daktyle i figi. Slodkawe i rozgrzewajace. Nieco posmak mokrego drewna i koncowka kwaskowa alkoholowa. Nie przeszkadzalo to a wnet umilalo sylwestrowa powolna degustacje. Bardzo dlugi finisz. Klasych Cystersow polecam do starzenia bo kapitalnie i lepiej smakuje niz swierze piwo ktore kiedys pilem w malej butelce.

(Flasche) Es hat eine sehr dunkelbraune Farbe mit kleinem rötlichen Einstich. Die Schaumkrone ist leicht bräunlich und fein und es ist nicht filtriert. Das Aroma ist sehr fruchtig, citrusartig, ein bisschen Mandarine und Erde oder Zartbitterschokolade im HintergrundEs ist sehr vollmundig und schwer, schmeckt nach nassem Malz, ist leicht säuerlich und auch hefig. Außerdem ist es, vor allem im Nachgeschmack, sehr samtig. Bittere ist fast garnicht vorhanden und die Karbonisierung ist gut so. Zusammengefasst; ein sehr leckeres Bier, aber eher für einen gemütlichen Abend mit Freunden und nicht für einen Strandbesuch.
Una birra davvero eccellente. Impossibile elencare tutti gli aromi che suscita.

Rochefort 8 combines a subtle fruit and honey aroma with velvety chocolate raisin and pie crust flavors. A very warming alcohol finishes a dry light bodied Belgian ale. You should have six bottles at all times in case of a zombie uprising.

The aroma is sour balsamic vinaigrette, nutty brown sugar. Smoked wood chips. Toffee and sour raisins. Unlike anything Ive whiffed before.

The appearance is opaque brown with a red hue. Pure white head. Looks thick and chunky.

The flavor is burnt malts, toffee and brown sugar. The funk is there, but mild. Metallic aftertaste.

The palate is silky, oily and perfect for this style.

Overall, it is slick and thick; sour, sweet and malty as hello. Hint of funk followed by a sweet malty respite. Not in my top beers, but an outstanding one-off.

Pours a dark burgundy and pretty cloudy with a light brownish head. Aroma is sweet with some yeast, malts, big dark fruit, booze, and perhaps some anise. Some licorice flavor mixed in with some bready, grainy flavor. The taste is sweet at first and then does punch with the alcohol. Good warm hints of raisins, some other dried fruit, fig, and plum. Leaves a sweet, yet boozy dark fruit finish.  Great!

Dark hazy reddish brown with a nice beige head . couldnt detect much aroma . smoky taste to start then some malty caramel sweetness with a sour hint and notes of german black bread .long finish with more bitternesswith an almost earthy aftertaste .Medium body  , the high alcohol does not overpower .
Nice beer but a diffent beer like the 10 version, this brown not so sweet, with with thin, smel for not so good some caramel.
Pours a hazy, yeasty brown color.  Aroma is similar to a light dubbel  Initial flavor is spice then some dark bread tastes take over.  Some plum notes as well.

11.2 ounce bottle with 7 years of age. Aroma is filled with fruity alcohol, port, yeast,and malty notes. The flavor shows off the malts and the yeast, while there are still the port notes in the background. A really good beer.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours muddy brown with a medium beige head that collapses into a collar and skiff of foam after a minute. Big unappetizing
chunks of sediment appear in my second Trappist glass; I left a half inch of beer in the bottle even. Aroma is doughy, yeasty, funky, dark fruits, dust, pepper, caramel. Taste is sweet and meaty and turns slightly bitter, tart and dry in the finish. Carbonation is average, body is medium to full. Its a good beer, but I was expecting more.

330ml bottle. Aroma is figs, brown sugar, and molasses.  Pours cloudy tan with big lingering head.  Taste has lots of raw wort. Rich and multilayered. Raisins and brown sugar dominate. Very subtle earthy hops underneath. Finish is long and lingering. Very little heat present. Great beer.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a hazy, murky brown thick enough that no light or shadow could think of passing through. Aroma is thick with influences and reminiscences of a Cabernet Sovignon and a luscious malty presence. Taste is very much like a thick, malty, Cab. I can see why so many people rave about this beer with its proximity of taste and aromatic profile to the famed style of wine. My preference, however, lies in the 10. This beer is still one of the best in the world, though.

Bottle at home. Pours a copper brown with a white film on top. Caramel, dark fruits, a bit of breadiness on the node. Light caramel, dark fruits, apricots etc on the lovely taste. A little biscuity. It aint no 10, but its still lovely.

Bottle at home. Dark brown/copper, short lived bubbly head. Nose is big rich chocolate, caramel, hint of spice, no booze though. Sweet caramel, honey, Belgian yeastiness. Rich sweet finish, fruity and caramel. Lovely!
Pours brown with reddish tint.  Light brown head.  Aroma is light...malts and spice.  Taste is complex with bready malt, choclate, dark fruit, and warm alcohol.  A great beer.
UPDATED: JUL 26, 2012 Rochefort 10 is one of my favorites, so I expected this beer to be fine as well. I was disappointed by it. Doesn?t come close to the 10 in body, aroma and taste.

One of 7 trappist beers in the world the trappistes rochefort is an incredibly flavourful beer. has a sweet malty aroma and taste. so far I have had both the 10 and the 8. Out of the two Ive had I would say the 8 is more palatable.  Both go better with food than as a beer by itself. I look forward to trying out the 6 as well

Pours a dark, dark brown; almost black, hazy with the the yeast included.  Thick light brown head that fell away quickly.  Caramel, bread, roasty, bread fruits and alcohol on the nose - love it!.    Medium to full mouthfeel.  Whoa, the taste... the depth, deep roasty sweet malt, bread and dark fruits.  Warming alcohol finish, some raisins.  Some spicyness?
Poured a hazy dark brown with a tight light tan head.  Aroma was yeast, molasses, and alcohol.  Taste was dates, wood, bread, and alcohol. Had very nice carbonation and mouthfeel.

33 cl. bottle @ home. Hazy dark brown with an off-white head. Yeasty aroma.
Taste is bready, with some caramel. The alcohol is also noticable. Medium to strong carbonation
Dark brown body, light brown head. Chocolate, Winey Fruity notes, raisins, yeast and some citrus hops. Very smooth and quite tasty. Complex.
Bottle from Jubilation. Creamy light tan head that last forever. Oh so smooth. Bready. Cherry-its tasty, but can be a bit cough syrupy. The alcohol blends in nicely with everything.
Bottle. Pours murky fizzy head. Great smell and tastes of dark fruits, yeast, carmel, just all around great much rather drink it then write about it.

Lovely dark espresso color with a fizzy head. The nose is complex - spicy with notes of caramel, dark fruits and cinnamon. The taste is lightly bitter,  roast coffee coming from the dark malts. This beers very good, Im tasting something different every time I take a sip. The palates rich, full, and long.  A robust, great beer.

Relatively flawless beer.  Ive always just gotten the 10 because its generally the same price as the 8, but the 8 is a damn fine beer on its own.  Really nice dark fruits and spicy yeast notes.  The sweetness is light and the finish is dry.  Those monks can do it.

Ok so I though this was just hyped by people that havent had much beer but for review 1200 whatever this beer is absolutely
Ridiculous. Huge malty and raising flavors. Dry finish with some caramel flavors without the sweetness. Amazing balance, might like this more than the 10.

Clear bright red, decent tan head. A beauty.
Smells malty, alcoholic, cherry.
Spicey, sharp, alcoholic.
Bubbles bit too intense.
Just a bit too acidic and too much of a hit to go down well.

Pours a dark cola color with buddy head that diminishes to a cm thick ring. Smell was initially a little vinous with fig and dark dried fruits and some caramel sweetness.  Taste is sweet caramel, raisin, Muddled malts; not as complex as expected.  Perhaps a bit oxidized.  Finish lingers in a bubbly freshness.  Good but not in the same hemisphere as its big bro.

Arôme riche de grains, dalcool et dépices.  Couleur brune, boisée, moyennement opaque, épaisse, beau collet.  Assez sucrée, moyennement amère.  En bouche, elle a du corps, sa texture est crémeuse et la finale est assez longue.  Au fond du verre, un dépôt de levure quil faut laisser tranquille.

Big, bold, bad, and nasty.  This beer is like get smacked in the face with a sweet 2x4.  It is intensely complex and quite sweet, hinting at molasses, or some type of syrup.  It minder minds me somehow of whole wheat bread, cake batter, andis rich and buttery.  But it also has a bit of a musk to it.

Pours an opaque brown with a thick, foamy tan head...light sediment throughout.  Aroma has a very mild tartness...slightly bready...caramely with raisin and fig.  Flavor is malty but not sweet...earthy with a hint of yeasty spice...nice and roasty with just enough delicate hoppiness!  Mouthfeel is silky and smooth with a slightly dry malty/wheaty finish.

Dark and malty, heavy flavor made a bit lighter by the fairly heavy carbonation.  Coffee like notes.  Aroma is light but similar to a porter, giving hints of the dark roastiness.  The flavor is not very complex - starts heavy, gets lightened by carbonation, then fades out.  Similar to the Rochefort 6 it has a bit of a watery aftertaste.  Did not live up to the hype.  Would drink if put in front of me but I prefer others over this, including the Rochefort 6.
En alkoholkraftig belgare med typiska trappist inslag som jag tror är jäst men utöver det är det mycket sötma och lite syra samt någon krydda som jag inte kan precisera.
Bottle. Complex dark brown beer. This was my first try and it didnt disappoint.
Brown color.  Cloudy with a thick, though quickly disappearing head.  Sweet taste, alcoholly, and damn near perfect.  A shade less body than the 10.
Bottle. Brown with white head. Fruity and candy sugar flavour. Unbelievably good every time.

Pours a dark mahogany with lots of carbonation. Tan head. Aroma of plums, figs, raisins, toffee, and brown sugar. Smooth as silk mouthfeel. Taste starts semi sweet with plums and vanilla. Works into a sweet toffee with hints of candied figs, raisins and notes of peat?. Finishes incredibly clean. Very balanced beer. Alcohol is very warming and smooth. Wow this is a treat. Amazing complexity.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Pours a dark yet clear amber with thin white head. Aroma is malty, sweet and nice. Taste is essentially an orgasm in your mouth. Indescribable.
Ill leave the experts to describe this, dark brown with a frothy head. Mind bogglingly complex and should be taken seriously.
user_location: Chapel en le Frith, Derbyshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle 33 cl....It  Dark brown bit hazy body with a medium beige head.... the aroma is fruit, spices and malt... the flavor is Belgian yeast, dark fruits .. like  prunes, raisins, and caramel.... alcoholic taste finish....

Bottle to snifter. Pours red brown copper looking with a quick foamy kahki head that settles to a tight foamy film. Aroma is smokey peat and sweet nutty bread. Taste is sweet malt and spice with bitter caramel some dry nutty bread and some hidden clove and cinnamon. Palate is medium and chaulky with a dry warming finish. Very unique and interesting brew with a delicious taste.

La petite soeur de la 10 et presque aussi bonne.
Un robe rouge brun parfaite, mousse éphémère.  
Odeur complexe de vin, épice et caramel.  Intrigant  4
Goût aussi complexe que lodeur le laissait présagé.  Pétillement un peu élevé, malt caramélisé en bouche, amertume moyenne on sent passé lalcool.  Un bel équilibre.  
Arrière goût : More of the same!  Le goût reste longtemps en arrière du palais et est très plaisant.

Bottle from Beer and Spirits, Knaresborough
Appearance - Ruby brown, slight haze, slightly off white bubbly head, a little lacing.
Aroma - Spices, some herbal notes, sweet malts, slightly floral, hint of port, dark fruits - alcohol soaked raisins, varnish on old furniture. Very complex, fascinating, enigmatic aroma. Alcohol almost completely hidden.
Taste - Spices, sweet caramel malts, dark sugar, dark fruits - raisins and figs, aromatic, some yeast, warming alcohol.
Palate - Medium to high carbonation which suits the beer allowing the taste to dance around the mouth, sweet, medium body. Finish of warming alcohol with spice and fruits, lingers a little then cleans well
Overall - Aroma is fantastic, but I prefer the richer body and taste of the Rochefort 10, but it is still a superb trappist beer.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2011 33cl bottle.
Pours brown, with a dissipating off-white head.
Smells of nuts, candy sugar and malt.
Tastes sweet, with a large alcoholic bite.
Its tasty, but no where near its larger cousin.

Pours with a dense, light brown head.  A thing of beauty in its proper glass.  First sniff offers lots of caramel; followed by light floral hop aroma. Medium body, probably seems lighter due to an excellent bottle carbonation.  Lots of caramel malty character, and a long coffeeish bitter finish.  Excellent beer; one of the most elegantly presented beers Ive ever enjoyed.

Bottle. Pours murky brown with fizzy off-white head. Aroma has hints of dark fruit, dust, farmhouse, yeast and signs of lightly burnt subtle caramel. Flavor is very much the same with balanced hints of alcohol spice. Mouthfeel is medium body with lively carbonation. Excellent brew!

To my fellow Vets on this Veterans Day 2011 ... SALUTE!! By far this is the most wonderful dark strong Belgian ales that I have savored! While packed with a hearty ABV (9.2%!) it is well hidden in the flavors of brown sugar, dark chocolate, bananas, pears and cloves. This brew will definitely become a strong family favorite for us during the Thanksgiving/Christmas/New Years holidays! A bit high in price but truly worth every penny! Thick, rich and hearty and definitely a slow-sipper. Takes the chill out of the air very subtly! As the beer slowly warms, the flavors are absolutely divine!

Bottle, as pictured.  Wow, I was surprised at how dark this was.  Smelled strongly of raisins in particular, but had a spicy finish.  Surprisingly easy to drink for the style, I thought there was a bit of molasses too.  Good.

Dark cola colored beer with an off-white, frothy head. Aromas of caramel, mixed fruit, and earthy hints. Taste is a very nice mix of dried fruits, licorice, raisins, caramel, and dough. Finishes sweet, with warming booze thrown in. Very smooth, surprisingly drinkable. Tons of sediment in my glass near the end there. Overall an extremely enjoyable beer.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy dark brown coloured masterpiece brew, with an subtle taste of caramel, raisin, banana and dried fruit. True classic among the Trappist beers.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Bottle from vinmonopolet. Rich dark colour with a off white head. Chocolate and caramel aroma. A- a well blended taste with caramel, chocolate, grain and light hops. Medium carbonation.

This beer was served in a snifter. The beer was a bit colder than it should have been at the begining. I had to let it set about 20 minutes to hit its stride. 

Ar- The aroma is a rich spicey fruit cake. Nice caramel, fig and cider aromas. A bit of peppery yeast brings it together with alcohol.

Ap- The body of the beer is a dark mahogany with ruby highlights to light. Yes if you dont back light this beer you are missing out. 

T- The beer delivers on the aroma big time. The spices open up a bit more cardamon, cinnamon, and nutmeg. A but more frutiyness fig, raisins, dark berries. The finish dries out due to spice, peppery yeast and alcohol.

P- The body seems to be light but I think this is due to a scrubing nature to carbonation. The alcohol is a bit hot. I think the heat would fall out with a little age. 

O- Not a bad beer drink; however, I  think I would bypass this beer and go for the 10 every time.
P-

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours solid brown with a light creamy head. Aroma just like Rochefort 10...molasses, sweet dark fruits, honey, butterscotch. Flavour is light...sweet dark fruits such as plums, cherries, and blueberry. Some honey, yeast, molasses and brown sugar. Not as full bodied as I had expected from the 100/100 rating on here. However, still very enjoyable.

Beautiful deep redish brown colour.
Nose: Plums with a bit of yeast.
Taste: Nice and malty.
Palate: A shade short for this type of beer.
Nowhere near as good as the 10 from the same monks but nonetheless a very good ale.

From a 330ml bottle on 1/11/2011. Pours a very dark brown with lots of yeast sediment floating around. Settles with almost no head. Has a strong and very pleasant aroma of malt, dark fruit and chocolate. The flavour is disappointing in comparison. Theres a relatively bland fruit sweetness, a touch of balancing bitterness and not much else. Exhibits an almost syrupy texture. Not particularly complex or challenging. A big disappointment given its rep.
Doesnt get much better than this, other maybe than the 10 in this variety. Long finish with hints of floral notes, wheat, hay and caramel. Great beer to sit back and relax with.

Dark brown with a resilient tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, metal, bread and alcohol. Taste is really sweet; fruity and malty, with a mild bitterness. Medium bodied, average carbonation, and soapy.
A lovely deep caramel, roasty aroma. Pours deep brown with a thick white head. Slightly bitter initially with rich creamy malty flavour and a alcoholic finish.
From the bottle, sunburst with a bubbly and thin off-white head. Dissipates fast. Dark fruit, caramel, malt, yeast. Alcohol hidden. Body a little watery.

dark brown with off-white head. almost similar to the 10 but despite the lower alcohol content I feel it more notable. otherwise in the flavor and in the aroma too theres chocolate and strong fruity notes. good beer

33cl bottle pours dark with a pillowy tanned head. aroma is yeasty, bready and alcoholic, with a sweetness of caramel. taste is rich and complex. sour cherries, brandy and dark fruits, with some warmth from the alcohol. good carbonation, and a long delicious finish.. very nice!!

pours a nice brown with minimal hop aroma.  Definitely a much more subdued and balanced alcohol taste compared to the Rochefort 10.  Lots of nuts and chocolate with a fairly smooth finish.  a perfect example of a Belgian dark ale.

Red-brown with bountiful creamy, tan head and floaties.  Plum, cherry, yeast, light lactic, merlot,  toasted malt, light caramel malt.  Smooth flavor of merlot, plum, dark fruit, slight vinegar, yeast, and ending with toasted/slightly roasted malt.  Mild alcohol.  Lingering toasted malt.  Springy carbonation.  Well-attenuated.  Smooth, with good character, but not Rochefort 10.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2012 Somewhat disappointing due to the lack of character. Nothing stands out. It just tastes far too sugary for me. Used to think it was an ok Belgian ale but just not something I would chose over something with more complex flavor, now I just completely do not get this beer.
Dark Brown with a long lasting beige head.  Ripe fruit aroma up front.  Initial taste is expansive on the palate.  The alcohol is not hidden very well.  Long lingering plum fruit finish.

Bottle from el corte ingles, lisbon. Beautiful and complex beer. Ligh caramel, light alcohol and liquor aroma. Dark brown appearance with some touches of red. Taste is lightly sweet. Texture is creamy, carbonation is lively and, fortunately, finish is long.

Very nice Trappist Beer. 
Had it on an 33cl bottle and I enjoyed every single drop of it.
Nice brown color with small head.
Sweet taste but balanced.
A beer to enjoy a good book and relax at night.

OMONOIA LAOS PROTATHLIMA

Smag: medium sød, medium bitter. 
En hel del umami. 
Generelt: Helstøbt øl, hvor smag og fylde går op i en højere enhed.

11.2 ounce bottle purchased a year ago at Sun Devil Liquors in Phoenix ($4.99).  Pours a rusty dark brown with really big fizzy beige head and lots of yeast floaties.  Aroma of overripe dark fruits, vegetables, dark caramel, earthy yeast, brown sugar, and some spice.  Flavor of dark fruit (raisin, fig, cherry), smooth dark caramel, dry spice, some molasses, a bit of booze, and a hint of anise.  Sweet but not cloying.  This completes the Rochefort trifecta for me...another great ale from these Trappists.  (2246, 622)
UPDATED: OCT 23, 2011 Bottle, pours dark brown with medium head. A: plums, cookies, alcohol. T: medium sweetness. Good beer but R 10 is better....

Poured a muddy brown color with aromas of sweet  figs/plums, earthness, spice, a touch of choclate, and some sweet malt.  Flavors match the aroma, with a twinge of alcohol.  Had a nice balance of sweetness and spice.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2016 33cl bottle. Pours a black reddish with bubbly tanned head that goes down while i look at it. Many tiny but still visible bubbles. Nose : rochefort smells woderfull ! Magnifiscent aroma ! Many fruits in it : oranges, mandarines , pineapple and ofcourse red fruits. Its a masterpice when it comes to fullness and harmony. Little caramel and cherry alcohol tones. Wow ! 
Sip : Its bubbly but not annoyingly fluffy. Spicy and abviously fruity. Fruity in a really fine way; its far from being a fruit beer. I kinda enjoy it more then the 10 version because of more refreshing feeling.Tofee tones appear on the end while still mixing with the amazing fruit/caramel madness. Definitely a great beer !

Bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on October 11. Pours chestnut brown with a big grayish head. Smell is floral with yeast, figs, alcohol and spices. Taste is very sweet with figs, prunes, molasses, cloves and some alcohol. Quite nice but a tad bit too sweet.

Appearance - Deep, dark red/brown with virtually no head, small amount of carbonation. Aroma - Fruity, cherries, coffee and chocolate tones, not as rich as the 10. Initial taste - Wonderful heavy bodied chocolaty taste, slight bitterness is woven wonderfully into the overall taste. Further drinking - developes into a sweet, slightly vanilla and caramel taste, very nice indeed!

Bottle at Bishops Arms Marina, Helsingborg. 24th September 2011. 

Pours cloudy dark brown with a creamy beige head. Sweet and quite sharp aroma of raisins, esters, spices and toffee. The taste is sweet, soft and smooth with an amazing balance of flavours. Theres good maltiness and just the right amount of sugar. Vinous in the taste with flavours of dried fruit. Ends with a long mellow finish.
Deep brownish color with a cream tan head. Aroma of caramel and a rich body with flavors of grains and yeast.

Red brown with big head. Caramel malt almost chocolate , datte, lots of plum, red berries, belgian yeast. The sweet character and the hints of alcohol is very very pleasant. High carbonation and full body but this stays very drinkable. A treat!. But it stays the little chick sister of Rochefort 10.

Deep brown with red tinge and small tan head.  Aroma brown sugar, dark fruits and bread.  Full body, alcohol only there at the finish.  Malty dark sugar flavors with complex fruit flavors, a little yeasty, coffee, licorice, dry finish, a little bitter without distinct hops.  Not much else to say, fantastic.
Rich, inviting aroma w/ raisins, port, apple cider, currant, brown sugar.. in the mouth its complex, rich, delicious, layers of flavor, nicely weighted. A lovely beer.

Very nice dark colour with a two finger high tan head, which unfortunately sunk rather quickly. Fruity nice smell of dark fruits (like raisins and plums). A sort of smell I couldnt really place (maybe like red-wine or something). Some scent of spices. Same dar fruity taste, but a lot of alcohol. Smells almost better than it taste (could have been because I had another strong beer right before).

Rochefort 8 on tumman ruskea ja sen vaahto on runsas sekä lähes valkoinen. Tuoksusta löytyy kypsää banaania, lakritsia ja pientä mausteisuutta. Banaaniaromin lisäksi tuoksussa on mukana myös tummaa hedelmäisyyttä. Maussa mausteisuus ja lakritsi korostuvat enemmän. Katkeraa humalointiakin löytyy hieman. Olut jättää suuhun pikkuisen kuivan tunteen ja on runsas sekä lempeän hapokas.

330mL bottle from a trade with a friend in Montreal. Thanks Dan! Been wanting to try this one for a while. Pours an opaque reddish brown with a large tan head and loads of floaties. Aroma is really nice, quite sharp and perfume-like. Dry yeast characters, floral, deep rich malts and mild dark fruit, just perfectly presented, I could sniff this all night! But to drink it is even better, or course. Nice chewy malts upfront, almost nutty, with some raisin and date, figs, boozy finish and aftertaste that actually doesnt take away a lot from the beer. It actually feels like a bigger beer to me than the 10, though I havent had the 10 in a long time. Feels awesome on the palate, good and thick with some dryness from the alcohol. Lingering notes of figs and candi sugar. Awesome stuff, I wish the LCBO could bring in some Rochefort outside of consignment orders.

Impressive strong Belgian Ale although a bit too bitter for my taste, has some coffee in its taste and it somehow reminded me a little of Imperial Stout. Its palate is incredible and the beer develops wonderful in your mouth.

Subtle aroma of dark fruit, grain and yeast.  Fancy peeps here at ratebeer.com say plums and what not.  Could be??  I dont care. This is a great beer.  Robust and refined.  Creamy, complex and boozy.

Bottle at home. Pours a lovely deep ruby colour with a decent beige head. Big barley nose up front with caramel, treacle, alcohol and a rum and raisin chocolate character. Flavour-wise, this is quite complex with raisins, plums, pudding and ginger. Alcohol is quite present with a long hum and lingering raisins and caramel. An oily mouth-feel despite moderate carbonation and a fair CO2 prickle. Maybe a bit too highly carbonated for me but superb nonetheless!

Bottle @ The Ponsonby Belgian Beer Cafe. Opaque, deep mahogany pour with a persistent, off-white head leaving heavy lace that subsides quickly. Brandy and dark fruit nose. Medium body with lively carbonation. Figs, cognac, brown sugar and some yeast. Ethanol burn is fairly prominent, emphasising the spirit aromas. Short, balanced finish with continued ethanol burn. Need to try the 10, but so far I slightly prefer Goose Islands Pere Jacques. Blasphemy, I know.

Pour is a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is of brown sugar with some dark fruit and alcohol.  Flavor is much the same.  Big dark fruit flavor.  Lots of fig and plum.  Also has lots of dark sugar with a spicy bite to it.  Hides the alcohol better than the aroma.  Stellar beer.

Pours a dark reddish/brown with two fingers of off-white head.  Leaves a good bit of lace as it is swirled around.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with a little bread and a bit of zip to it.  Taste is figs and dates, brown sugar, roasted coffee, caramel and vanilla, and leaves a little bitterness on the tongue.  The alcohol is very warming but not over the top.  Medium body with a good bit of carbonation.  To this date, the first belgian strong ale Ive had and is leaving a nice impression.  I have the 10 waiting on me and maybe one day ill come across a westy 12 and really know what they are like.
Deep cloudy brown with a minimal pale head. Aroma is dark fruits, brown sugar. Medium body with reasonable carbonation. Taste is grape skins, malt, dates with a slight bitterness in the finish.

Pours dark brown with a medium head.  Aroma is brown bread, brown sugar, and a little caramel.  Taste is sweet with bread, fruit and spice.  Creamy, smooth, mouthfeel.  This is a classic that lives up to its reputation.

Bière brune opaque. Des odeurs fruitées me dilatent les narines avec ses effluves de melon miel et de pêches accompagnées de notes maltées, houblonnées et alcoolisées qui nous amènent vers un parfum sucré de biscuit davoine. En bouche cet élixir dégage un fin fumet dherbes, dépices et dalcool, le tout très bien amalgamé avec le malt, laissant une agréable amertume. Sublime.
Its no 10 but it is a very solid Belgium Strong none the less.  Pours a mahogany with a touch of off white head. nice yeast, malt, dark fruit nose and taste.

Dark reddish-brown colour. Aroma of coffee, caramel (brown suger), dark berry (blueberry or blackberry). Medium carbonation. Taste of malt, caramel, nut, peach, coffee, toffee and roast chocolate. Low bitterness.  Too complicated for me to understand needs to be revewed again. Some say it needs to age too.
Deep ruby brown with thin cream head. Slightly metallic on the nose with some nutmeg. Spicy alcohol soaked fruit with a long and moreish finish.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Chocolate brown with an orange-yellow cast. Very foamy head at first that settles down an leaves a thin persistent layer. Lots of floaties.

Aroma: Plums, figs and other sweet dark fruit. Some alcohol and mustiness.

Taste: Strong sweet figs, plum, caramel and sugar counterbalanced by light leathery and musty yeast. Dries out slightly toward the end and becomes an intoxicating mixture of dry, sweet and musty malts.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, chewy, smooth body with a light dry finish. Warming.

Overall: Complex, yet very approachable. Gotta love the monks.

The body was a medium-brown, cloudy and with a creamy plush head. Smelled of biscuits, raisins, ginger, caramel and alcohol. The flavor was of hops, fig, honey and nutmeg before a mellow finish. Left a warmth from the alcohol and had a smooth finish.
33 cl, served in a Chimay glass. Brown with a little head that dissapears in a while. Earthy aroma with dark fruits and some hops. Spicy taste, some dark fruit and candy, not too sweet. Unique

Pour mahogany brown with off white head. Aroma spicy, earthy, hop bitterness, candy sugar, dark fruit, bread, yeast. Taste plant like, earthy, slight bitterness, dark fruit, bread, yeast, candy sugar, grassy, sweet. MF full body light fine carb. Super solid brew very tasty and has unique flavors that are quite complex.

Sep 11. hazy dark red/brown with a nice head. Smells of fruit, some applejuice amongst them. Sweet and delicious... The taste on the other hand starts off small with some sweetness aswell and builds up to a strong lasting aftertaste that makes you all warm inside... Some distant alcohol flavor.

Pours a dark brown with a small tan off white head.
Aroma of bread, malt, sweet fruit. Taste of bread, sweet malts, with a thick feel with medium carbonation. Very clean lingering finish with a touch of the higher alcohol content. A very nice beer.

999!  This one is an obvious amazing selection when you feel like dropping the coin.  Dark fruits in light manner and yeasty bread filled nose.  Big and malty flavors throughout.  A classic all the way around.

Pours dark brown with high frizzy thick head. Aromas of orange, dark bread and syrup. Tate is slightly burned brown sugar,  but still a quite mildly falvoured trappist. There are some bitterness and you can also taste some coffee. Quite creamy and carbonated texture.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2014 Re-rate, January 11th 2014. Unclear red-brown color, full sized off-white to beige head that lasts for quite some time. Smell and taste malts, some caramel, some sweet-bitter, lightly hints of raisins, dried fruits and nuts. Medium to full body and carbonation. [Original rating: Bottle at Cafe buitenlust, Oirschot. Dark brown color, light brown head. Not the best smell, but a nice taste. Medium to firm carbo, medium to full body. (6-4-8-4-14=3.6)]

Die Farbe erinnert mich an Coca-Cola. Der Schaum ist wenig haltbar. 
Dem süßlichen Lakritzgeruch, folgt ein malzig-süßes, fruchtiges Geschmackserlebnis. 
Die 9,2% Alkohol wirken erst im Abgang wärmend in der Kehle. 
Störend empfinde ich bei diesem Bier, daß es nach der Hälfte der Flasche irgendwie an Substanz einbüßt, ja sogar ins Wässrige abgleitet. 
Trotzdem gut trinkbar. Ein Spitzenprodukt ist es für mich aber nicht.Test vom 14.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Not an overly "big beer". The aroma is modestly staged, proven to be a false indicator of the containing tastes; all of which are crisp and well balanced. Lots of notes of malts, hops and fruit. Suprisingly easy to drink considering its strength. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2015 Easily one of the nicest smelling beers I have ever experienced. A beautiful sweet fresh fruit flavour with notes of malt. Poured cloudy and brown with a diminishing bubbly head. The taste on this beer was quite unique, very distinctly Belgian with some spices and wine character. The taste was not overwhelming up front, but the aftertaste was strong and delicious. The palate was unexpectedly crisp and clean for a beer of such strength, slightly alcoholic. A delicious offering from Rochefort, a beer Id like to explore more in the future!

20150303: Aroma of rich sweet plum and caramel sweet malts. Cloudy brown with a tan head, beautiful. Flavor is astounding and complex, rich long aftertaste, lots of candied fruit, rich malty flavors with yeasty and spicy notes. Tingles your tongue, slightly boozy, absolutely astounding.

The pour is dark amber with a slight haze and a goodly amount of carbonation building to a soft, frothy head.  The aroma tended to be sweeter than some of its counterparts with a candied maltiness on the nose. The body was good.  The taste was also sweet but the finish was clean.  A desirable beer.

Bottle at SAQ.  Pours a muddy brown with a lofty and dimpled beige head.  Interesting aromatic profile of sweet plum, earthy spices and woodiness.  Flavor is a blend of candied fruits and slight boozy character that fades into a touch of alcoholic heat on the tongue.  Carbonation is surprisingly soft and lends a very thin and almost watery palate to the beer; though there is complexity enough in the flavor to balance it out overall.  Dangerously drinkable for the style, and I quickly envisioned pairing this beer with a fine cigar.

Pours a dark murky brown with a huge light brown head. Aroma is dark fruits, spices, a little chocolate and alcohol. Taste is very complex with heaps of dark fruits, chocolate, sweet malt, spices leading to a beautifully warm alcohol feel. Lovely and soft in the mouth. Fantastic ale.

Pours a beautiful mahogany with a big foamy white head that dissipates very quickly. This beer is what beer is all about. This beer shows that when Beer is made right, you cant help but fall in love. Very complex with a lot going on. You get hops, yeast, sweet malts, some belgian candi, prunes, and even wood and forrest floor. The last earthy bit is so nice. Well balanced beer, too.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2012 
33 cl bottle. BBE 20.05.2014.
The dark fruit aromas have got a lot stronger, same thing with the liquorice. Some similarities with Mikkeller Santas Little Helper 2008. The sweet elements on the flavor seemed to have smoothened a bit too. Still very complex brew, definitely have to save some bottles for near bbe date tasting.
33 cl bottle. BBE 09.03.2016.
Originally rated on 20090915.
Pours dark ruby red with large head which leaves a little lacing. Theres a lot going on in the aroma, orange peel, earthy malts, belgian yeast, sugar candy, caramel and some prunes and raisins. The taste does not fall short with its complexity, dark malts, yeast, sugar candy, caramel, orange and raisins. Additionally, a bit of toffee and licorice at the end. Lots of carbonation, some sourness, a bit sticky palate and a bitter finish. Full-bodied, complex and very enjoyable.
5338

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 The aroma is rich and intricate, with dark fruits, caramel, molasses, spices, some chocolate, and even some rich, leathery notes. The mouthfeel is energetic, with a medium body and vigorous carbonation. The taste is complex and layered, if a bit astringent for the sweeter estery flavors to shine through. That said, I enjoy it more than the stronger and boozier R10.
Smooth and full dark belgian beer. One can taste the alcohol though it plays with the strong malt and barley

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2012 Have to re-rate this following more extensive trial, and especially a face-off against the 10. Its a great beer, that has to be said up front. A world-class beer, even. But its not the 10...  Pours dark brown with a medium tan head. You really have to hold this beer to a light to appreciate the complexity. Its murky, not fizzy. Theres so much sediment, so much stuff in there. The color changes depending on the light... As with the 10, its an easy 5/5 on looks alone. Aroma is rich, with lots of dried dark fruit: prunes, raisins. Theres port wine there, and alcohol which is surprisingly present (much more than in the 10...). Also brown sugar, pepper and a hint of dark chocolate. Taste is malty and sweet yet complex with a very subtle yet clearly present bitterness lingering in the background. The alcohol, again, is quite present. Body is medium with fairly high carbonation, but the pleasant and balanced variety that refreshes, especially in a beer this strong.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2016 Brown body, off white head. Really fantastic aroma of dried fruit, molasses, biscuits, bubblegum, vanilla, belgian candy yeast. Taste is rich, sweet, dried fruit, with a dry finish. Palate is tingly. Excellent beer.

Bouteille 330 ml. 9.2%. Couleur brune voilée, mousse beige mince. Arôme de prunes, un peu de vin dorge, sucre et fruits mûrs....un peu de chocolat. En bouche, fruits mûrs, caramel, alcool et toffee. Bière complexes de grande qualité. Finale en alcool, prunes rouges et un peu de sucre. Très Bonne.
(This beer rating was imported from FB and unfortunately lacks any further comments.)

33 cl bottle, BBE 141015
Rather spicy has some aged fruits. Flavour has also lot of spices, some aged fruits. Alcohol-fulfilled finish. Quite much CO2 on dryish palate. Good, but too much CO2 and stands in the shadow of R10. It definitely has something that this lacks.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2011 Fantastic Belgian. Deep complexity of flavors with a very smooth finish, left one trying to find all the undertone flavors. Poured from bottle, with not much white frothy head. Color was very dark.
Pours hazy brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma us malts, yeast, dark fruits and alcohol. Flavor is quite strong along the lines of the aroma. Superb.

Pours a nice dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is malt, chocolate, some Christmas spices, yeast.  Taste of raisins, fresh figs, medium-dark chocolate, malt, bit of brown sugar.  Finish is syrup and pepper.  What a great beer.
Nellolimpo decisamente della produzione trappista belga, che volete che vi dica VIVA VIVA, splendida!!!

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish-brown.  Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, sweet caramel, yeast.  Taste is sweet and slightly spicy, a bit diacetyl.  Carbonation is bordering on being unpleasant to me, but is otherwise acceptable.  This is my least favorite of the three.

Date: July 22, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Opaque brown with large amount of white and off-white head and floating sediment.  Aroma: Alcohol and fruity. Flavor: Consistent with aroma, starts little sweet with alcohol finish and very smooth with very small amount of carbonation. Other: I seem to be way off the mark here compared to the masses with my drinking experience of this product, so maybe I got a bad bottle.  I will have to try this one again sometime for comparison.

Beer pours dark brown, hazy with sediment in suspension and a creamy light brown head. Wonderful aroma of berries, light chocolate malt, dried fruit and yeast. Very complex flavour reflects the aroma. Palate is creamy and full with soft carbonation. Finish is lingering complex fruity and malt dominated. Alcohol complements the complex flavour. This beer is a masterful creation.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2011 Sexy en apparence avec sa couleur rouge sombre et son effervescence de champagne. Elle se boit justement plus comme un mousseux avec le caractère du raisin et des épices. Un spécimen assez unique.

330ml bottle.
Dark reddish brown will some off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, dark fruit, Belgian yeast - great rasin flavor with some chocolate and spicy yeast.  Very smooth and quite drinkable for the ABV.
Bottle from Alko. Originally rated on 6.6.2009. Excellent, strong but well balanced and tasty Belgian Strong Ale.

I find this beer hard to find but man, it is worth going out of the way for or paying an extra couple bucks.
It is my favorite out of the three, for it gives something that North America has never came close to.

Appearance - Rochefort 8 has about one half a finger of head on the initial pour. C Appearance was medium to dark brown and pleasing to the eye. Some dark yeast specks could be seen floating near the bottom of the glass that I poured it into.

Smell - The smell of the beer is quite sweet and full bodied. I smelled raisins and plums. 

Taste - The taste to this beer was very mellow and pleasing. All tastes were in perfect balance. I could taste raisins and plums as it went down. Very slight caramel note as well.Could not taste the alcohol content at all. 

Mouthfeel - Pretty heavily bodied. The beer was very smooth and pleasing.

Overall - This beer was very good. Almost perfect, but not quite there yet. I guess I am a little hard to please. A very well-brewed beer. I would have liked the taste that I experienced during the middle of my sip to have been a little stronger.

Given to me by a neighbor during 4th of july, this beer was amazing. Dark and smooth with not much of the high carbonation of the belgians. If this is what a real Belgian beer tastes like, i may have to become a fan.

33cl bottle. Pours chestnut with a purple/red hue and a generous head. The nose has stewed apple, vanilla and just a hint of dark chocolate. The taste has more stewed apple, cinnamon, liquorice and coffee. The palate is rich in structure, thick in texture and the finish falls away nice and elegantly. Overall, an excellent beer.

Pours cloudy dark brown color with a large foamy tan head.  Aroma is of dark grapes/cherries.  Taste is sweet with alcohol burning early in the taste.  The finish is maple sweet and slightly spicy.  Overall, an easy drinking yet strong offering from Rochefort.

Pours a hazy brown with a full frothy head.  Aroma of raison, some candy sugar, malt.  Med sweetness, lite bitter and dryness.  Med body, creamier texture, ave carbonation, long finish.  Alcohol comes through at end.  Very complex.

Pour is a deep brown color with a nice foamy light tan head. Nose is of dark fruits. Taste is very much the same with a good chunk of candi sugar. Very light on the palate which is nice for a for a Belgian strong.
Aromas of dark fruits and sweet malts.  Flavors of dark fruit, figs/dates and belgian candy sugar.  Overall a very good belgian strong ale
I do like the taste and smell, but i didnt really like the mouthfeel of this one. A good beer, not my favorite style. Will probably drink this one again soon.

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours very dark brown with a small tan head. The aroma is dark fruit, figs, apples, caramel, fresh bread, and ripe bananas. The flavor is intense sweetness up front through the middle, and a faintly bitter and musty end. The palate is very heavy, thick and syrupy. The carbonation is lively and adds a crispness to the mouthfeel. The finish is long and warming, with a pleasant and faint aftertaste. Overall, this is an astoundingly good beer. Complex and powerful, but well balanced and never abrasive or abrupt. The flavors mix wonderfully, and finish well. Easy mouthfeel, and great finish.

Ive just had a bottle of the Rochefort 6, so Im expecting great things. Poured hazy russet brown with a fluffy off-white head.
