But the expectation of a trappist ale makes my appreciation of the appearance of this beer different to how Id usually rate other styles. The aroma is rich and complex. Dried fruits, chocolate, spices, Christmas cake, I have never given a ten for aroma before.
Full, rich and complex. Raisins, cinnamon, allspice and loveliness. Toasty and nutty, sweet and unctuous. Wow. Just wow. I wont be forgetting this one for a while.

A true pleasure and one of my favorites. 33 ml bootle poured into Trappist glass at 6C. Poured a dark amber with half inch light brown head that dissipated slowly. Arouma is sweet and of burnt malts. Pleasing. Velvet to the mouth, with moderate carbonation at front, smooth and light bodied in the mild, and a pleasing mild burn at the end (also described by others). A lot going on in the taste, but definitely not too much. Just right! Sweet, burnt malt, and bitter after tones. Overall, top shelf.
A deep brown succulent beverage with just enough bitterness to complete the sweetness.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2014 Pours deep brown, with a very fizzy, lively tan foam. Nose is very sweet, bubblegum. Sweet, very tasteful. Fizzy on the top of the mouth. Aroma of bubblegum, burnt malt. Havent tasted any beers like this before, but I like it. Looking forward to the #10 I also bought today.

Re-rate: This dese-rves better, its one of my few go-to beers. Upping some of its stats.  8-3-8-4-16

Re-rate 2: One of the beers I always come back to. Several times a year even. Pours mahogany. Quite a bit of bubbly, very slightly tan head. Caramel, cherry, alcohol, malt nose. Sweet. A bit bitter in the ending, Bubblegum, cherry, cola, caramel, malt aroma. Frizzy carbonation, warming alcohol mouth feel. A bit over medium thick body, which fits this beer. 10-4-9-4-19 (I need to rerate more beers!)

Brown colour with big, fast dissapearing head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, raisins, green apples. Taste is slightly sweeter than the rochefort 6. Medium carbonation with moderate alcohol taste. Good trappist

At publicisdrugstore in paris, 33cl bottle. Murky brown red color, huge quickly fading head.  Very fine carbonation, awesome mouth feel. Fig and chocolate aroma, smooth mouth feel, really unique. Super drinkable. Super sweet nose.
Hazy reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, dark chocolate, dried fruit, yeasty and spicy. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and bitter finish. 110611

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012 75cl bottle at home. Delicious. Huge beige head, dark brown reddish color, great lacing. Sweet aroma, slight alcohol. One of my favorite beers. sweet but not too sweet. Thin back end. Flavor of dark malt, sweet fruits... Well carbonated. Very clean finish. Rochefort should be proud.

Bottle in De Paas.  Pours dark, slightly hazy brown with small but lasting white head.  Aroma has dark fruits, slight chocolate, raisins.  Flavor has same as aroma with figs, leather, malt and a slight alcohol aftertaste.  Carbonation is soft to medium.  Great example of the style.

Wonderful aroma of malt, chocolate and figs.

Pours a dark brown with a one finger size head. The head lingers, especially around the rim for the duration.

Taste is delicious. The sweetness is appealing, and I dont really care for sweet beers. The sweet fades fast giving way to a dry, rich taste. Front of tongue and back are superior.

Overall, a slendid drink.

poured from the bottle into its corresponding glass. It has a wonderfully toasted malty aroma. It has a dark brown body that you can see light through. Taste is absolutely amazing; roasted malts, raisin, clove, sweet Belgian sugars... wonderful. Medium body to the palate, average carbonation with a delightful alcohol burn as it finishes. This beer was just great.

Bouteille de 33cl. Couleur cola opaque, très joli mousse crêmeuse de belle tenue. Très intense aromatiquement , puissamment fruitée, du fruit rouge et noir, pruneaux et un alcool présent juste ce quil faut. Très agréable sensation en bouche. Un must! Trouvée à Vanuxeem - Ploegstaert.

Truly an incredible beer. Seems like you could drink this forever and detect different aromas every time there is so much depth. Im getting some of the burnt malts, but not much. Dark fruit, like plus and maybe cherries. Maybe dark chocolate. Oily mouthfeel. Top notch.

This is one that everybody should try at least once. When poured its too black to even look through the glass and that leaves you curious. The malt used to brew this beer must be burned to a crisp to make it this dark. A nice thin foam head on top that settles quickly. When tasted it gives you hints of mocca, chocolate and caramel. Really sweet but not too sweet in my humble opinion. There is also hints of fruit to be found, bit of apple perhaps. Rochefort 8 leaves me craving for more and I will defintely try this one again and certainly look op the no 6 and no 10!

(bottle). Hazy dark brown color. Small off white head. Sweet toasted malt aroma, with moderate raisin and dried cherry. Sweet toasted malt flavor, with moderate spiciness and light bitterness. Avg duration. Dry finish, with moderate alcohol and light sweetness. Medium to ful body, Moderate alcohol warmth. High carbonation. Spare lacing.

Bottle. Amber/Brown in colour and a little tanden head with large bubbles. The aroma has notes of caramel and fruit (banana and plums). The taste is fruity and you can sence bread and caramel notes as well. This is a really nice Trappist
Smells a little like wet dog as well as a bit earthy. Very carbonated and a complex flavor. I think Im a bit jaded because Im comparing it to the 10, which is much smoother and much tastier.
Bottle. Pours purplish brown. Off white almost tan head. Nose/taste of raisin, dates, dried figs, yeast and toffee as well as miscellaneous other dark fruits. Highly carbonated. Well balanced.

Poured without letting any yeast sediment into the glass, leaving a clear deep mahogany beer in the glass with a small but dense creme colored head. Beautiful! The aroma is of fine chocolate with raisins and plums, with a delicate sweetness. Very deep aromas. Taste is luxuos and smooth with more plum confit and fine chocolate. It has a bit thin finish though and the carbonation is a bit too spritzy. Overall a great beer though.
A lot lighter and smoother than the 10. The better of the two. Now I have to try the 6.
This is what you get when you spend most of your time on your craft! Brewing excellence... This stuff was undescribably good and it hit me like a Megaton Nuclear Warhead!

11.2 oz bottle poured into a goblet glass.  It pours a deep brown color with red tinge.  The head is a nice light tan and is full of large bubbles.  The aroma is amazing with notes of burnt sugar, like creme brulee, or burnt marshmallows.  Also get notes of fruit like banana and plums on the nose.  Taste is every bit as good as the hype.  There are notes of bread, dried fruits, and candy, with a nice balanced finish.  This is one of the best Abbey beers I have had, definitely lives up to the reputation.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2015 30/4/2011 Pours very dark brown in glass, almost black. 2 cm off white foam head. Nose is leather, banana cake, sarsaparilla, Taste is potent and aromatic in the mouth. Alcoholic on the tongue and finish. Taste is dried fruit, prune, raisins, figs, sarsaparilla, yeast, bit of dark chocolate. This is something you want to drink in Winter. Warms you up. Complex on the palate, but couldnt drink it like wine. too potent. 3.8 Re-rate 06/08/2015 Bottle from Dranken Pauwels, Opaque very dark brown, large off white head, which dissipates to thin. Nose is candy sugar, caramel, banana, dark fruits, plum, dried fig, prune, raisins, pear, toasted malt grains, rye bread, little red vinous. Beautiful pear, dried fruit and Taste is soft, malty, caramel, banana, dried figs, prune, sultana, floral aromatic, little parma violet, toasted cereal. Finish is dried fruit and a little spicy Christmas cake.

There was so much hype surrounding this beer with all of its romantic notions of 450 years of tradition and secret recipes and such, I figured there was no way it could possibly live up. It completely blew me away. It is every bit as good as they say it is. Aroma is a bit of leather mixed with a bready, yeasty. Appearance is brownish red with a cream colored head that doesnt die. Taste is incredible, everything the aroma promised and so much more. Dark cherry, apple, yeast, leather, tiny hints of chocolate a nice warming finish. Palate is dry but not too dry. Incredible beer. Truly breathtaking.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Dark brown pour with a thin tan head sitting atop. Dark fruits, caramel and something sour come through on the nose. All the dark fruits coming through in the taste - plum, raisin, currant, fig. Some chocolate and wood in there as well. Good beeer, the 10 is better though

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2013 Aroma: Sour, like vinegar...a little reminiscent of a lambic. Earthy, complemented by a subdued smell of candied sugar and raisins. Malts and booze arrive at the party but arent the main guests. 

Appearance: Ive had this beer in a few different glasses and the slim Trappistes Rochefort tulip thingy makes this beer look ace, though the aroma is slightly sacrificed. How you pour it will have a direct effect on the amount of sediment, clarity and color of the beer...its usually a murky brown, but I was careful and got a clear, dark blood red/brown. Some carbonation. Head is off-white, very active and diminishes quick, though that is very dependent on how old the bottle is. Beer looks very dark and sinister and scares all but the most curious away.

Taste: Caramel, dark chocolate, bit of coffee, earthy, woody flavors with a somewhat yeasty finish...this is like drinking a fruitcake. You can find lots more if you take the time and "hmm" and "ahh" about it. Complex and well balanced.

Palate: Oily and clingy...but it complements the beer well. Nice carbonation too thats tingly, though its appearance has you thinking otherwise. Alcohol isnt transparent but it does have a bit part to play in the character of the beer.

Overall: Stands in the shadow of the 10? How could you. Each grade has a different feel to it...different moods or occasions will call for whichever one I want at the moment. Nobody makes a better beverage than Rochefort...I hope theyre proud!

Rating no. 100!
Nice head, brownish, dark redbrown.
fruity nose, prune, figs, cardboard (!?) - nice except for the cardboard.
medium body, very long - harmonic!
Delicious with chocolate, fruitcake, dried prunes, dried redberries.
Really good as I think the cardboard note comes either from glas or bad storage.

Bottle pours deep brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel apple, milk chocolate, raisins, and light spice.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of cocoa, plum, nutmeg, and clove.

Clear deep caramel brown huge tan head, medium sized bubbles, little lacing, retention like crazy.. Sweet caramel aroma, malty, some subtle dark fruits and light smoke... Flavors follow suit, wish there was a touch more of a distinct belgian candi quality... Lively medium full body, warming, slick body... Good, but not in the very upper echelon for me...

Dark brown pour with a huge tan head. Aroma of plums, caramel and dried fruits. Tastes of raisins, plum, caramel and a dry finish until the carbonation settled down. A little thinner mouthfeel than I expected but a very good beer otherwise.

bottle; cloudy dark brown with thick pale brown head; aroma-caramel, alcohol, spice, plums and dried fruits. I really have a hard time defining it more specifically; taste-mild sweetness, moderate carbonation and moderate long-lasting bitter. Great beer, a little heavy

Looking forward to rate this one, a true classic, the 6 was very good, but not unforgetable. 33 cl. bottle from the supermarket. Poured into a trappist glass. Deep mahogany colour with a light tan head, that goes from big to small, but longlasting. Aroma is breathtaking. Tons of dark fruit, yeast, plums, figs and cherries. Very sweet caramel notes. Hint of roast and a touch of alcohol. A intense flavor: Lots of roasted malt and overwhelming amounts of dark fruits.  Palate is creamy and perfectly carbonated. The aftertaste lasts for a very long time, and keeps coming back. Its far better than the 6, and I cannot wait to taste the 10. This one gets a very high rating...

33cl bottle.  Pours cloudy mahogany/brown with fairly large amount of khaki/white head, that dissipates quickly and moderately laces.  Nose is raisins, cereal malt and a fair amount of yeast character, leather, and spice. Taste is caramelized malts, dried fruits, alcohol spiciness, and a well balanced herbal bitterness. finish is slightly boozy and slightly fruity.

12 oz. bottle poured into snifter. Fantastic fruity smell rich with notes of raisin. For a beer with an ABV of 9.2%, this ale does not have an overwhelming alcohol taste on the front or back ends. Silky smooth mouthfeel and a slightly sweet fruit flavor round out this magnificent ale. This is simply one of the best beers I have ever had the pleasure of drinking.

Bottle  330ml.

Dark brown, opaque color. Great alcoholic aroma. On the tastebuds, caramel, roasted walnut taste with a good presence of alcool. Well-balanced beer. A great beer to try.
En deilig øl!  Fine fornemmelser av sjokolade og kaffe.  Belgisk gjær og masse snadder.  Litt lettere enn storebror Rochefort 10...    Deilig ettersmak.
Agreeable strong ale. Does a good job of pleasuring the tastebuds. Id have another.

Poured from a bottle into a goblet. Beer is brown and really hazy. Forms a thick off white head made up of small and medium bubbles. I cannot determine the level of carbonation due to the haziness. Head leaves some lacing on the glass.

Sweet smell, nice aroma that includes fruit and a strong malt presence. This beer smells wonderful. I can pick up a slight alcohol aroma as well.

Spicy, medium body, sweet and peppery (is that allowed in a beer review). Beer bites me at first, a big shock. Im thinking I should grab a few of these and age them for years. Drinkability is good and mouthfeel is good. Second taste, beer is a little thin for my expectation, taste is pretty good, a little bready / biscuity, not as aromatic or honey like as I expected. Overall a good beer but not my favorite trappist.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 11.2 oz. bottle in a Trappiste glass.  Hazy opaque brown pour with minimal tan head.  Toffee and caramel aroma.  Alcohol and caramel flavors.  Sweet up front with a mild bite on the finish.  I think I like 10 the best, but I would need to have all three in front of me to truly compare.  Excellent ale.  Definitely let it sit for a little while.  It got better over time and not as cold out of the fridge!

poured into a snifter. pours a cloudy mahogany with a slightly tan head that drops rather quickly, but not all the way. Decent lacing. Sweet malty nose that has a sharp prune aroma. The high alcohol is definitely in the nose as well, with a hint of cinnamon. Highly carbonated and a little rough on the first sip. Raisins and prunes are the first thing I get from this, followed by a ton of spices. I also get baked apples and pears from this as well. Feels outstanding to drink this. I love trappist beers.

As far as I am concerned, the only better Belgian beer than this is Wesies Blonde/8.  This is a wonderful beer and a total sipper.  Although I would love to drink 3-6 in a sitting, I wouldnt be able to walk away AND it would cost me an arm and a leg.  Its wonderful, full bodied beer, sweet and just what you expect from a great Belgian beer.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2014 Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma of dark ripe fruits, caramel, marzipan, wine and small hints of alcohol. Taste of dried dark berries, dark ripe fruits, vinous notes, caramel, dark malts and brown sugar.

Poured into a large bowl-shaped white wine glass to substitute for a trappist glass. I made a rookie mistake while distracted and poured all the yeasty sediment into the glass. Sometimes this doesnt matter but this time there was enough to affect the experience. Ill have to get another one sometime.

Rochefort 8 poured medium rusty brown with a nice two finger frothy head developing. Retention and lacing were both above average. 

The aroma was of dark fruits - plums, raising, and figs with candi sugar, liquorice and yeast. 

The taste was quite sweet with the first notes again being of dark fruits. The candi sugar and liquorice are again present midway through the sip but give way to a bit of a sour finish. Quite nice.

The mouthfeel was spot on for this beer. It was medium bodied with moderate carbonation. A little agitation bring a nice collar throughout the drink. 

I enjoyed this beer but it didnt live up to the hype - perhaps this is my fault for botching the pour. Ill give it a try again sometime but for now Id take prefer the Rochefort 10.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2012 Dark and warming, tastes were of dried fruit, christmas pudding and brandy, one to savour

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2013 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: sweet, brown sugar, raisins, prunes & figs, spice, caramel, earthly malts, tastes like the 10s little brother //////// Re-rate: 33 cl. bottle @ home. Procured from the supermarket. BBF 25/07/2018. Pours dark hazy amber, touch copper, creamy off-white head. Smells very fruity, bubblegum, figs, prunes, candy sugar, soft sweet light brown bread, soft BE yeast, raisins, berries, incredible, Taste is an explosion of bubblegum fruit, white & brown bread, figs, raisins, prunes, BE yeast, sweet spices, tiny hint of liquorish, soft, juicy, hint cocoa. Total bubblegum body. Drinks like water. Man this is incredible, I remember this being good but this is ridiculous. Different from the 10, a different experience, more of a drinking as opposed to sipping beer. Upped to 4.8 for now.

Bottle. Im talking to a friend as I pour so in goes the yeast without even trying the beer without it. Gotta pay better attention next time. Dark, deep, woody(?) brown with not a lot of slightly beigeish head. Aroma has a lot of liquorice in it. Some fruits as well as some spiciness and a bit of yeast. Taste begins with heady amount of liquorice, transforming into a mix of candied sugar, spiciness and yeast and finally settling again into a warm mixture of liquorice, fruits and alcohol. Palate is medium and quite carbonated. Not as full as youd expect or like.
Bottle from Beer Tempel, Brussels. Mild malty aroma. Dark brown colour with a good foamy beige head. Strong bitter malt flavour. Sour aftertaste. Too strong for me.

330 ml bottle poured into tumbler (alas the in-laws do not have a proper trappist glass!). Pour begins clear, but some sediment at the bottom of the bottle. Thick brown colour with a small hint of red or purple. Tan-white head that is fizzy to begin but settles to a thicker half-inch. Aroma is fantastic; dominated by raisin and plum, but also fruity, berry, floral hops, lemon, cinnamon and more that I cannot quite articulate. Taste is phenomenal. Can something this complex and with this much alcohol taste bright and lively? Apparently. Sugar, plum, raisin, cinnamon, malty, berries, fruit and on and on. So well balanced, no hint of alcohol. This is the second time Ive tried the 8, and last time I tried it I liked it better than the 10. Outside of Westvleteren 12, this might be my favourite beer. Absolutely brilliant.

Really great, duh, you knew that before you got here.  It really is like a light "10" which is odd because its 9.2% and you dont expect to call something light with that sort of gravity.  Plum, sugar, berry, light carbonation...much quicker finish than 10.  Very very good.

Hazy metallic brown with a tan to off-white, three finger head.  The head remains through many sips.  

Very yeasty and fruity aroma.  Overripe fruit and doughy bread.  Dates, pears, bananas, apples.  Alcohol is present too.  

Taste follows the aroma but slighty more mellow and dry.  Crisp and full.  More bready than fruity but the fruit is very present.  Mutligrain sourdough with baked apples, raisins and dates.  

Delicious and complex.  Fruity and refreshing.  Drinks fully but not heavy.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2011 average sized tan head, hazy, brown colour
light malty aroma, maybe a bit of toffee or caramel. alcohol aroma is huge, almost like a spirit
med body, creamy and slightly fizzy w/ a chalky finish
moderately sweet w/ the same finish
tastes of toast, cobwebs, and softly yeasty
not as good as the 10yo

Pours deep brown with a nice beize head. Head remains full and slightly laces nicely. Dark fruit and high alcohol on the nose. Well-rounded mouthfeel with spritzy carbonated covering. Very complex flavor of malt, dark fruit and alcohol.
bOttle.  Do you really need a description of this beer??  If so, head down to your local market, pick up a couple singles, and get busy discovering the trappist way....

A bready, biscuit like aroma with caramelly sweetness.  A deep brown pour with an effervescent white head.  A very bubbly, champage like, ale with caramel and chocolate sweetness.  Medium bodied . Complexity develops as the glass warms.

Also one of my usual favourites. This beer is close to his better brother. Roasty, hints of blue cheese, alcohol, soy sauce, smoke, brown, black, hazy, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, salty, full body, creamy, thick feel, lively, soft carbonation, long finish,

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 Dark brown body with an off-white head. Aroma is intense, including chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, honey. Amazing. Velvet palate with the ideal amound of carbonation. Amazing sweet flavour with chocolate and plum, spicy and long aftertaste. A masterpiece. (10/5/10/5/20)
Dark brown body with a big off white head. Amazing strong malty aroma with plum, caramel, spices, orange, licorice, honey. Full, perfectly carbonated palate. Amazing sweet flavour with dark fruits, caramel, some chocolate and lots of honey. A masterpiece really.
think head, rich dark colour. yeastty, floral aroma. good carbination, well balanced flavour not too hot or bitter. long rich palate. lasting flavour of treacle. best trappist ive tasted

330ml bottle from 2010. Pours a dark hazy brown (dont think I gave this enough time to settle after shipping) with a small tannish head that settles in and stays for most of the beer. Smells of yeast and grains, sweet fruit (cant pick them out though - almost a blend). Starts of thin bodied and highly carbonated but develops into a much creamier and full bodied mouthfeel. Yeast and sweetness on the palate, some bitterness and the complexity of the brew becomes evident as you let the aftertaste linger. Only other 8 I remember having was the Christmas brew and this one is definitely better - more complex then expected and looking forward to having another one once it settles down.

Very light compared to 10 but

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2011 Original rating, 2011-02-25: 8-3-9-4-18=4.2
Dark brown, hazy, a bit murky really. A nice off white long-lasting head makes up for the dull first impression. The aromas are raisins and (slightly overripe) apples. The taste is sweet, caramel, and more raisins and apples, and I think I find traces of plum, champagne and hints of port wine as well. Medium to full body. The finish is everlasting! A superb ale in every respect (apart from the murky appearance).
[0.33 cl bottle, Vinmonopolet]
Re-rating, 2011-06-24, 8-4-8-4-16=4
When I started my ratebeer career 4 months ago I thought the Rochefort 8 was the best beer ever. 130 ratings later Im eager to check if this still is pure perfection.
Poured into a Rochefort chalice this is a beautiful beer, with an everlasting tan head, excellent lacing. True, it is a bit murky with large lumps of sediments settling at the bottom of the glass, but still the appearance is upgraded from 3 to 4. I remembered this beer to be far more intense, both in aroma and flavours. Medium sweet taste with a very light bitterness, or is it the alcohol that is biting? Aroma stays at 8, taste is downgraded from 9 to 8. Medium body, lively carbonation. Overall is down from 18 to 16. Ouch. It is still a remarkable beer, but Im no longer sure if this is The Best Beer Ever, the beer that all other beers should be compared to. Does it really give me more than e.g. Nøgne Ø #100? Or Mikeller Beer Geek Breakfast? Or more relevant, Rochefort 10? One thing is for sure, I better re-rate Rochefort 10, maybe that one is as intense as I remembered Rochefort 8 to be...
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet, Oslo City, Oslo]
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2011 Bottle poured into a tulip glass. Very good beer, not as good as the Rochefort 10, but certainly worth trying.

33 cL bottle at home into a Karmeliet glass.  Vibrant head, very dark beer.  Rich aroma, with a hint of roastiness, and a blend of subtle aromas.  Light and sweet, and doesnt taste as boozy as youd expect seeing as its a rocket fuel. A pleasant sipper.  Not quite as much flavour as Gouden Carolus Christmas though.  Good and enjoyeable, but there are a few better beers of its type.

Aged bottle, best before 07/02/2012, bottled 5 years prior, i.e. ca. 4 years old now.
A deep reddish-brown pour with medium bubbly off-white head. A bouquet of fruity aromas of prunes, figs, dates and grapes. Taste is equally fruity, lots of plum, a light sweetness, a touch of dark chocolate, a bit of red wine. Well carbonated, full mouthfeel and very warming. An absolute classic, the perfect beer to sip in front of the fireplace on a cold winters day.

Rehills, Ncl. Cant believe it has taken me this long to get round to this. A truly amazing beer. Rich aroma of fruit and spices, flavours of caramel and brown sugar. Has hints of a big IPA at times. Texture and taste is earthy, late aroma of cough syrup and strong alcohol, but its all so well balanced and moreish. Spectacular stuff.

Pours dark brown with a large long lasting light brown head. Aroma of raisin bread, apples and spices. High carbonation and rather light palate with a dominating alcoholic taste at first, then after a while raisins with caramel comes through. Doesnt quite match the expectations from the aroma and its look. Need to rerate.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2011 Wonderful beer with a strong bark taste. Woodsy caramel apple color and taste. A cereal feel and very carbonated. Nice buzz.

pours murky pale brown-reddish with a thick light beige head, nice lacing. dark fruits, bourbon malts, burnt caramel, dry leaves, earthy belgian yeast taste, hint of spicyness, peppery, warming alcohol. long lasting hoppy finish. lively, micro-bubbly carbonation. medium body. makes me dream of the no.10... just excellent!
A lot like a smaller version of the 10, its nice, just makes me wish Id bought the 10.
11.01.22 bottle from saq. Dark brown small white head. A:  Spicy, light brown sugars, alcool. F: Med body finish is sweet and medium long. O: Tasty and classic

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Spots a very dark beer and good solid head. Cane sugar, mild yeast, dry leaves. Great and foamy in the mouth, developing the medium bitter richness. A flavourful and rich beer that is balanced but still interesting. Much prefer it over the 6. (2,30 EUR, 33cl bottle)
This is a very solid beer, my first Trappist beer. It is big and malty with tons of character coming from the Belgian yeast.

Átláthatatlan sötétbarna/bíbor/lila színben mutatja magát (üledékkel az alján) egy közepes és krémes habbal, amely végül ujjnyi vastagon megmarad.
Illata erőteljesen aszalt gyümölcsös és alkoholos.
Szirupos, nyelvet csípő testességgel indul, kissé fanyar aromája mazsolás, alkoholos, karamellás, csokoládés és citrusos egyveleg, melyet enyhén aláfesti a komló jellegzetes fűszeres íze.
Likőrös, melengető, gyümölcsös és fűszeres befejezése igencsak kiszárítja a torkot, egy hosszan tartó gyümölcsös-fűszeres utóízt hagyván maga után.
F.a.s.z.a.

Pours root beer brown with a nice, bubbly head that sticks around.  Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit and even a little coffee.  Flavor is classic belgian funk, malt, chocolate and ripe fruits.  Very clean, complex finish as well.  And excellent beer.

Bottle, aged about two years.  Pours a deep dark crimson hued brown with a medium to thick sized beige head.  Caramel and some light plum notes on the nose, toast and a healthy amount of malt.  Medium bodied, big carbonation, but then everything thins out a bit.  Toast and some dark fruit notes moving into a warm boozy finish with more toast, malt, and caramel, and touches of yeast.

Pours a deep, hazy brown and ruby with a think, foamy off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with hints of caramel, raisins, and dark fruits. Flavor is sweet and fizzy with roasted malt, toast, yeast, caramel, chocolate, raisins, plums, and dark fruits, with light alcohol notes. Thin bodied with generous carbonation. Delightfully tasty brew.

Thick head, dark opaque.  Smells of alcohol and carmelized raisins.  Sparkling and dry.  Very nice mouth feel.  Alcohol flavor is obtrusive and obscures other flavors.  Finishes with dates and alcohol.  Very much preferred the 6.
looking at all these high ratings im thinking we had a bad one. it smelt funny and it had this funky skunked taste.

Pours a beautiful deep reddish dark brown with a huge lasting beige head. Aroma is full butterscotch and molassas with some prune and alcohol. Flavor isnt too sweet, but an amazing roasty brown and candi sugar with a little carbonic twinge and definite alcohol presence. Body is rich and held together by a really tight carbonation. It was everything I expected.

Got a lot of raisin or fig on the smell. For the high ABV, extremely drinkable. There is also a light banana smell to this. I think the Red Chair is strong on banana, this gives you a light quantity of banana, but its there.  There is really a marvelous sweet, almost banana bread, with raisins, flavor to this beer.  So, good on the nice bready-sweet malts.  For a beer that is high on malts, I find this most drinkable-- because Im-- as yet-- more of a hop than malt person.  I feel like there is a slight bubblegum flavor to this, too.  And Ive noticed ratebeer picks this out.  You dont get a lot of head on this beer, but there is some, and theres also some lace retention.  I dont blame the beer for this, but rather its make.

Bottle 33 cl.
Color: red/brown with a full beige head.
Aroma: sugared strawberries, touch of chocolate, sweet!, caramel.
Taste: red fruit, sweet, slightly sour, touch of alcohol.
Aftertaste: slightly bitter and sweet.
Texture: full, sticky.
For me this is a little to sweet.
Very thick beer. It has the taste of trees or forest, Very bazaar beer. I am unsure if the bottle we tasted was old but it was not a very outstanding beer
looking at all these high ratings im thinking we had a bad one. it smelt funny and it had this funky skunked taste.

0.33l bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown - almost blackish body with a big everlasting off-white and creamy head. Lots of beautiful sweet dried fruits and a really lovely nose! Lively carbonated and medium to full-bodied. Ohheoo this was good shit. Sweet, cocoa, fruity from plums, raisins, brown sugar and a really nice alcohol taste in the mouth. This really impressed me, and I cant wait to try the 10.
We must have had a bad bottle. It could have been really old. I would like to try again.

Bottle @ Home. Pours dark brown with a creamy offwhite head. Aroma of raisins and other dark dried fruit, caramel and chocolate notes, also some undefined sourness, abit like sour cream or butter. Fruity notes dominate tho, very pleasent. Taste is roasted malts, yeast, sweet brown bread, chocolate and dried dark fruit. Medium body, soft carbonation, silky mouthfeel. Very nice. 160111

Poured into a snifter.

4.5 A: Murky medium brown color, like apple cider or something. Two fingers of light brown head with excellent retention and lots of lacing.

3.0 S: Aroma really isnt that impressive. Its pleasant, but not strong enough. A bit of dark fruity esters. Not really any spiciness. Pretty boring.

3.0 T: Caramel malt, some dark fruit. The yeast characteristics are really subdued. Im not getting any spiciness. A little boozy, which mellows toward the end. This is a very one dimensional brew. This really doesnt do it for me like the 10 does.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Carbonation could be a bit more spritzy. Really creamy.

3.5 D: Why this beer is in the top 100 is beyond me. I liked it, but it cost way too much for how mediocre this is.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-10-2009 04:05:19

Bottle: Dark brown pour with full cream-white head. Very full tasting and richly colored. Nutty aroma, with maybe some hints of raisin or fig. Havent tried the 10 yet, but the 8 already ranks among my all time favorites.
Bottled.  Poured dark brown with full tan head.  Aromas of fruit, yeast, and caramel.  Taste is smooth.  Spicy with dark fruits.  Plenty of carbonation.  Medium body, not too thick.

Dark brown pour with a big fizzy off white head.  Faded super quick, left a thin collar throughout though.  Aroma was full of rich fruits, raisins, a hint of chocolate and a light roast character.  Light sweetness too, no heat.  Flavors were dominated by fruity yeast characteristics, some wood, rich malts and light bubblegum.  Wow these are great beers.  Leaves a light sweetness on the palate after each sip, malty and wonderful.  Lots of carbonation here, fizzy mouthfeel.  I would love to go back and taste 6, 8 and 10 side by side to really compare em.  They are all fantastic.
Cloudy brown pour from bottle.  Nice, creamy off white head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee and dark fruits.  Taste is dark chocolate, raisins, plums and some spices.  Slightly sweet finish.  Excellent!

Side by side with the 10, an absolutely beautiful looking beer. Gorgeous dark tan head, the beer was a gusher, and the head has lasted the entire experience. Sweet aroma, caramel, a bit roasty, somewhat lazy compared to its bigger brother. Its a bit more watery than the 10 and the sweetness is lacking, it seems to even have a bit of roasty bitterness. Still nice, but the 10 is head over heels above.

Tasted from a 12oz bottle. Dark brown color with a an aroma of nuts up front with some fruit also coming through. Maybe some raisins or dried figs. Taste is very smooth with more fruitiness coming through but not overpowering. Medium finish.

I prefer the Rochefort 10, but as well as her major sister I appreciated it very much. Ambered color, a little bit opaque with a medium head, not too much persistent. I found a lot of sedimentation inside. Of course, the aroma is a little bit less strong with respect to 10 but its a very good trappist beer!

From 11oz bottle.  Nearly opaque mahogany, huge, dense off-white foamy head with excellent retention.  Aroma of light pilsner malt, spicy yeast character, and raisins.   Malt-forward taste, dark roast malt, and huge flavor of raisins and plums.  Fruity sweetness on the finish, and very slight bitterness.  A bit of spiciness.  Medium body and high carbonation.  Smooth on tongue, crisp finish.  No alcohol detectable despite high gravity.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Dark brown pour with full tan head. Aromas of raisin and dark fruit. Great flavour with a fantastic alcohol finish. Leaves you wishing you had another bottle.  Simply put, the finest beer I have ever had.
pours prwoun with beige head this beer is awesome i sih i had more smells of honey carbonated but smooth awesome
Pours brown with a beige head.  Aroma is honey and toffee, earthy yeast.  Taste is sweet, honey.  Palate is chewy, creamy, average carbonation, bitter finish.

Bottle sample, poured into trappist glass. Pours a dark brown with a nice thick beige head, nice lacing. Aroma is of dried fruit and spice. Tastes of plum, raisin, caramel, chocolate maybe subtle vanilla. I would say this stands up to the 10 and that some people would enjoy it just as much except it doesnt have the taste and aroma of alcohol that the 10 does.
dark brown beer  with a tan head. Smells very fruity. Great flavour with a nice alcohol finish. Very enjoyable.

Bottle courtesy of BarZigKin. Pours hazy brown with a fluffy creany greyish-tan head and nice lacing. Aroma is sweet, concord grape jelly, figs, prunes...amazing! Its fizzy with a sweet/alcohol/malty taste similar to a dopplebock. VERY GOOD...highly recommend!

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 12oz poured. Color is a very nice dark, almost black. Smells slightly of smoke with a burnt caramel sort of finish. Very little head, but consistent carbonation. Tastes slightly of dark fruits, plums and dates with a burnt almost woody quality to it. A deep whiff leaves the nostrils slightly singed and after a few sips one can feel the warmth of the alcohol in their chest. 
A fantastic, living, breathing beer.

Bottle at a restaurant in Brussels (3,80 euro). Dark brown/almost black in color with a thick tan head that lasts for a long time. Surprisingly fruity/tart nose, almost a bit winy (which doesnt come through in the pallet). Medium body, not too thick or chewy. Very enjoyable overall.
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. Dark muddy brown pour. Frothy white head. Aroma of yeast and fig. Taste is smooth, fig and nut....extremely good.
Nice color, aroma is slightly yeasty.  Really good balance of yeast and malt with a bit of an alcohol finish.  Overall a very good beverage.
Bottle from Angelos shop in Lankroun. My first trappist bier. Very untypical for me, used to Czech pilseners. But I got speechless. Soooo great!!!

Pours deep ruddy with a quickly diminishing head.    The smell is rather mild but gives off aromas of sweet malts and sweet candied sugars.  There are some raisins and chocolate in the nose as well.  The sweet dark fruits are mst prominate.  Raisins, dates, and figs are the easiest to note.  Slightly spicey followed by candied sugars.  The finish is a little short.

Bread and yeasty aroma, light brown, cloudy beer that pours with a good head.  Highly carbonated, taste is slightly sour.  Maybe the bottle I had was off somehow, but I dont agree with the extremely high ratings.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 Bottle @ home.  Pours a hazy dark red/brown body with a tan head.  Rich dark candy sugar, caramel, sweet malty aroma with notes of plums, cherries, and raisins. Big fruity flavor that ladened with cherry, fig, raisin, and plum notes along with a caramelized, toffee/candy sugar taste. Finishes pretty balanced for being such a rich beer. Bubbly/effervescent mouth feel. Not a note of the 9% abv. World class.
Pours a dark carmel color. Basically no head. A little too light on the palate. Clean finish. Very much a Belgian Abbey Ale.

Wow.  This is one of those experiences you have as a beer drinker that makes you stop and think, "Wow.  I didnt know it could be this good."  Pours a fairly dark brown with lots of bubbly, tan head.  A fair amount of sediment is readily apparent.  The nose is fantastic.  If I didnt know better, after the first whiff Id think I was about to drink falls fresh apple cider.  Apple cider is also the first thing that comes to mind upon drinking.  There is also some sweetness from dark fruit flavors that sort of counters the spice and vinegar of the apple cider flavors, and just a bit of very subtle belgian yeast, too.  Theres not even a hint of the ABV, on the other hand.  The mouthfeel is great, as theres plenty of carbonation, something that is often lacking with many a Belgian Strong Ales.  I really cant wait to try the 10 after this.  One of the best beers Ive ever had.

Pours a hazy dark brown with a nice head, but the head disperses quickly for a Belgian beer.  The aroma of this beer isnt especially strong.  Raisin, bread and malt.  This beer is a medium sweet with a bitter finish and has a bit of a yeasty taste.  Cant taste the alcohol as much as the 10, but it is still there a bit.  The bottle I am drinking is very carbonated and the beer blows up a bit when it hits the mouth.  Im not sure if the bottle I got just wasnt terrific, but Im not overly impressed with this beer.

Bottle 330ml at home. 
Pours dark brown with a thin tan head. Smells of ripe fruits, caramel maybe a bit of coffee. A bit of alcohol in the taste first, but then fruits, caramel, malts. Palate is just heavenly creamy smooth.

@ kerstbierfestival
rochefort 8 cuvée 2010 
head: beige, bubbly 
colour: dark brown 
smell: malts, soy sauce, sourness, spices, anis, ( a bit ) , dutch drop ( a bit ), bitter 
taste: hopy/malty start, licqour+licquorice, hebrs, anis, sweet dry end , aftertaste is earthy

33cl bottle from Sourced @St Pancras Station. Pours a cloudy deep brown colour, with a thin short-lasting tan head. Nose; smokey, barley, dates, figs and currants. Taste; caramel sweetness, liquoirce/fennel, medicinal, rosemary & tyme, rich and complex like a christmas pudding! Very enjoyable, but I prefer the 10.

its so pretty and it smells so good, caramel-y, yeasty, and a little fruity, with a smoky resin-y finish... but the taste is a little bit of a let down. Im not sure if thats because its not quite warm enough... yeah, apparently thats it. never mind. a little overly carbonated, but lovely mouthfeel otherwise. 

would definitely go on a second date with this one.

06/12/2010 - 33cl bottle @ home
Dark brown cloudy beer, beige creamy head that dissipates rather fast. Aroma of overripe fruits, dried fruits, coffee. MF: nice carbon, full body. Taste: fruity, malty, chocolate, caramel, dried fruits, spices. Aftertaste: caramel, chocolate, spices. This is some seriously good beer.
Note: so I finally got around to taking some notes for the trappists. Ive been drinking them for years and usually when I did not felt like sampling something new and taking notes. Tasted them with 2 friends for a trappist review article in the student society magazine.
this shit was pretty, pretty, pretty good. $6 dolla a bottle? probably not worth the price.

Appearance: murky brown with the hue of deep cut woods; old houses. Minute head of an off-white tinge which lingers as a disorderly puddle as a collar tries to herd it in. swirls with no lace, puffier collar.

Nose: whole grains, cracked wheat, bran, rye seeds; amazingly bready in a crunchy versus chewy way. Raw brown sugar. Marzipan. Fruitcake, dates, candied sugars. Dried grapes and apricots. Cardamom and paprika; spice more in the back as a whisper then as an active trait. Gentle sweetness up front fades into the crunchy breads.

Palate: wow. How I love Trappist soft frothy mouthfeel for a full breadiness without the harsh abrasiveness of raw carbonation. Stab of sweetness sin the back of each swallow; fruitcake, candied sugars, dried dates. Spices weave in and out, blossoming best in the finish with cinnamon, paprika, and cardamom. Practically floats across tastebuds she is so gentle. Lovely addition of dried apricots and grapes. Dab of bark and dry fall leaves for a whispery presence of earth. Plum and grape skins in the back; tart. Doesnt dry nor does it coat. Cooked brown sugars mingle with marzipan for a glazed sweetness kissed in caramel. ABV is nowhere apparent or intrusive. As warms apples make a showing, more juice then flesh or skin. Beautiful.

Final Thoughts: Belgium and her beers were my first beery love and will always be my first beery love. Moments like this only serve to reaffirm how, why, and forever.
En riktigt trevlig trappist-öl. Stor alkoholmängd vilket känns i de första klunkarna då den är aningen spritig. Men sedan kommer de fantastiska smakerna av örter och citrus.

Heavy carbonation with a bubbly head. Fruity smell some caramel but the taste was lacking, nothing really stood out for what I was expecting, I dont think this one was old but it leaves me very disappointed. Ill try the 10 when a fresh batch comes in but this seems way overrated.

Very dark brown, lasting small head. Aroma of figs, dried plums, dark chocolate, malt, yeast. Very fruity, smoky. Smooth, buttery mouthfeel. The taste is complex and sweet, with liquorice, plums, citrus, bread, salt and a very pleasant malty and alcohol-warm finish. A great brew.

G: 18-ounce glass snifter. Bottled on date of January 30, 2008. 

A: Pours with a thick and creamy two-finger head with plenty of carbonation atop it. The color is typical of the style, a fairly robust and creamy dark brown. 

S: Strong, sweet smell of raisins, dates, and dark sugars; maybe a hint of molasses. A slightly-acidic smell with little alcohol. A nice spice factor, as well. 

T: Fruit-filled aftertaste, though not much on the front end. The belgian yeast are definitely present here--much different than the usual taste of malts and hops. However, Im a little disappointed with the lack of complexity in this one--hopefully Ill get more out of the 10.

M: The initial sip brings a strong sense of the beers carbonation onto the tip of the tongue. Mild sensation of alcoholic warmth and tingle on the swallow. All in all, very smoothe.

D: Very delicious and easy to drink, but Im not sure if the value of this one is enough to justify the cost of drinking a few of these.

Deep mahogany pour with a thick light tan head. Aroma is breathtaking. Tons of dark fruit, plums, figs, cherries. Very sweet caramel overtones. Hint of roast and just a touch of booze. Absolutely the most intense flavor Ive ever had in a beer. Its indescribable. Tons of roasty malt and loads and loads of dark fruits. Makes me think of a fine raspberry truffle. Mouthfeel is creamy, perfectly carbonated. Amazing beer. Might actually be TOO flavorful. Cant wait to try 6 and 10.
Bottle. Pours clear deep amber with hugh off-white head. Aroma is sweet and has notes of dark fruits and caramel. Taste is sweet with dark fruits, caramel, alcohol and some fruity hops.

330ml bottle. Dark plum colour with a rich creamy tan head and some sediment in the pour. Sweet and sour fruit aroma with plums, cherries and raisins prominent along with lots of alcohol notes wafting up from the glass. Strong and intense flavour that really warms the mouth and penetrates down into the throat and gives a full mouthfeel.

Plusieurs bouteilles de 33 cl. Arômes de levure légèrement fruitée, de fruits mûrs et de mélasse. Robe brune aux reflets roux, beaucoup de particules en suspension, effervescence active. Cette bière possède une texture en bouche particulièrement réussie, à la fois ronde et sèche. On retrouve beaucoup de fruits mûrs et de raisins (Special B?), des notes de chocolat et de cassonade. Les esters fruités de la levure se mêlent bien aux notes apportées par le malt. Finale très légèrement amère. Très bon !

Bottle at the house.  Shared with DarkBeerChick :o)  Poured a murky brown body toppped with a fizzy, lasting head that leaves nice lacing and was cola bubbly.  Aromas of caramelized sugars, candied dates, prunes, figs, over-ripe plums, fig preserves.  Complex and inviting.  Flavors mirror the aromas and adds some alcohol, molasses and a slight floral/grassy hop.  Lively, fizzy carbonation that seems coarse at first, but isnt.  Medium to full mouthfeel and a slightly bitter, dry finish.  The complex malt profile is amazing.  The alcohol showing up in the flavor is a slight detraction, however, I think it sort of adds to the overall experience too.  Looking forward to trying the 10 soon.

A huge thick foamy head full of sweet dark fruits and brown sugar aromas with a hint of cocoa. Raisin, plum, a little cherry, and malts on the palate. Effervescent in the mouth, but not as silky smooth as the "10". Among the best I have had!! Top Ten.....easily!!!!

Notes from Tuesday, July 13, 2010

Ar: Figs, burnt sugar, wood, light vanilla
Ap: Served in wide wine glass at 55 (best option I had at the time!).  Pours an extremely cloudy, murky mahogany with a 3/4" cinnamon head.
F: Flavor follows suit.  Lots of dried fig, burnt sugar, wood, and a decent bit of vanilla.  Very mild hop bitterness accompanies a nice alcohol burn on the finish. Some sweet spice (clove, allspice) notes as well.
P: Nice thick creamy body with assertive carbonation.  Perfect for this beer.

O: Great Belgian strong.  A bit pricey here in the states ($4.99), but well worth trying.

Bottle, 33 cl. Dark brown beer with a red shine, medium beige unstable head. Aroma of malts, caramel, dark fruits, light sweet. Taste starts with a sort of roasted malts and dark fruits, with a light sweet background and quickly evolves with a hoppy taste coming to the foreground, giving the beer a light bitter touch also. Caramel and chocolate taste flow in between the other tastes, as well as a light, nice alcohol touch. Much carbonation in the beer also. Fantastic beer to drink, however not the best.
Clean full strong ale.  Opens with malt and caramel, mouthfeel quickly moves to carbonation loaded with alcohol.  Solid entry, but not the best.

Pours deep amber with thick creamy tan head and foamy lacing.  Notes of vanilla, malt, and caramel.  Well balanced taste; malty goodness is offset a bit by the hops so that it is not too sweet.  Very smooth and creamy.

Cloudy, deep brown and active pour with a 2 finger off white or light brown head.  Very nice retention.  Smells definitely of dark fruits.  Maybe some grape juice in there with the expected banana scents.  Very interesting and complex taste.  Dark fruits and maltiness start it off.  Cherries, grapes, and plums could be the culprit.  A warming feeling from the alcohol closes it out.  Very full bodied and aggressively carbonated.  Feels great on the palate.

Trappistes Rochefort 8 är en mörk öl med stort vitt skum. Doften är präglad av farinsocker, malt och kola. Doftmässig är den ganska söt och jag börjar direkt att tänka på en typ dobbelbock, mer än en trappist.

Smaken tycker jag nog är så där. Som doften varnade om var den mycket söt och lite för enkel för min smak. Faktisk har jag inte mer att säga om denna. Är det någon som vill fylla ut resten? Jag hittade faktisk inte så mycket mer än mörk och söt.

Dark murky redish brown color. Off-white head. Aroma is malty and fruity, grass, peer, molasses. Taste is sweet like that of cane sugar with flavours of dry grass and herbs. A bit boozy feeling and quite dry aswell. I used to love it, but now a couple years later I am quite disappoined.

Fairly young sample (3 months old). Pours brown with a good off white head. Aroma is fruity with ripe bananas and plum, sweet raisin bread and a slight amount of sourness peaking through the rich aromas. Tastes a bit less complex then its bigger brother, but still a very pleasing beer that will keep you warm on the colder days ahead.

Bottle. Dark brown/red with a large off-white head. Aroma: grass, toffee, caramel, spices, some yeast, and something I cant place. Taste: sweet, caramel, malt, dried fruit, glögg, spices, syrup/brown sugar, alcohol warmth. Some black particles towards the end of the bottle. Quite a full mouthfeel.
UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 Smells great - fruity and sweet.  Very good appearance.  Tastes sweet, yet not overwhelmingly so.  Great beer.

Bottle: Pours murky dark brown, with some sediment (when put up to a light), and an off white head with nice retention. Im drinking the Rochefort brews in order - 6, 8, 10. The Color here is the first obvious difference from 6, to 8, as well as the retention on the head, whereas it seems to sit a bit longer. Aroma seems quite similar - dark fruits are abundant, with a bit of sweet bread and perhaps some booziness. And Booziness is something you do notice with this brew, perhaps more so than I would like, this brew is certainly also heavier on the malts, and also has a bitterness, again caused by the alcohol, i suppose. Well, its a great brew to be sure.

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Murky reddish brown colour. Fingerthick offwhite head, reducing to a stable ring. Complex aroma with a strong malty base and layers of ripe fruit (plum, fig, raisin). Medium-to-full-bodied, lively carbonation. Exquisite balance. Tremendous malty/fruity aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2015 Small bottle. So this is the little brother of Rochefort 10. It is a bit more smoother and more drinkable with more toffee taste coming through. On the other hand, I feel that its lighter body cant support the high alcohol content as well as the bigger brothers intense character does. Re-rate: Bottle from the cellar, 19 months old. Colour is clear amber - much lighter than I remember it to be, almost as light as a fresh "Rochefort 6". Compared to a fresh bottle the aroma has faded quite a lot. Taste seems to have mellowed out quite a bit: the fresh vanilla-like aspects have faded but so has the alcohol intensity. Its just subtle and incredibly smooth in every aspect now. The fresher bottles can have a bit too high carbonation but on the other hand I really like the intense vanilla/dark berry aroma of a fresh bottle. I guess the ideal sample would have to be somewhere in the middle, say 6 to 12 months old.

Pours very dark brown with a slight tan frothy head. Malty aroma, some yeast and  very far floral also. The aroma develops some sweet dry fruits notes after a few sips. The alcohol level make his presence at the first touch with the tongue. Medium sweetness, remisence of raisins and other dry fruits and some light bitterness. Medium/full body, soft carbonation, creamy. Long finish with some bitterness, very little sourness and persistence of alcohol. A good trappist.
Good balance of hop bitter and malt sweetness. Taste is chocolate and spicy with a slight bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 Im trying to think of a nicer description than the color of diarrhea, so Ill just say murky brown with lots of particulate matter and a thick and foamy tan head.  Sweet and fresh apple cider aroma.  Tastes of baked apples (cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves), light vinegar bitterness, and some alcohol warmth.  Juicy mouthfeel and a wet finish with slightly sweet lingering vinegar.  I liked this a lot better the second time around (I think pouring in more of the sediment helped).  I still dont think its as good as the 10 but this is definitely a formidable belgian.

Dark brown with a BIG tanish beige head. Smells like dark fruits. Heavily carbonated with a medium body. Lots of interesting favors, like spices, plums, toffee, with a sweet warming alcohol finish. Good stuff, but Ill take the 10 please.

33cl bottle at the grote witte arend in antwerp.
Probably my favourite trappist beer

Bottle:
Small white to off white foamy head, turn into a small lacing.
Dark brown to dark amber woodish brown color.
Smell malts, spices, sweets fruit and a tiny hint of water.
Taste is fresh and fruity: sugars, dark fruits, bit watery but not in a negative way, like the softer version of the Rochefort 10.
Taste no alcohol, well balanced.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Best date of 220414. Pours a murky brown mahagony color with a very fluffy white head that quickly settles to form a nice coaster. Solid aroma of caramel, toffee, and slight touch of alcohol. Some spice notes as well. Well carbonated leads to a medium/light mouthfeel. Raisins, caramel, and tofee dominate the taste as well as a warming alcohol taste at the end. Some nuttiness as well with some bitterness lingering. Carbonation level slightly takes away from the overall enjoyment of this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2014 In bottle; great, great beer. Aroma of dark fruit and brown sugar. Taste was very good (Not sure why I hadnt tried this before). Plum, chocolate and brown sugar notes .... cant wait to buy some now that I am home. Highly recommend.

Hungary 2010, bottle. Surprised I havent rated this one before either. Deep dark brown with a one finger tan head. Dark fruit with some slight sour funk greet the nose. Dark fruit, brown sugar, yeasty esters, mostly dark fruit. I underlined great in my notes, mustve liked it a lot that night.

Bottle. Small to average light brown head over a hazy red brown body. Aroma-taste: sweet, chocolate, coriander and other spices, raisins-sultanas,wood. A sweet body, with a slightly bitter chocolately finish. Light to mediu bodied. Nice.
Great dark Trappist. Complex spicy and dark fruity nose. Flavour is so rich with dates and figs in alcohol and spicy notes. Texture is also rich and long dark finish.

Apparently this is the lower gravity cousin to the rochefort 10, which I have already had so I am kinda excited to try it.  This beer pours a dark brown color.  I has a lighter brown small head that stays for a good amount of time.  Smell is quite taste.  I smell molasses, plums, grapes, brown sugar and dates.  Taste is fairly complex.  I taste a good amount of plums and molasses.  There are some grapes and brown sugar mixed in there as well.  I traditionally am not a huge fan of this type of beer but this one is quite incredible.

Dark cider/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, some caramel, and spice; Some alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced and complex; Overall, an excellent trappist.

From a bottle. Dark brown with lots of head. Aroma is caramel, yeast and some berries. Flavor is heavy in blackberries, cherries, malt and brown sugar. Medium bodied with a smooth finish and slightly tangy/sweet aftertaste. Very good!

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2011 Bottle @ Bir&Fud Beershop.  OMG! My personal best experience since today! Deep and dull brown aspect, not so dark. Intense aroma of caramel, cherry, with some brown sugar and chocolate. Incredible taste, deep, intense, creamy, great end. Another one, please!
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 Had a Bistro Campagne. Very nice complex beer. A little more drinkable than the 10 but not quite as rich. Lovely. Serving: Bottle

Picked up a bottle from Mesa Liquor in San Diego, California, and poured it into a snifter.  It pours a cloudy dark brown with a medium-sized, beige head that slowly disappears.  Aroma is very fruity with hints of alcohol.  Flavors are lovely and complex: raisins and other dried fruits, combined with molasses, yeast, malts...  Theres a very interesting, tingly anise flavor in the finish thats accompanied by an oily, mouth-coating sensation that leads to a nice aftertaste.  This is a great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2013 330 ml bottle @ home. Rated @ 19.4.2010.
Pours a brown colour with a small white head. Very fruity on the nose with spices too. Complex flavour of fruits, alcohol and Belgian yeast. Dry and warming finish. Very good.
330 ml bottle, re-rate for a very long time. Fresh bottle.
Pours a deep mahogany colour with a large beautiful frothy white head. Aroma of very intriguing; pear, almonds, caramel and floral spiciness. Flavour of smooth caramel, mild bready maltiness, almonds, pear, pineapple and complex yeastiness. Rich mouthfeel and soft carbonation. So very complex and so very drinkable. Excellent stuff. Same points as before.

33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Pours big, off-white head. Dark brown/red colour. Aroma is spices, flowers, belgian yeast and alcohol. Taste is sweet and quite bitter. Complex with hints of burnt sugar (roasted or caramel malts) and alcohol. Mouthfeel is dry with medium body. Very nice and interesting overall. A great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2011 Le liquide a une couleur brune.  La mousse prend dabord la forme dune belle tête pour ensuite se transformer rapidement en anneau.  Le nez est attrayant avec un malt au profil chocolaté et de toffee, dépices, dalcool très parfumé, de poivre et desters fruités.  Au goût, dans la continuité totale des arômes : le malt est fortement présent, lalcool est piquant avec son caractère très poivré et les fruits se définissent davantage : des saveurs de raisin et de figue explosent sur la langue.  Aussi, présence de sucre brun qui donne, mélangé avec lalcool, des petites pointes de vieux rhum.  En bouche, le liquide est de densité moyenne et sa texture est crémeuse.  La finale est tout aussi complexe sur des notes maltées, fruitées et épicées avec un alcool qui réchauffe délicatement le palais.  En résumé, quoi dire de plus? (Dakujem rodenbach99)
Great pour, nice head. Creamy beer with sweet tinges of caramel and herbs. This beer was just amazing in general, one of the best bottles that Ive had in a couple of months.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2011 Amazing beer.So drinkable so complex.Cloudy brown colour .Creamy head.Aroma chocolate coffee black forest  fruits.Taste black chocolate, coffee, raisins ,some spices.Sweet finish with some sour.One of the best.

Poured a cloudy brown with an off-white foam head that dissipated rather quickly. Aroma of woody malt with just a twinge of skunkiness. Big mouth feel, dry and cola-like due to the carbonation. No real detectable alcohol.
Pours a medium brown, nose is winter spiced, burnt sugar, overcarbonated,  tastes dry, candy sugar, brown sugar and cider spices.

Poured a hazy brown with a large stable off-white head.  Some sediment.  Complex aroma of pale malts, pears, apples, grapes, and brown sugar.  Taste has a good amount of complexity as well.  It starts off with raisins and fruit flavors, and then transitions into a dark fruit finish with caramel malts and brown sugar.  Very well balanced.  Not as many esters as other Belgians.  Overall very good.

Why havent I tried this before?  A big time gusher when poured.  That light tan head has excellent retention, too.  Complex fruit in both the aroma and flavor.  Plenty of alcohol, rich malt, chocolate, cream, wow, just so much to be tasted.  All of the flavors are subtle and even delicate.  Delicious.  The only drawback was that high ABV.

Served in a Westmalle chalice at 12 degrees Celsius

A: dark red brownish, almost no head, slight to no lace.

S: Brown sugar, spices, dark sweet malts, bread.

T: Sweet, bitter, kind of buttery taste, the alcohol its very present, raisins.

Its a very good beer kind of strong for me the alcohol make me feel like Im drinking a hard liquor, but its a round beer that its going to need a couple of tries before the final verdict.

Bottle. Very nice, clear red/brown colour with an aggressive off-white foam. Aroma is big on floral yeast-characteristics, spices, dark berries and a fairly sturdy alcohol-punch. Taste is also big on spices and some earthy characteristics, coupled with flowers and the darker berries. Low carbonation, medium/big body, medium duration.

Bottle from a Brussels supermarket. It pours a murky, dense, chestnut brown liquid, with much sediment. The head is light brown, beige, even reddish; very high, pleasant, but doesnt last long. The aroma is earthy, with herbs and a roasty smell of malt that gives a sweetness that reminds of ripen peach, and a hint of licorice and chocolate. Its flavour is fantastic: medium sweetness, a little sourness, spices, ripen fruit; a mix of senses! The palate is carbonated, sweet and, suprisignly, a little watery, despite being a creamy dense ale. It finishes with a soft elegant bitterness, with a hint of black tea. All in all, this is one heck of a beer! One of the greatest from Belgium! Dont hesitate and give it a try!

Pours brown, really murky. Tan head. Aroma is cloves, dark chocolate, fruits (apricots? that seems out of nowehre...), other spices, malt, leather. Taste is... well, spicy, earthy. Somewhat boozy, which might just be the worst deterrent on this one. Really sweet. Lived up to its status.
Bottle, drank in a Rochefort calice, Brown beer, beige head, strong aroma of chocolate, spices. Powerful taste of caramel, spices, chocolate, some alcool. a classic of a beer.

Bottle. Pours a murky dark brown with a deep, deep red. Rose is dark fruit, raisins, currant and spice. Very foamy, but that dissipates quickly. Robust and complicated brew with caramel and nut in the mouth. Sweet and boozy finish. A little on the watery side in the mouthfeel for me.. but a very good drink.

bottle just finished about half hour ago, poured into trappist glass very murky brown lots of sediment was expecting a bigger head, smell is of fruits very peach like, taste is sweet then sour at the finish with a nice alcohol warmth. very nice for this cold saturday afternoon.

Pours a foggy dark brown with mountains of foam.  Aromas of sweet malts, raisins, honey, citrus.  A sourness kicks in midway and is joined by a soft bitterness for the finish, which is long, but not exceptionally so.  Big alcohol makes the flavours dance across the tongue.  Very bubbly.
Had at my place. Bottle. Pour is a dark amber with medium head. Aroma is full of alcohol. Flavor osmotic too exiing with hints of malts and sweets tarts. So so
33cl Bottle: Sweet licorice aroma, strong dark hazy appearance, bitter and slightly sweet taste with a creamy, thick, full body.

Pours a murky chestnut brown with a big bubbly beige head that recedes to a thick rocky cap with bubbles feeding from underneath.

The aroma is sweet with candi sugar, Belgian yeast and plenty of dark fruits, raisins and figs especially.  Thick sugary malts and spices are also present.

The taste is a step above the aroma with an array of flavors hitting me all at once.  There is an initial sweet fruit and yeasty sweetness which gives way to the chewy malts and candi sugar forming the backbone.  The finish is sweet and rich with a boozy presence and a lightly dry finish.

The mouthfeel is lively with lots of carbonation which aids in keeping the body from getting to heavy.

Creamy and dessert-like, this is an after-dinner sipper to say the least.  Complex and damn tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with an off-white head.  Nose has some dried fruit, yeast, dark malts, slight alcohol.  Medium body, taste is more of the same with some chocolate in the background too.  Great beer.

Pours brown into the glass with a big beige head.  Aroma is raisin and other dark fruit with a bit of sweet malt.  Flavor is similar to the aroma.  Lots of dark fruit.  Really not as impressive as Ive heard, but a great beer none the less.

Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle into a Chimay goblet.

Appearance: Pours a hazy dark brown with a very faint ruby tint. Has a 2 finger foamy tan head which dissipates fairly quickly. Lots of sediment floating around. Minimal lacing.

Smell: Dried fruits and light roasted malt are the dominant aromas with light hints of alcohol and phenols.

Taste: Delicious. Dried fruit, bread and light caramel up front followed quickly by a nutty flavor and a fairly strong alcohol bite in the middle then ending with a mix of sweetness, a hint of spice and very mild phenols at the finish. Very mildly sweet aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a high amount of carbonation and a distinct alcohol bite.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. This is one to savor and enjoy.

Overall: Top notch beer. They dont get a whole lot better than this. Buy it when you see it. It wont disappoint.

Its difficult to rate this one, because is just one of my favourites. How can we make a science out of this? At last, everybody has his preferences. I like this one because is strong enough, with a lovely taste, the kind of taste that makes me like a beer. When I like a beer the most, more difficult is to find words to describe it!
Pours brown with persistent head, caramel nose, sweet, medium body, a truly excellent beer.

Pours a deep brown amber with a large but quickly diminishing head.  Little lacing is left once this disappears.  Aroma is of malt and spices with a biscuity or bready note.  The nose seems closer to the Six than to the Ten, though this is may be due to the softer alcohol presence.  There is a bouquet of raisins, grapes, dates and apples, which is given some heft by the candied sugar.  Mouth feel is medium thick and honey like with a fine carbonation.  Taste is of the nose: sweet, perfectly balanced and just a hint of alcohol heat.  Finish is long and complex with the fruit developing into old, earthen hops.  I prefer the Ten, as its alcohol is so warming and body is so thick, but this is more welcoming for the casual drinker.  A truly classy beer.

Poured murky, dark-brown color and a tan, lacing head. Raisins, plum, roasted malts, molasses, vanilla and alcohol that were the most obvious in the aroma.  Medium dense with fairly high carbonation. Dry, sweet and sour aftertaste. Didnt exactly hit the spot, but its certainly an excellent, complex beer.

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep, opaque brown with a thick, lingering beige head.  Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits, Belgian spicy yeast, and some other stuff.  All these flavors combine and finish with a lingering ginger/chocolate note.  Full bodied and nice smooth texture.  Incredible.

Tasted 7/25/10. 330ml bottle. Unactivated pour still has a heavily sedimented and murky brown hue. Layer of bone white head. Aromas of fudge and dark berry esters. Full bodied with a nicely roasted malt bill. Tart and tangy fruity flavors. Little bit of both fresh and dried fruit. Flavors of cocoa dust and that good Belgian yeast character. Subtle perfume and floral flavors. Caramel and citrus. Great sweet and bitter dichotomy. The mild sediment at the bottom of the glass adds a really good graham cracker flavor with just a kiss of pepper. Wonderful brew!

330ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with a very small head.  Aroma is is dark berries, malt and rasins.  Taste is sweet to start, with lots of dark fruits.  Some alcohol and yeast, as well.  Lots of carbonation, with a low bitter finish.
Bottle. Dirty dull dark red in colour. Raisins on the nose.  Something else unplacable, possibly herbal. Sweetish taste, chewy palate. Raisiny finish with little bitterness. Yum!

Pours a cloudy, light-brown color with a foamy tan head. Aroma of raisins and aged oak. Tastes tart, sweet, and bitter. Bubbly with medium thickness. Noting flavors of raisins or currants, yeast, oak, and a bit of hops.
Dark, dark brown, good head but it quickly fades.  Aroma of berries such as raspberries or cherries.  Taste is like a malty roasted brown ale with those hints of berries coming back in the finish.
6th March 2010. Cloudy dark brown beer. Short lived off white creamy head. Dry palate. Rich dry chocolatey malt. Yeasty spicy undertone. Hint of licorice. Finishes dry and leaves a warming afterglow.

**Disclaimer:  I think this was infected. **  
Color is a very cloudy sap orange with really smooth fluffy head that stays on top of the beer and laces the glass.  Aroma is of sweet caramel malt, nutella, toffee and nutmeg.  Flavor is a sharp fizzy mess.  This tastes like rusty seltzer.  I can tell something good is supposed to be here, but instead I have its retarded, inbred, confused cousin.  Bottle at Frugal McDugal, Nashville.

Polished brown in the glass with a healthy, slowly fading tan head.  Carbonation slows to a glacial ferment.  Dark fruit, candied sugar, fresh cinnamon (bread?) aroma.  After the head subsides, a thin, sweet molasses smell takes over.  Wonderfully smooth drinker with spice, slight sugars, and a whisp of fading alcohol at the end.  The taste is well blended with no particular flavor taking over (perhaps a little too subtle for me).  I prefer this over the 10 but Im not wowed - perhaps the style isnt my cup of tea.

Poured mahogany with a decent frothy light tan head and light lacing ... spicey/earthy aroma with dark fruits .... the best part about rochefort is how smooth and non existant the abv is ... tastes of dark fruits plums raisins figs, light spice as well ... so enjoyable and tasty

Beer nirvana.  Bottle to chalice.  Pours dark brown, opaque with a nice tan head.  Aroma is as complex as it gets, bread, dark pitted fruit, plums, figs, etc. with noticeable alcohol.  Great creamy mouthfeel.  Very complex with a fantastic finish.

11.2 oz bottle.  Brown pour, large off-white head.  Aroma of dark fruit, malt.  Plums, yeasty notes, raisins. Not an overly intense aroma but very nice.  Sweet, good carbonation, slight sour note.  Complex flavor, a full range of flavors with Belgian yeast notes, dark fruits, malt, a light alcohol burn.  Long finish as well.  Very smooth, very good beer.

To start things off it has a good head that holds up really well, you can even tell by the feeling when you drink it. Its almost a smooth drink, almost creamy. Its definitely a drinkable beer. The taste is tough to place. It initially hit me as kind of sour cause it has a tang on the back of your tongue but it seems to finish with a sweet cream type thing. The best I can compare it to is plums or strong raisins.

Bottle. Pours mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma of dark dried fruit, Belgian candi sugar, wood and some earthy sour notes. Flavor is rich and smooth, lots of raisins and figs with some sour yeast, alcohol is well hidden. Fullish body with a mild carbonation and a long smooth finish. Excellent beer, served at cellar temperature but got even better as it warmed to room temperature.

330 ml bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a very nice tan head, long lasting.  Aroma of fruit, chocolate and spices.  Tastes very similar to aroma, very complex.  Does not reveal its alcohol content.  Classic.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark brown red. Thin off-white head. Moderate lacing.

S: Dark fruits, bread and yeast. Not as assertive as I was expecting.

T: Taste follows the same footprint but treads a little heavier. Figs, cherries, thick breads and yeast. Some booze.

M: Heavily sedimented... I just couldnt get the damn yeast to stop fing with my tongue.

O: Suffers from the heavy sediment and a blunted nose/flavor all around... Will have to try again, in case this was a defective bottle... Just didnt feel right... what a downer

Bottle. Poured a unfiltered muddy brown with bits yeast particles floating in it  with a large light brown creamy head that had excellent lacing. The aroma was quite intense of sweet chocolate malts and an earthy yeast with notes of molasses, figs and plums. It tasted smooth and sweet with a slight acidic-alcohol flavor in the beginning and ended slightly sweet with hints of chocolate, dried friut and a mild alcohol aftertaste that lasted quite a while. Mouthfeel was medium to full in body and very creamy yet oily in texture with a surprisingly lively carbonation. Overall I can sum it up in one word, YUM!!!!

330ml bottle. Pours deep, deep amber with a big pillowy off-white head and a lot of sediment. Big sweet malt and spice on the nose with some underlying yeast and caramel. Big sweet entry and a warm alcohol finish that lasts for weeks. Top notch.

330 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with an extremely frothy head that diminishes quickly.  Smells of raisins and other earthy tones.  Has a very full body and thick feel.  A very respectable beer with a complex taste, quite enjoyable.

330 mL bottle from Soho Organic Grocery in Elizabeth City.  Pours a muddy brown with a thin, foamy beige head.  Aroma of fig, plums, and Belgian candi sugar.  The first thing I notice is just how smooth this beer is.  Sometimes Belgian strong ales are too sweet or too strong in alcohol.  The sweetness is well-balanced with the right amount of fruitiness.  This one just gets everything right.

Pours a murky caramel brown with a rocky head which dissipates moderately. Nose is rainwater, raisin, caramel, apple, candy sugar, and alcohol. Maybe some woodyness and mild astringency.  Medium palate carries much of the same flavors with that alcohol backbone. Flavor lingers. Nice beer.

(11.2 oz bottle).  Caveat: this bottle is two years old and the strong maltiness from a fresh bottle is mellowed.  I like an AGED Rochefort 8; freash: not so much.  Also, I poured the entire bottle into my glass, rather than the traditional pour of the yeast into a small glass.  Pours a caramel color with off-white head.  Aroma is pure Rochefort: you know the aroma or you dont  Describing it is a different story.  Caramel, milk chocolate, earthy.  Taste is sweet -malts are still strong after 2 years with sight bitterness.  Full bodied with creamy texture.  Some prickly-ness on the tongue.  Alcohol is noticeable, but not overpowering considering its 9.2% abv.  This is a very rich and smooth beer that ages magnificently. Mon Dieu, the brothers at St. Remy know what they are doing.
Bottle @ Gollem, Amsterdam. Caramel, toffee, alcohol, treacle, some spice, malt. Short-lived off-white head. Dark brown body. Light bitterness, some sweetness. Warming. Sweet long finish.

Buona birra dal colore ambrato con schiuma compatta e persistente.Aromi di agrumi e note di fico che si evolvono lasciandola nel bicchiere.Di corpo medio sapore iniziale di liquirizia e spezie che muta poi a ogni sorso.Finale insieme fresco e piccante con la forza alcolica che esce con buona prepotenza.

The highlight of the night at the A La Mort Subite bar in Brussels,  Belgium.  This sublime brew came in the proper labeled Trappist glass,  It was dark brown with with a thick creamy beige head and long lasting thick lacing.  The nose is a very complex combination of aromas with ripe fruits like figs and raisin, blue cheese, and chocolate.  Full body, thick smooth creamy texture, and a mouthfeel that is as good as it gets. The flavor mirrors the aroma with some sourness added in.  The finish is long and spicy. This is a fantastic beer.

Tasted from 11.2oz bottle from Famous in Lombard.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick but quickly receding off-white head.  Nose of red fruit with some banana and caramel.  Flavor is red fruits with toasted malt, cola, and a slightly salty note.  There is also a hint of nutty oxidation.  The body is medium with fairly light carbonation and a medium cola finish.
bottle @ home, dark with small beige head, medium sweet , caramel and coffee, 9.2% alc is well masked. well balanced and easier than the 10.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2010 Aroma is wood, caramel, bisquits and yeast. Taste is Yeast, caramel, some alcohol, some sugar and some coffee. Almost fizzy and higher drinkability when aged for one year. Being 9,2% the alcohol is well hidden.

330ml bottle, Trappist glass,The  Belgian Bar Rotorua.    I havent seen a beer in a glass that is so inviting and such a work of art as this!  Dark brown hue with amber tints, large flecks of sediment swirl around the bottom, thick creamy beige head with brown streaks fully lasting, thick creamy lacing. Astonishingly wonderful complex aromas - very fruity (vinous, very ripe dark fruit dates raisins) yeasty (squash court sweat, blue cheese, some basement mustiness).   Complex mostly sweet chocolaty flavour, mild sourness - very yummy.  Full body, thick smooth creamy texture, long spicy finish.  Absolutely 1st class in all aspects.
resin, coffee, roasty, nuts, caramel, woody, smoke, licorice, raisin, just a great brew. so well balanced in all aspects.

Bottle.

A - Dark cloudy redish-brown color with a fair amount of yeast. Beautiful, large foamy, meringue like, off-white/very light beige head with great retention
