S - A lot of juicy dark fruit with raisin, plum, fig and date (loaded with them all) with just the slightest hint of them being rum soaked. Some dark malt and plenty of spice. Also a strong phenol/medicinal aroma. Overall the strongest is a juicy plum/raisin smell with a fair amount of phenol.

T - Plenty of dark fruit (as in the nose) with a plumy taste being pretty strong. Nice dark malt base with hints of chocolate and a good amount of licorice coming out. Well spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg, and other spices. Phenol/medicinal flavor is fairly present, not quite as strong as the nose, but definitely there. Also a touch of earthy bitterness.

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy.

D - Very drinkable beer, especially given the ABV and style. Lots of juicy and jamy fruit flavors along with a nice balance of malt and phenol/bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden.

Notes: Best before 14/10/14. Very nice beer that I very much enjoyed. Plenty of fruit and some dark malt have a wonderful taste and are well balanced making a good example for the style. A good amount of phenol/medicinal taste also present, but adds a bit of a kick. Licorice is fairly strong for the style. Overall a very enjoyable and solid beer from a great brewery. Not quite as good as the 10, but very nice in its own right.

Served from bottle into a Chimay goblet.  Poured a nice amber brown with a three-finger white head that slowly subsides to one-finger.  There was nice lacing evident throughout.  The aroma was comprised of roasted nuts and sweet malt.  The flavor was filled with malt, spice, and alcohol.  It was medium on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this is an excellent brew.  If the appearance of lacing and head retention were better this could be way up there in the ratings.  If you havent tried this, you owe it to yourself to.

Bottle at Le Baron in Eindhoven, NL. Pours a medium dark brown hazy color with tan head. Aroma is dark fruits, figs, light caramel, raisins and bread. Flavor is yeasty, bread, sweet, malty, and dark fruits.

Bottle at Brasserie Henry in Budapest. Hazy, deep brown with full, deeply carbonated foamy head. Beautiful but subtle nose of spices, residual sugar. Sip is rosy and sweet toffee. Chocolate, hazelnut. Quite hopped and bitter in the middle. Alc is well hidden but helps this finish bitter and dry. Aftertaste lingers, very pleasant. Sharp, refined. World class indeed.
More drinkable than the 10, just not as awe-inspiring. Perfect balance and just exactly what it should be.

11.2oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a dark, ruddy, chestnut/burgandy with a huge, rocky, off-white head with great retention and lacing. aroma is great with sweet, bready malts, caramel, and dark fruit notes of fig, cherry, and raisin backed by belgian spices and candy sugar with an interesting hint of floral, white wine. flavor is delicious as well, less sweet that the aroma, with toasted malts, chocolate, burnt caramel, and yeast with notes of orchard fruits, figs, and dried cherry finishing with a hint of spice, cedar, and light nutty tones. as it warms the cherry and spice notes really come to the forefront adding a new level of complexity. palate is full bodied but crisp and brightly carbonated with a pleasant dose of warming alcohol. overall, a wonderful belgian strong.

bottle.  pours dark amber with off-white head and little sediment.  Aroma is chocolate, licorice, raisin and smoke.  light sweetness.  full body, no filmy aftertaste and long finish.  Tasty, but missing something after trying the 10.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2010 Bottle 330ml. Appearance: dark reddy brown with tan head. Aroma: malt, candy sugar,fruit, bubblegum. Flavor: malt, hop, yeasty.

Poured into a Rochefort Trappist glass. Murky brown color with a creamy tan head. Very good lacing and retention. Aroma was extremely complex with notes of vanilla, brown sugar, caramel, chocolate, figs, molasses, and more! Flavor had just the right amount of sweetness and alcohol. Very impressive as it warms. Mouthfeel was great - very creamy and soft with a long malty finish. Just outstanding!
Starts with a very sweet flavor and fades into a slightly sour/bitter aftertaste, unfortunately after it warms up in your mouth, the alcohol becomes more prominent in flavor.

Bottle, in a Chimay goblet. Pours nice mahogany brown with some yeasty chunks and a soft smooth light tan head. Nose is mostly bready and earthy with a bit of the green apple note I noticed in the 6. Flavor... complex. Sweet, fruity, all sorts of nice spices, bread, a little bit of alcohol warmth. Pleasant smooth palate, although the carbonation is pretty strong. Theres a lot going on in this beer.

Is it supposed to be completely full of suspended tan-brown yeasties?  Last time I drank something this cloudy I was in the bathroom for most of the next day.  Dear God, please dont let that happen tomorrow.  Were in the middle of State testing and I dont want to have to explain that problem to a proctor.Thick one finger creamy head settles to the thickest lace Ive ever seen.  Huge chunks have settled to the bottom, but the smaller flakes arent dropping at all.   Spicy and creamy in the mouth.  Feel is like velvet.  Im gonna have to try another bottle from another source and see if its as chock full of stuff as this one.

12 oz. Glad I chose this one. Pours is a dark mahogany with a tall beige head. Smells like a fresh wine, a little bit sweet, like a riesling, with some hints of citrus and fresh fruit in the bouquet. Wonderfully sweet flavor of orange citrus and coriander and vanilla,  a little bit of stronger spice like cinnamon also hits the palate. Finishes just a little bit bitter with a very earthy yeastiness Wonderful belgian.

This beer pours a sedimenty, opaque amberish-brown with clearish edges and topped with a creamy, resilient khaki head from the 330ml. bottle bought at BevMo (and yeah, I saved mo, errbud loves a deal). Fo sho! Aroma of earthy spices: coriander, cumin, cardamon, and some nutmeg, day-old bready yeast, brown sugar, figs, plums, and other dark pitted fruits, molasses, and alcohol. An unexpected hoppy taste up front that lasts for just a second, followed by spicy yeast, lots of malts, gingerbread, and plums soaked in pure alcohol overnight. Velvety, carbonated, tangy, boozy. Drinkability: Not my particular style, but complex and fairly exceptional. Pairing: Steamed mussels. Rebuy: Probably not. #441 on 06052010, DG.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 lovely burnt wood colour with a frothy head. dark fruit cake notes of plums and fig and some doughlike notes that have an almost vanilla quality to it. awsome stuff. chocolate and roasted notes on the uptake and dark fruits follow with a malted butterscotch finish that lingers along with a boozy kick. Beautiful beer!

11.2iz bottle poured into official glass.  Deep cherry red-brown color after mixing in the yeasty dregs.  Head fades out into an oily lacing.  Sweet, mellow dark fruit tones without and alcohol harshness to speak of.  Deep candied plum and fig notes.  The taste is sweet and malt centered, with a nice creamy, yeasty, mouthfeel.  Brown sugar, with a lively raisin tartness.  This beer is flat out phenomenal.  One of the best Belgian Brown ales for sure.  Some distant candy orange in the sticky aftertaste.

Pours a deep brown with ruby red highlights. Many sediments that are pale in colour are at the bottom. Carbonation is very lively with tiny bubbles. The tanned head is big and foamy-creamy with great retention and lacing. The smell is of apples and some hop mixed in. Notes of chocolat are way in the back. The mouthfeel is lighter than the Rochefort 10, but still has some hold on the tongue. The flavour is really complex. Starts off with some nuts, then, bitter chocolat, coffee, light fruit and spices. Bitter and dry. Wow ! I must say. Bought 6 more for the cellar.

Bottle from Ølbutikken - That last wink of belgian beer before the grand opening of Mikkeller bar and the beer festival in Copenhagen.. a lot of beer is going to be enjoyed the next couple of days.. and I dont think there will be room for so many belgians. Therefore this masterdont poured in a original Rochefort glass. The pour is dark hazel nut brown with a tanned small head there are there for good. The nose is sweet and malty with a clear chocolate caramel profile. The taste is a legend. The balance between the sweet malty vanilla notes and the biterness and finaly the tough warming alcohol is spot on. The finish is alco-warm witha soapy yeasty attitude. It a bit more tempered and thus a bit more gentle to drink compared to the big brither stamped nr. 10. The palate is medium and creamy. Yummy

11.2oz bottle, best by June 13, 2012.  Served cool room temp into a Duvel tulip.  Pours murky brown with a large head that fills the glass nicely.  The swirled remnants of the bottle drizzled over the top take on the effect of a fudge topping, the foamy head holds very well giving this a very dessert-like appearance.  Aroma is dark chocolate, dark fruits, figs, plums, some cherries, brown sugar, molasses, bread, yeast, noticeable alcohol is the only detractor on the nose, but still a very potent and complex aroma.  Flavor is very malty, chocolaty, dark breads, less fruit than on the nose but there is still some raisins, plums, grapes, very flavorful.  Alcohol is also there in the flavor, especially earlier in the glass.  Mouthfeel is slick, medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes a touch watery.  The Rochefort beers are some of my favorites, very rich and complex, a treat to enjoy.

Bottle pour to trappist glass.  Pours a murky purple brown with a small but long lasting head that produces a shimmering lace.  Aromas of ripe grape, caramel sugars, yeast.  Flavor is very rich and complex with ripe fruits and a yeasty balance.  Perfectly carbonated.  Rochefort just never fails.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2011 75cl bottle Cuvee 2010  Cloudy dark brown color with a red shine and a silky head. The aroma has noticeable amounts of chocolate and overripe fruits with a slight alcohol hint. The flavor has a decent malt profile where you get gentle notes of chocolate. A little bit too carbonated for my personal flavor. The Cuvee (75cl) version is a lot more balanced and softer of flavor then the normal 33cl version. Im interested how these will perform after some aging.
Se rapproche beaucoup de sa grande soeur la Rochefort 10. Légèrement moins gouteuse, mais sapproche tout de même de la perfection !

Dark amber topped by a lasting creamy brown head. Yeast and bread dough dominates the nose, completed by a sweet brioche and chocolate undertone. Full body, aggressive carbonation, a bit of cardboard in the attack would suggest a slight oxydation, but it shifts rapidly towards a cakey, chocolate bomber with great complexity and a super long spicy-sweet finish. Great balance in this beer. Clearly my favorite Rochefort.
33 cl bottle, pours a nice dark colour with a large long lasting head, very sweet with a nice long finish that has a touch of alcohol.

bottle at Bières et Compagnie. served in its proper chalice, this beer pours a murky dark brown with a nice off white head. aroma is loaded with plums, raisins, cherry and spices. taste is dark fruits, sweet malt, caramel, butterscotch and a somewhat minty aftertaste that lingers. the alcohol makes its presence known, but in a pleasent way. nicely carbonated, this beer was a perfect marriage with the mussels i had it with.
Dark coloured beer with a nice head. Very complex aroma. Soft sweet taste, a real degustation beer. A beer to enjoy on a long winters eve. (Bottle 33cl)

11.2 oz. bottle- Pours reddish amber with a thin head and good lacing, aroma is alcohol raisins and even some chocolate. The flavor is mellow and tastes like a not good but great Belgium brew, it has that indescribable sweetness that all beers from the region have, and this is one of the better ones. I would like to buy all the authentic Trappist beers and have probably the best vertical tasting ever, how awesome would that be.

I got this as an extra in a trade with DLucky...and it is definitely an awesome extra...really excited for this one. Aged 11.2 oz bottle poured into my Chimay chalice (both brewed by monks...right?). Best by June (or maybe March) 09. Rochefort has limited availability in PA and is very expensive.

A- This is a beautiful beer. Pours perfectly into my chimay chalice with a 1/2 finger head with perfect retention. Traces of lacing are left all the way down the glass.

S- The nose is very pungent and at first loaded with a nauseating grain alcohol odor with a big barleywine-like maltiness (Im not a fan of most barleywines). It was hard to put up to my nose at first...but upon further inspection the nose is quite complex. Strong phenols are definitely upfront and what I noticed initially. Fermented grapes/raisins, a sweet bready yeast, funk, and a soft spiciness come through almost as equal upon further inspection.

T- Fermented grapes raisins and/or plums upfront with a soft spicy yeast backbone. The gingerbread spiciness comes through a little more for the finish along with a slight alcohol warmth. A slight soft spiciness lingers on the back of the palate.

P-The mouthfeel is perfect. Low carbonation and medium to lightweight body loaded with yeast. Extraordinarily smooth.

O- This is an awesome beer that took me a few sips to warm up to. At first I didnt know what to think about this beer but it very quickly grew on me. It is a nice, well put together Belgian that is complex and very smooth. Im sure the aging process has helped a lot with the mouthfeel and maybe has hindered the nose. After some aging its still a bit boozy and it would be hard to drink more than this bottle. One I will have again (if found at a decent price).

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-25-2008 02:53:46

The less alcoholic counterpart from the Rochefort collection in comparison to the excellent Rochefort 10.  Just as good though, head a dark cream color , noticeable hints of chocolate and alcohol (not as much of a wine texture as the 10).  Aftertaste=what gives this Belgian beaut so much notoriety.
33cl bottle. Pours a dark amber colour. Aroma is malty (bread, candies sugar).  Light licorice taste with an alcoholic touch. Good palate. Still one of my best.

This poured a cloudy brown, with a full two fingers of sticky head. Aroma wasnt particularly strong but had some caramelized malts and a touch of dark fruit like a prune or a currant. The flavor on this one really let the very sweet malts come out. The dark fruit was also present but did not make up the majority of the sweetness. There was even a hint on tangy fruit on the aftertaste, much like an unripe pear. This actually kept it from being overly sweet. Mouth-feel was very pleasant throughout the whole experience. Alcohol, while well hidden came across more on the aftertaste with a light pleasant burn on the exhale. A very delightful  and well balanced belgian.
Lovely smooth aroma of berries. Great appearance with a thin white head. Lovely fruit flavour of berries and fruit gums. Bitter tangy finish

330 ml. bottle.  Pours earthy mud brown color with visible sediment suspended in the body, nice beige head froth, good lacing and sticks around as  thin film for awhile.  Aroma of plum, honey, butterscotch, fig, raisin, cherry.  Taste is really not describable in words, but features a sweetness of dark fruits which slightens into some tartness, with some spices and alcohol characterizing the finish.  Pretty smooth mouth feel though the alcohol is a bit noticeable on the finish.  This is really as good as it gets.

This was my inaugural pour for my new Chimay goblet.  At any rate, this beer pours a beautifully dusky brown with a calm head. Its a nearly idyllic looking in the goblet. The beer looks substantive and earthy, like something that would be drunk at great feasts. The nose is wonderfully Belgian. There is some alcohol presence, which mostly serves the complex smells of fruits and malt. The taste is a highly refined caramel with an array of bitter and sweet fruits. The feel is lush and velvety.

Bottle. Nice trappist beer. Think Im going to age some 10, 8 and 6 bottles. This was a young bottle but still great. Pours a hazy dark brown beer with a good white head. Good aroma with hints of fruits and spices. Taste is sweet with some bitter notes. Great brew!

330 mL bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto, served in a snifter. Pours murky reddish-chocolate brown with a small tan head. Head mosty fades but leaves some lace. Aroma is strongly floral with yeast and notes of caramel, toasted malt, chocolate, raisin and port. Notes of vanilla and pepper also present. Flavour begins with toffee sweet malts but becomes progressively more bitter with notes of chocolate towards the end. The finish is long spice and alcohol. On the palate, medium in body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a beautiful beer. The aroma is complex and inviting. Its complex malt sweetness pairs very nicely with vinous notes and subtle spice in the finish. A true pleasure! 2010-04-09

Bottle.  Shared on the porch with neighbor Barry.  Medium bodies and quite brown.  some sediment.  A lively head.  Muted spices and a strong earthy tone enhance this easy drinking brew.  Light subtle nose. Thin settling head.
Color of brown sugar with light brown head. Aroma of dark sugar. Very high carbonation. Molasses in flavor with some residual sweetness.
Bottle at Stone Bistro. This was delicious. Tasted sweet, spicy and hoppy. Very smooth and satisfying on the palate. Great sweet fruity floral aroma. Lacing on the glass.

33 cl bottle. Color: opaque reddish brown. Impressive tan head. The aroma is amazing:  heavily malty, very spicy, fruity, slightly alcoholic. Taste: fruit, spices and alcohol. Well rounded and very complex. Warming finish. Very good drinkable. I love this beer
Pours a darkish red/brown.  Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol.  Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit.  Also has strong hints of spice.
Beautiful rocky beige head lookis like a piece of the moon.   Rivers of chocolate covered raisins...corriander and spice ,with some divinity thrown in .  Beautiful.

Dark brown-red color with nice tan head. Fresh fruity, sweet aromas combined with malts. Sweet, frutiy-caramel and malty flavor, complex and pleasant with some grassy dryness. Very nice in palate and finish is very enjoyable with good balance of sweetness, hoppyness and malts..

Nice yellowish brown color, looks a bit like cola. Good balance, slightly salty (like salmiak), proper amount of hops and not too sweet. Just what I wanted right now (beginning of the evening, before dinner). I really like the Rochefort trio.

11.2 oz. bottle tried side-by-side with the 6 and 10.  Got it at The Party Source, but Ive seen this all over, which is awesome.  Pours a beautiful murky plum-brown color with some sediment and an amber tint.  Creamy beige head that starts big and settles into a perfect cap on the beer.  Aroma of caramel malts, Belgian yeast, dark fruits (raisins, plums, dates, cherries), bread, metallic notes, candi sugar, and licorice.  Not as sweet or buttery as the 6, but fruitier; like a mellower version of the 10.  The flavor also fits that description, with notes of caramel malts, the same dark fruits as above, Belgian yeast, alcohol, chocolate, and hops.  Medium-bodied, with average carbonation.  Alcoholic aftertaste.  Pretty nice beer, and lower gravity cousin to Rochefort 10 seems like a damn accurate description.

Pours a nut brown with a large light brown head. Sweet aroma of biscuit malt, dried dark fruits, chocolate, toffee and some notes of alcohol. The flavour is sweet with distinct biscuit malts and dark dried fruits. A nice amount of sourness is noticeable from the yeast. Alcohol is warming and there is a hint of bitterness in the finish. A complex and beautiful palate.

Bottle as shown at Freaking Frog in Las Vegas. Pours a dark cloudy brown with large frothy beige head with good sticky lacing along the glass with yeast flakes floating. The aroma is a sweet malt and yeast and candy. Medium mouthfeel with one of the smoothest tasting Belgian I have ever tried. Hides the alcohol very well. Really enjoyed this one, taking very slow sips enjoying this Belgian from Rochefort.

Bottle. Was afraid it was just a bad bottle, but I see other people also havent enjoyed the 8 as much. Pours a very strange cola-like color with barely any head, but lots of fizz. Aromas of malt and dark fruits. Taste of bubblegum, yeast, clove, fruits. Finish is alcohol.

2008 Bottle - Its Saturday morning, I aint got shit to do, so why not?...Pours a dense amber with a large sandy head...aroma is rich dk fruit, pear and plum, candy malt and light spice...flavour is pretty similar, dry fruit, roasted grain, malty but never sweet...havent had one of these in a while, and its a bit duller than I remember...

pour cloudy copper with short lasting head.  Malty, fruity nose, plums, raisins and a hint of alcohol.  Sweet malt, full flavor, fruit similar to nose, hops bitterness provide an appropriate balance to the sweetness.  Palate is very pleasant and smooth.  An overall feeling to this beer that others should aspire to.  The only real shortcoming is the appearance.

330ml bottle 
Appearance: Poured murky dark brown with floating yeast chunks. Large dirty light tan head that dissipates quickly, some lacing in the glass 
Aroma: Sweet malts, dark fruits 
Taste: Sweet malts, spices, hot alcohols. Medicinal/band-aide aftertaste that sticks around. 
I really like the 10, but this not even close. I had the 10 on tap in Belgium so maybe that is the difference. Ill try a bottle of 10 tonight to compare. 
*Edit - I tried the 10 and stick with my comments. The 10 is very smooth and balanced, unlike the 8.

Pours murky brown with a chunky tan head.  The aroma is dried fruit, abbey style yeast, cotton candy, spice, and a touch of booze.  This beer has a full body with lively carbonation.  The flavors are much the same as the aroma and balanced with a slightly bitter finish.  This one certainly remains among my favorites.

Good head, dark color, a great deal of sediment.  Aroma is cheesy, earthy, and slightly malty.  Overall taste is AMAZING!  Taste is bready, a bit of chocolate, nutty, slight molasses, a little spicy, roasty and toast as well.  Aftertaste is toasty, buttery (not diacetyl though), fruity, and slightly phenolic.  An overall sense of alcohol when drinking.  Very fine carbonation.
Inky brown pour same sticky white head as 6 and 10. Very strong yeasty aroma. Flavors not as sublime as 6, of the two I actually like 6 better. Nice long finish.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours a nice, almost-opaque brown body with a long-lingering caramel-hued head. Smell and taste alike is Rochefort classic: figs, dates, raisins, dark malts, yeast  notes, brown sugar. A very smooth blend, with an excellent palate. This is the most downright drinkable of the Rochefort series, smooth without beeing watery like the no. 6 tends towards in my opinion. Not quite up there with big brother no. 10, but a very, very solid brew.

Dark brown reddish, medium tanned head.
Aroma of fruits, faint liquorice.
Flavour is a creamy liquorice and fruit.
Very full, both of flavour and texture. Very nice.
bread, toast, hoppy,brown, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,

I first had this beer during my first visit to Belgium in 1998. Our hosts had a refrigerator stocked for guests-I had one and that was the start of my quest for anything Belgian.  Now I finally rate it.  Nose is chocolate, malts and sweetness-very understated. Taste is sweet, sugar candi, malts that have just been slightly roasted. Smooth body and eminently drinkable. World class.  Not sure of the dating on this. L271212 08:23. What does this mean?
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 1, 2010 Bottle. Pours dark brown with an inch and a half of thick, cappuccino head. Lots of pulpy particles dancing around in the glass. Strong herbal aroma along with oak, cinnamon, burnt sugar and alcohol. The first sip is extremely silky and creamy with lots of complex caramel and toasted malt flavors. There is an earthy yeast character to the Ale with hints of herbs, cola and brown sugar. It has an incredibly smooth, warm alcohol finish and a subtle candied sugar aftertaste. Not nearly as sweet as it sounds nor is the ABV overpowering. I could see becoming a monk if I got to drink this every day.
330 ml bottle.  Pours thick very dark hazy brown with nice tan head.  Dark fruity aroma and taste with raisins and plums.  Full body with minimal after-taste.  One of my favorites.

2008-05-23, bottle, Göteborg
AP: cloudy amber brown, wee white foam
AR: yeast and fruits, skumbanan
F:caramel, dark fruits, yeast
Aroma is yeasty with the distinct smell of alcohol coming through.  Tick, creamy head.  Taste contains plums, currants, and alcohol on the nose.  Smooth beer that finishes strong.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2010 Dark amber with nice creamy head. Aroma slightly vague sweet malt and dark fruit. Taste is sweet, fruity from
figs, raisin, caramel, chocolate bitter, alcohol. Palate is full, carb is fizzy, finish with lasting alcohol impact.

Hint of Chocolate with a slightly fruity twist.  Medium sweetness, light bitterness. Full body with a thin creamy texture Rich clowdy liquid with a dark amber color.  Very suprised by the sediment volume, a lot of yeast suspended as well as settled.  Soft think off white head that dissipated rather quickly. A relaxing beer that feels perfectly balanced. A astringent,

11.2oz bottle that Ive been sitting on for about 2 years. Pours a very murky, sediment filled brown body with an orange tint. The sediment looks fairly even though, unlike the 6s chunks. Finger-width, creamy and frothy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is similar to the 6, but much deeper and fruitier at the same time. Rich, caramels and toffees with a distinct chocolate malt. A wider assortment of darker fruits than the 6 too. Prunes, raisins, dates, black cherry, and plums. Yeast, lightly spiced bread, candi sugar, licorice, and just a hint of alcohol. Flavor is rounder, fuller, and a bit hotter than the 6. Lots of plum-caramels, dates, raisins, and chocolate up front. Some bready fruitcake, a hint of toffee, floral and delicate yeast spices, licorice, and a touch of alcohol heat. Finishes with a nice, underlying chocolate before this slowly and crisply dries with a light to moderate, but subtle hop bitterness. Lengthy aftertaste after a medium, very creamy body and a smooth carbonation. Overall, this is a damn good beer. Lots going on in this flavorful, wonderfully balanced beer. Impressive.

Pours a nice solid dark brown colour, small off-white head with a fair bit of sediment. Strong aroma of caramel malts, a little yeast and dark fruits; raisins, dates and prunes. Taste is sweet up front with the malts and fruits clearly present, the finish is slightly bitter and quite abrupt. Medium to full body, creamy / oily on the palate with average carbonation. Overall a very good beer, enjoyed it more than the 10 as well.
bottle, brown colour with nice lacing white head. Smell: very fruity. Taste: very complex: notes from alchohol, fruity, yeasty, heavy beer. Spicy, mild sweet, caramel. Very nice trappist!
heavy cloying sweetness, dark color, oily feel, long finish, chocolate, white foam, full body, soft carbonation,

Pours dark brown with a thick off-white head.  Lots of floaters in this beer.  Aroma is alcohol with musty malt undertones.  Lots of basement aromas.  Taste is alcohol and malt with a sweet aftertaste and a nice spicy feel in the back of your throat.  Really good stuff.

A: Reddish brown in color with a nice fluffy white head.

S: Figs, dates, cherries and some other unidentifiable dark fruits. Caramel and yeast, with some spice as well.

T: Sweet dark fruits, especially cherry, some mild chocolate flavor in the background. A bit of a cola taste.

M: Dry, creamy on the tongue, nice carbonation.

D: Another fantastic Rochefort beer.

Darker body than expected, good off-white head, decently lasting. Aroma is port, dark fruit, molasses, with a yeasty sting. Strong licorice and raisins in the mouth. Finish is dry, and leaves a slightly tarty aftertaste. Smooth, oily but silky (never heavy) on the palate. Very dark, almost smokey flavours give this beer depth and originality.

Pours murky brown with a small dissipating head. Aroma- complex and fruity, apricot pit, earthy, caramel. Taste- raisims, prunes, cereal, sweet malt, alcohol. Very rich and satisfying mouthfeel and aftertaste.
Delicious beer! Similar to the "10". I taste caramel, chocolate, raisins and nuts.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 Dark brown. Head is good sized, light coloured. Aroma of fruit, apple, red fruit, raisin, bread.Sweet beer, lots of fruit to taste. Red fruit and apples, caramel.
When you buy this one, its a good idea to let it rest for 6-12 months before consuming it. The taste you get then is very rich. Tasted aged bottles allready on multiple occasions, and its not that rich as a 10, but sometimes its less sharpness wins it from the 10.

Pours a medium mahogany with a short lived off white head.  Left little to no lacing on the glass.  Aroma is doughy with some barnyard and dark fruit.  Alcohol is a bit upfront followed by some malty flavors and a fairly dry finish.  Not quite as good as I expected to be honest.  Much prefer St. Bernardus.

Pours very hazy with quite a bit of sediment. Very dark brown with a creamy colored head. Aroma of dough, a little leathery. Flavors were well balanced , but nothing really stood out. Alcohol taste was actually a bit too forward. A great beer, but for a Trappiste it was a bit disappointing.

Pours a slightly hazy dark brown, almost a mahogany, with a fairly thick pale tan head that sticks around for a little bit. Strong, malty aroma has an undertone of spices and some fruity hints. Flavor is mainly malty, subtly spicy and fruity, with just a little bit of an alcohol nip. Texture is very smooth yet a little rough on the edges. Worthy!

Bottle. Pours grayish hazy brown with off-white head. Some loose sediment lumps after several days of settling. Complex aroma has fruits, herbs, peppers, licorice and aftertaste has alcohol and licorice aromas.

tap. aroma di malto tostato e caramello con sfumature di frutta a polpa rossa e matura.al gusto sempre un buon sentore di carammello bilanciato con una delicata tostatura,persistente. forse spunta un pò di alcol. ma comunque buona.
Dark brown color, small beige head; big, dark fruity, cherries in soy sauce-aroma; medium body, smoothly carbonated mouthfeel; soily flavor is dark fruity and malty sweet with some spiciness.

Pours murky brown with an off-white head. The aroma is caramel, sugar and dark fruit. The flavor has quite a bit of grape with some other dark fruits, caramel and candi sugar. The sugar is pretty forward in the taste. Somewhat boozy. Medium mouthfeel and high carbonation. A very good beer, but not as good as Rochefort 10.

Bottle in the Man of Kent pub, Rochester, UK. For a beer thats way too cold and way too frothy his has an extremely big pull. The malts are very strong and the moreishness of this is strong. I dont want to like this, but I really do.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown with garnet highlights and a medium tan head.  Aromas of yeast, roasted malts, caramel and brown sugar, raisins, toffee, alcohol, and some sour/acidic notes.  Taste is initially slightly sour and yeasty, trending toward sweet raisins and figs, with a mild resinous hop finish.  The finish and aftertaste have notes of wood/oakiness.  The alcohol is not overwhelming, but adds a warming quality.  Medium body and somewhat creamy, but for me, pretty highly carbonated.  Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 Had a bottle the other night. Nicely balanced flavors and aroma, but nothing really stood out for me. I prefer Chimay or St. Bernadus.

Had another bottle at Trafalgar Pub in Eindhoven. Much better experience. Flavors of raisin and dates, doughy yeast, cloves. Taste is a little acidic and sweet. Fairly carbonated. Quite good overall.
330 ml bottle a hazy dark brown colored beer with a tiny beige head aroma malts dry fruit sweetness spices and some bitter taste malts fruit some sweetness and a bitter spices ending a good beer

330ml bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Pours a hazy dark brown with a tall foamy tan head. Malty sweet aroma, hints of dried fruit. Nice malty sweet, figs and slight chocolate flavors, noticeable, but not overpowering alcohol. Nice carbonation. Lingering aftertaste.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a medium head. Not much aroma until it airs out a bit, then the aroma comes alive with a fruit malt with a hint of chocolate. The aromas translate into the flavor on the palate. Although the flavors seem to change from one to another. Nice carbonation. Not sweet, not bitter. Nice alcohol tingle on the tongue. Very smooth from start to finish. I highly recommend this one.

Aroma: dark fruits, alcohol, caramel. Dark mahogany appearance. Taste: Very complex, noticeable alcohol, dark fruits, caramel, gingerbread, christmas pudding, warming spices. Very lively carbonation and tingly on the palate. Most full bodied, very rich. Strong, complex beer with a very apparent alcohol flavor.
Murky brown pour at craft atl.  A very nice, smooth, well-balanced Belgian strong.  Very good.

Hazy brown beer with a small lasting beige head. Good lacing. Aroma: dark fruit, alc, fruity yeast, some hops. Taste: chocolate, caramel, raisin, figs. Pretty sweet. Well hidden alc. Very good underlying bitterness that balances the warming alc. Really good beer.

Pours dark brown with ruby tints providing a thick, generous, light off-white head that sticks around a while. Light fruit on the nose, paired with spices and deeper fruits and light alcohol. Dark malt is more prominent in the mouth, with deep fruits and some chocolate, but balanced by lighter sweetness (and maybe some grapes) that follows through to the finish and balances the alcohol. The lingering sweetness is a bit excessive...
genialissime ! tres tres bonne biere , un gout relevé et frais a la fois , bonne pressence, bonne texture, a recommander durgence !!! :)

Very interesting beer.  Thought I would check out all the hype.  I wasnt disappointed.  Frightened at first by the cidery aroma, thought I might have gotten a bad bottle.  I was wrong.  Dark red-brown, mostly clear with bits of sediment making for an interesting appearance.  Wonderful, complex taste.  So many things going on inside:  citrus, dark chocolate, too many to mention.  Comes on strong at first, but finishes smoothly and sweetly.  Lingers on the palate with a wine-like quality.  Impressive!
Bottle 330 ml. Deep brown with a thick, lasting white head.  Sweet aroma with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is smooth. Great beer.

Serving date: 2009-04-02. Served in snifter. Best before: 2013-08-20.

Dark brown with deep red hues. Big and creamy beige head with very good retention. Plenty of lacings.

A very powerful and rich smell. Plenty of fruity aromas (blackcurrants, blackberries, ripe pears). Pleasant aroma of chocolate, caramel and slightly boozy and spicy alcohol.

The taste is very well balanced and complex. Somewhat sweet fruity flavors (blackcurrants, blackberries) up front. Rich chocolate flavors. Plenty of layered malts - caramel, freshly baked bread, brown sugar, coffee. Some spices. The alcohol becomes noticeable already in the mouth and develops even further towards the finish. There are also some grass and grains in the finish.

Full-bodied and very creamy. Plenty of carbonation though, that makes for a rather lively mouthfeel.

This is one great beer. Its really well balanced and carries some fantastic aromas and flavors.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 pours very dark brown with a thick, somewhat creamy off-white head and no lacing.  aroma is alcohol, over-ripe fruit, licorice, and yeast.  body is fairly full with a creamy texture.  taste is tart with a nice alcohol burn.  notes of yeast, a hint of citrus, berries, nuts and even a little chocolate are present.  finish is rich and warming with the chocolate sensation lasting longest.  This is a lovely and complex beer.

Tried from 5 year old bottle at the brewery, wow what a remarkable change from the younger 8, intoxicating aroma, brownish red color, taste was full of so many different flavors and intermixed at once dancing on your tongue, very easy to drink, worth seeking out and aging to get this incredible taste out of the 8.

Bottle.  Light coffee, marron with a thick and creamy light tan head.  Nice and beautiful.  Light caramel, nuts, chocolate, herbs and spice.  Complex stuff.  The initial kick of carbonation is surprising but it balances out pretty nice with some nut, plum, bread and earth.  Nice balanced finish.

Pours a nice reddish amber color with an enormous head that leaves plenty of lace.  The aroma is floral and earthy with notes of cherries, some nuts, and some sweet chocolaty malt. There really isnt as much to say about the aroma of this one as I found to say about the other two, but the beer is damn pungent and everything is so clearly defined and pleasant that this one smells damn near perfect. The flavor is dry, far drier than the aroma lets on, I was expecting a far fruitier and sweeter beer so at first the alcohol presence seemed a bit overwhelming but after a few sips it seems to perfectly balance a lot of other things that are going on in the flavor here. The beer is summed up pretty well in three words fruity, nutty, and earthy. To be more specific on the fruit though there are certainly the sort of expected dry/dark plum and raisin type fruit things going on but there are some rich almost pie cherry like notes in there as well along with some apple. Im not getting any pear which is a bit of a disappointment as the pear notes were one of the coolest things about the Rochefort 6, but I suppose they make three different beers for a reason right? There are of course the rich earthy tones that work well with a cavendish like tobacco flavor and the lighter chocolate tones. Another work of absolute art from Rochefort.

333 mL bottle pours dark mahogany with little to no retaining head into a chalice.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of sweet malt, figs, raisins, dates.  Similar tastes: starts with the fruits, sweet malt and caramel hold throughout, finishes sweet and a little dry with some alcohol present.  Low carbonation with a soft mouthfeel.  Full bodied and mighty fine.
I thought that the 9.2% ABV would pack quite a punch, but it is surprisingly smooth and delicious. The color is dark brown and the flavor has dried fruits and malts. Pretty damn good.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 Chilled but not cold in a pint glass.  The aroma and taste are complex with both spicy and sweet tones.  I get a lot of plums, toffee, and candied fruit right away with rich pepper /spice at the finish.  Strangely, very little yeasty taste and the citrus make it much brighter than expected.  The level of carbonation is about right and the mouth feel and warming are great.  There is a lot of sediment (more than expected) and some mild resin taste but overall its a very nice beer.

EDIT: Had it too cold the first time.  This one really opens up after it warms some.  The aroma grows and the taste becomes even more complex.  So I recommend this one slightly chilled.

Complex Aroma, very fruity. Perhaps plum. Pours with a thick, creamy head. Dark brown colouring with a cloudy apearance. Suprisingly light flavour considering the hue, notes of roasted toffee and pepper. Very warming when swallowed.

Murky chestnut pour with small, centrally congregating cream head.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, and malt.  The taste is yeast and malt with undertones of alcohol and fruit.  Finish is exceptionally sweeter and a bit of alcohol.

Bottle: Deep maroon with a brownish hue and a thick creamy tan head. Toasted rich aroma- toffee notes, dates, fig, plummy and warming. A bit too carbonated- thins out the body. Not as creamy as the 10. A touch peppery at the fore followed by plummy toffee-like richness. The malt depth leads to a toasted dark Belgian malt note and peppery alcohol/spicy phenolics follow. Not bad, just not as cohesive and silky on the palate as anticipated.

Interesting beer.  Has a complex aroma.  Notes of fruit, malt, and caramel hit the nose.  Good sweet and bitter balance, with the carbonation preventing the sweet from overpowering.  The carbonation also gives the beer an interesting finish, which fades nicely.  The only knock for me is the body, the beer is just a bit thin for me.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful, sedimenty brown.  Aroma is complex - hints of fruit, caramel sweetness, and alcohol.  Taste is equally complex, citrusy with a malty background, a slight bite from the alcohol, and a delicious sweetness.  Some hoppy notes as well.  An incredible amount of flavor in this brew.  Each taste brings new notes.  One of the best beers Ive had in a while.
Cloudy, amber brown colour with some particles. Aroma of spices, fruits and alcohol. Flavour of roasted malt and fruits, alcohol masked. Beer well balanced. Really an excellent beer.

330mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy amber-brown with visible suspended particles of sediment and a persistent, frothy off-white head.  The aroma is floral, spicy and fruity, with the alcohol coming through as it warms.  Sweet and fruity flavour with some bitterness from the malt preparation and a balanced, mildly hoppy aftertaste, while the alcohol is reasonably well masked.  Full bodied with initially quite lively carbonation.

12oz bottle from 16th St.Liquor in West Van. Pours a slightly cloudy deep brown. Tan head dissipates to a thin ring. Aroma is complex. An abundance of  smoky malt with fruit notes including bananas. Taste is thick with roasted malt, yeast and layered fruit and malt. Alcohol is evident but subtle and well integrated. Mouthfeel lingers well and warms as it settles in. A very magical beer.

Incredible head on this; pillowy, off white withe lacing.  A deep amber color and strong malt note in the aroma.  Sweet and smooth with a hint of roastiness and a kick of alcohol at the end.  Dangerous.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Cloudy brown. Opens with a pop, enthusiastic tan head fades to a nice veil that laces. Dough, dark sugars, summer berries, citrus , raisins, white pepper. Very noticeable alcohol, but its not raw. Fruit and chocolate with some astringency on top of the sweetness. Remaining carbonation is perfect to bring lightness to the palate. Seems more about balance than complexity for its own sake. Finish is herbal with a touch of brandy. [4.1] Id already given this a 5 for palate, but it certainly is spectacular in that regard. This time the finish seemed gently drying, allowing the various flavours to dance as they linger. [4.2]Drinking this a bit recently. And the last few Ive had have had fine lasting heads. So just up on that score.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2011 hzy-mhgy, thk-tan-dns-fmy-hd, thk-lace, med-co2, full-bod, 

dark-fruit malt sweet §cheese boozy oaky aroma, 

fruity malt T1, §bitter sweet-malt §mnrl T2, warm-alchl §malt T3, 
§funky (bier de garde goodness) and warm throughout, with some green banana hefe-weizen esters in the finish.
one of the easiest drinking dark abbey ales ive had.

Pours murky brown with an abundant rocky head. The aroma consists of candi sugar, raisins, an earthy aspect, and a little spiciness. It slightly sour with a fair amount of carbonation and a nice bitterness.

zeer donkere body met een licht bruine kraag lekker zacht van smaak vol met smaken van mout en graan die mooi samen gebracht zijn in dit bier dat zorgt voor een zachte smaak en afdrong de afdrong is zelfs licht zoete zachte smaak

Bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy deep brown. Very dense tan head. Disappears slowly leaving beautiful lacing. Aromas are a little odd. with heaps of fruit including bananas, stone fruit and plenty of fruity esters. Even perhaps a little lemonade. There is also some roasted malt and some yeast amomas. Flavours are a lot more as expected. heaps of roasted malt, stone fruit and alcohol. Mouthfeel settles as it warms. Great beer.

A truly unique experience!  Medium opaque brown in color, similar to the 6 with a more balanced palette.  Notes of candied pear in nose and dried cherries on palate.  If youre not a fan of this kind of beer, you dont know what youre missing.  Dynamite brew - a one of a kind gem!  Rated while drinking with Fistfull and Bigguns22.

A truly unique experience!  Medium opaque brown in color, similar to the 6 with a more balanced palette.  Notes of candied pear in nose and dried cherries on palate.  If youre not a fan of this kind of beer, you dont know what youre missing.  Dynamite brew - a one of a kind gem!  Rated while drinking with Fistfull and Twindog.

A truly unique experience!  Medium opaque brown in color, similar to the 6 with a more balanced palette.  Notes of candied pear in nose and dried cherries on palate.  If youre not a fan of this kind of beer, you dont know what youre missing.  Dynamite brew - a one of a kind gem!  Rated while drinking with Bigguns22 and Twindog.

Nice dark amber with a very thick, creamy off-white head.  Nice earthly and yeasty aroma.  Slight fruityness to the aroma as well.  Oily and chewy mouthfeel.  Full-bodied to say the least.  Taste is of very dark fruits with a very warming alcohol finish.  This is a nice beer but I like the 10 better.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Pours a hazy brown, lots of sediment and carbonation. Tall foamy tan head. Aroma is caramel and dark fruit and some earthy hops. Flavor is big and rich. A caramel and raisiny sweetness intermingles with a sour and herbal-bitter tartness. Alcohol well hidden. Very good, however it has a rather unpleasant cherry cough syrup aftertaste.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2010 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours dark brown with big beige head and nice lacing.  Nice high carbonation.  In general the taste is complex, dark fruit and effervescent.  In particular it has flavor tones of brown sugar, figs, and a hint of caramel.  Alcohol is not that noticable, but does has a hint of harshness.  A really good dark stong belgian ale.

Bottle. Cloudy brown with big beige head. Abundant carbonation. Slight apple juice and brown sugar aroma. Very sweet (fruity with some brown sugar) and effervescent. Alcohol lingering in the background but well hidden.

Dark brown pour into thick creamy tan head that slowly dissipates into melting foam lacing as carbonated bubbles rise from the bottom of the glass into a swirl of creamy foam. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, yeasty biscuits, and hints of ripened fruit. Complex flavor of creamy sweetness, sweetened ripe fruit, and sweet caramel malt with slight hint of hoppy bitterness in the finish.

Brown colour, small head rippling with tiny bubbles. Aroma is oaky, taste is licorice, so complex, not bitter. Aftertaste develops and remains in the mouth, warming alcohol. A great drink for a cold Winter evening. Delightful.

33cl bottle, as pictured.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a medium beige head. Ok retention, decent lacing.

Aroma of fig, banana and liquor - with a citric edge. 

Fairly active carbonation in a heavy-bodied strong ale. Full, but fizzy mouth feel.

Taste strongly reminiscent of Jamaican rum(!), but its not too sweet. Fig and banana are as evident here as they are in the aroma, and the malty bitterness nicely balances the fruit and alcohol. Lots of interesting herbal spices in the mix, the whole thing reminds me somehow of a Christmas desert. Herbaceous finish and mildly alcoholic after taste.

This is a most agreeable, superbly balanced Belgian strong ale that shows that basic sweetness can be a plus as long there are enough bitterness and spice to compensate. Very likeable.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2010 One exceptional brew. Full in complexity of taste. Extremely full bodied in nature. Poured warm into my old stlye Rochefort glass with yellow writing on. Smells of figg; prunes, dried fruits. raisins and candi sugar.

Texture is pure black tar. Red is settled at the bottem. Tastes of carmael; figs, raisins, prunes candi sugar and well measured roasted malts. Very complex brew. Lovely to sit there and contemplate theory of life with. Not as good as the 10 but very close. Lovely boozy and heart-warming finish which is fruity and not burning, just a stunning winter drink. Smoother and more easier going than the 10 as it carries less alcohol.

11/22/2009:  Trappistes Rochefort 8...  Aroma:  A bit sweeter than the Rochefort 6; dark caramelized fruits and malt sugars; other characteristics like that of deep red wine; maybe a hint of something herbal or even like peppermint.  Appearance:  Dull brown color; murky/cloudy and opaque; frothy beige-colored crown.  Flavor:  "Darker" tasting and more rich than the Rochefort 6; caramel; dark brown sugar; roasted chesnuts; hints of chocolate; notes of creamy sherry or other liqueur; something that I can only desribe as watermelon; a splash of vanilla; more alcohol, but all of the flavors are also heightened as well; oxidation is starting to set in and is detracting a little bit from the overall flavor...  Palate:  Medium to medium-full carbonation; good level of carbonation; slightly sticky on the lips.  Overall:  Definitely obvious that this is the bigger brother to Rochefort 6 since the characteristics are similar, but everything is bigger; this a very good beer priced at $4.99+tax/bottle!
e33 cl bottle ( ALC. 9,2% VOL. / Consume before: 30 06 09 ) from Rivers Bend Wine and Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating #1836 for this beer. Score:  8/3/8/3/16 = 3.8
Bottle thanks to Cavie.  Muddy brown pour.  I cant smell anything in here.  Tastes like rotten meat.

Pours a dark brown to black liquid with a thick beige head. Sweet rich aroma with hints of toffee, chocolate, coffee, grapes, berries. Very delicate taste, slightly bitter and moderately sweet. Alcohol is a bit present but not overwhelming. Full body, long bittersweet malty finish.

Bottle courtesy of BückDich. Hazy reddish orange pour. Smell is weak at best. Has banana musk with light elements. Some other fruits. Taste is a dry bitter. No fruit on the flavor. This is actually extremely disappointing. Chemical cleaner or bad Lubbock water.  WTF.
Bottled. Cloudy redish brown in colour. Fruity nose, almost tomato. Herbally sweet in taste.

Murky brown pour, medium-sized and lingering light beige head. Malty chocolate and fruit notes in the aroma. Plenty of maltiness and alcohol in the body (but still very drinkable and not unpleasantly alcoholic at all), with a fairly complex overall palate.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2009 Toasty nose with subtle dried fruits, white grapes and furniture polish. Very sophisticated and complex on the palate. Even with 18 months or so of age, the secondaries are really coming through. The palate is not quite developed yet. Delicate but well-shaped finish. The whole thing is very subtle in every way, but also very enjoyable. An easy drinker at almost 10% ABV.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 33cl Bottle. Poured a dark murky brown color with a thin beige head. Great aroma and taste - both are complex but balanced. The carbonation was moderate. This is a great beer.

Bottled. Hazy murky brown with thin tan head. Aroma is fruity with apple and various fresh fruit, also yeasty/bready with malt, molasses/syrupy and alcohol nose. Flavor is caramel malt and booe with heavier bready feel. Also lighter fruits. Texture is medium thin and clean on the tongue. Leaves lasting malt flavor on tongue.

Bottle at 9th ave vitner with Thor the viking.   Poured into a large duvel Trappist glass.  Deep brown, think off white head with plenty of floaters.  Large aroma of wet figs, molasses, green apple and alcohol. Taste is malty, dark fruits and molasses with ripe carbonation.  Very nice sipper, delicate and robust.

Bottle - figured it was time to rate one of my gateways. Deep bright brown with a nice-sized head that falls pretty quickly. Nose is bread and caramel with dark fruits and bitter cocoa - not dusty, but like chocolate ganache. Taste is very yeasty to start with sweet plums and toffee mid, then the subtly bitter, woody chocolate. Just a hint of dark rum heat on the tongue. Super-well-made beer. Brings memories of buying 3 of these @ a convenience store in a small belgian town and drinking them out of plastic hotel room cups.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2010 Bottle. Dark murky brown pour with a thick, lasting white head. Tobacco, rich ripe grape and plum aromas thick with some roasted barley aromas and nuts. Some alcohol and yeast in traces. Sweet sticky toffee taste with rhum and grapes, nice complexity. Beautifully full and mellow mouthfeel.

Very fine, sweet, floral aroma.  This is a malty and complex ale, with flavors of baking chocolate, cola, and hops.  It is dry and well-bittered, but with a sweet, gingerbread softness in it also.  Fairly light-bodied, and it is hard to believe this has a 9.2% alcohol content.  RT8 grabs the palates attention with a lingering tingle.  This is probably my favorite of the Trappistes Rochefort releases - an excellent brew.

( 330ml bottle bb 12-17-13). Pours very murky orange-brown with yeast particles and nice lasting head. Nose chocolate, rum raisins, yeast, alcohol, bread, and caramel. Taste is creamy, spicy and bready yeast, nuts, and alcohol. Finishes a little warm, very creamy and nearly overcarbonated. If this was slightly sweeter it would be amazing.

Love these brews! Rochefort, you are a friend of mine! I like the 10 and 6 a little better, but this is a great strong ale. Nice and creamy, lots of dark fruits, wonderful aroma. The only thing that Im not wonderfully fond of is the aftertaste. I cant pinpoint what it is, but it doesnt do it for me quite like its brothers.Very, very good beer.

poured dark brown with a slight off white head that stuck around longer than expected.  smelled like bread, fruit, and molasses.  tasted a lot lighter than expected with a 9+ abv. very carbonated and very refreshing.  no alcohol after taste either.  very very drinkable.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. Lot L260912 10:04. 
App.:  Very deep copper with remnants of a tan head.
  
Aroma:  Deep sweet dark fruits, molasses, a bit of woodiness and rum, a little buttery, some minty herbals, lots of sweet malt aromas, quite inviting.
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate but soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Quite sweet and fruity, lots of caramel/toffee, herbals, molasses mintiness, slightly woody, a bit of alcohol, some yeast; sweet with balancing bitterness, a little alcohol and some light tannins, all with a pleasant, lightly woody malt finish. 

Certainly a bit simpler than the 10, but the alcohol is much more concealed and it is still a wonderful brew.

This brew poured with a pretty neutral brown hue. It was pretty murky - probably because I got the end of the bottle, so bits of barley were in the head and in the brew - it made it look like coffee. There was also a fantastic off-white head that lasted for quite a while. It had a pretty sweet scent with a hint of coffee and hops in it. Strangely, on first taste, the first thing I got was alcohol. This is pretty strange considering most brews will have the alcohol taste at the end. It reminded me strongly of a thick cappuccino and it ended very sweet. This was wildly different than most other high-alcohol brews that we have where it starts alcoholic and ends sweet. Dare I say: it tickled my fancy.

33cl bottle from Alko.  Dark brown with at big, beige thick head. Aroma is mostly chocolate and coffee. Very complex flavor, caramel, plums and malt. Sweet warm finish. I think I enjoyed mine little too cold, hence a hard time to notice all the aroma.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2011 330mL bottle - pours dark brown with a big beige head. Fantastic aroma of chocolate, raisins, plum. Flavour is plums, malt and yeast. Medium-bodied, though no where near Rochefort 10.

It seems as though all the Rochefort brews hold their head up high and its very impressive. The aroma is of sweet fruits, coffee, chocolate, and brown sugar. The taste instantly reminds me of the 10, but only weaker, it tastes of bitter sweet fruit, brown sugar, and roasted malts. This brew finishes very smoothly, which is to be expected, and leaves a nice alcohol/fruit taste in the palate.

Bottle from Mr Lawrence Wine Merchant, Brockley. Pours dark brown with a beige head which leaves some good lacing around the glass. Aromas of chocolate, raisins, plum pudding, slightly nuttly. Flavours of raisins, dark fruits, bitter chocolate, demerara sugar, vanilla. Finsihes sweet, smooth with a gentle hoppiness.

Bottle for personal rating #1100. Pours a chunky opaque light brown with a huge beige head. Nose of raisin, brown sugar, belgian yeast, toffee and tart black cherry. Yeasty flavor with brown sugar, dark fruits and booze with a semi-sweet finish. Not quite as good as the 10, but pretty solid.

Dark Amber/Copper in coloring with a dense, thick head on the pour. Coloring is even, a bit murky. In the mouth, something of a refreshing carbonation with caramelized sugar, maltiness, and hint of molasses and toffee. Possibly fig. Not as raisiny as the 10, which is a positive point, to me. Very well balanced.
UPDATED: DEC 14, 2014 Simply put, Wow! A lot of reviewers say it tastes like raisins or plums, to me it tastes like Concord white grape juice with beer added.Left me feeling euphoric.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 Pours a hazy medium brown, with a huge beige head, excellent retention, very fine lacing. Aromas of biscuit, ripe fruit, pepper, cilantro, cake, and wood. The aroma significantly improves as it warms.  Medium body, smooth and creamy. Medium sweet, a hint of citrus, with an earthy slightly bitter finish.
Poured into a trappist glass. Aromas of raisins and plums. Initial flavor of plums, malt and yeast. Ends with a bittersweet and heavy taste. Not a bad beer. Better that the 6.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Bottle. 11.2 oz. Split with Sean and Dave. Pours slightly hazy amber with a creamy, thin, tightly-bubbled off-white head. Awesome ring of lace remains throughout. Aroma of toasted raisins, vanilla, figs, overripe apples, sweet malts, dark fruity esters, and slight nots of molasses and bittersweet chocolate. The body is medium to light, with a highly carbonated, slightly dry, gingerly sweet palate. Tastes overwhelmingly like mealy apples, fresh raisin bread, and real cinnamon. The finish is crisp, complex, and soothingly warm. The alcohol is almost completely undetectable, except for the gentle warming in the chest. This is a prime example of a Belgian strong ale done exceedingly, formally well. A must try for any serious fan of the style.

Bottle. 
Pours a hazy dark amber with a big tan head. 
It has a well balanced and very vinous aroma with notes of sweet malt, rock candy, spices and dark fruit especially raisins.
Flavour is raisins, alcohol, rock candy, spices and wood with hints of sweet roasted malt. Ending in a alcohol raisin finish. Thin bodied.

Smells strongly of fermenting malt but is greatly overshadowed by a musty, mildewy smell that really isnt that pleasant of an addition, it reminds me of my experiences with not-that-great homebrew. Somehow it manages to be both completely dark AND cloudy, though how you can see clouds through the dark, I dont know. But this beer does it somehow. The flavour is so smooth at first your sort of waiting around for it to pick up and then its all up from there. The yeasty flavour actually hits before the malts, and then it all bubbles nicely off the tounge as only a belgian can. Very nice, but I do have to say I thought it would be a bit thicker/stronger.

Pours deep brown, With a tall white head, Looks Amazing, like it should be in an ad or something. Aroma is very malty with slight fruit notes, Very malty, bready flavour. Very rich and deep, notes of chocolate are preasent towards the end of the palate, and just the most subtle fruit flavoue. I am very impressed. This is a great trapist. It really gives me every thing I would expect of Trapist. Like I said before, Great!

330ml. My favorite beer overall. After tasting it again in blind condition im sure this is for me the best beer in the world. Malty caracter with a caramal and fruity taste. Great beer with a excellent performance. Only they could have added some more hops to this beer. Absolutly a perfect beer none the less.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is malty caramel, dry fruit, plum, raisin and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, dry fruit, raisin and plum.

Got this in a bottle in the Porterhouse in Dublin. Wonderful deep, dark brown colour with lasting tan head. Aroma is strong and of fruit and malts. Flavor was also strong. Tasted malty with fruity notes. Not particularly bitter, sweet or sour. Well balanced. Finish was of a strong alcoholic kick though perhaps not as strong as on might expect. Fantastic beer all round and one for those long winter evenings.

Enjoyed from an 11.2 oz bottle in an elongated tulip glass.  The beer pours a deep ruby to just lighter than brown.  Winey and almost sour notes come through in the nose, as does some raisony malt.  The palate is slightly sour up front, and then malty toward the middle and finish.  Carbonation lessens the aforementioned characters, but not to a point that seriously detracts from the overall qualities of the beer.  Overall, a classic.
cloudy dark brown pour with a tan head that disappears rather quickly. fruit and bread on the nose. little alcohol on the palate. great nutty finish. slightly heavy mouthfeel.

11.2 oz bottle 9/21/09 (Courtesy of ygtbsm94)-Pours a dark brown with a small loose tan head. Aroma of fruit, yeast, bread, and butter. Taste of malt, caramel, toffee, and fruits. Alcohol burn when going down. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and quite tasty but maybe I was expectimg more than there was.

Bottle.  Pours a thick dark brown color with a nice, fluffy tan head.  Aromas of bread, and herb are prevalent on the nose and on the tongue.  A little harsh on the palate, has a warm alcohol burn down the throat.  I was a little disappointed in this, Ive had better Abbey beers, both Official Trappist and Non-official.  Still decent.

Pours a lovely cloudy brown color with beige head, some lacing. aroma is typical of a Trappiste Ale, with grains, and fermented fruit. The flavor is strong and tatstes of fruit and warm alcohol notes. This beer is good, but it is not as flavorful as the Trappistes 10.

Cloudy, deep brown in appearance with a generous head. Unsure if beer is naturally hazy or if I disturbed the yeast a bit too much

Nose is the real treat with this beer. Reminds me of a clean brewery, some unfamiliar smells along with the yeasty bready aromas that you love. Take that and combine it with many desert spices that are elusive, maybe brown sugar, nutmeg, Christmas pudding, and Irish bread pudding with amaretto topping.

On the palate the beer is noticeably thin bodied and carbonated well but youre just so enchanted by the nose that you dont care what else there is. Yes, I cant get past the nose. No need to comment on taste.

Finish is somewhat sour and reminds me of burnt apples. Can I just nose the beer? Is that permitted?

pours a deep dark brown with puffy beige head. aroma of barley, prunes, maybe some fresh oranges and a cognac perhaps. taste of malt, with a hint of clove, raisins also. aftertaste is strong of alcohol but not in a bad way, a warming, smooth delicious swallow. great stuff.
A nice beer. Aroma of fruit and grains. A small taste of alcohol but not to much. A dark taste with some hits of chocolate  and perhaps some fruit. And a really fine finish.

Bottle 330 ml. A delicious strong beer. Aroma is butter, grain, and alcohol. Flavour is mostly sweet, warmly alcoholic, with a very long finish. Palate is full-bodied and sticky. Colour is dark brown, head is white and stable.

Bottle. Dark murky brown pour with a decent beige head on top. Dark fruit aroma. Taste is dark fruit, caramel, hint of chocolate, quite sweet. A nicely balanced easy drinking version of Rochefort 10. Belgian beer at its best.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark golden almost brown color, rich tan head.  The aroma is fantastic, there is some bread, some tobacco-like spice, and a little bit of dried fruit.  The palate is near perfect, not too light or too dense.  The carbonation is alive but not bouncy, and the alcohol is only prevalent as a warm sensation at the end.  The flavors include some spice, and a little bit of dried fruit and of course malted grain.  Great beer!
Much like its big brother 10. Great beer that I wish I could drink more often. Dark brown color with light tan head, nose is full and fruity and caramel flavor

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2014 Bottle. Dark cloudy brown body with medium tan head. Aroma is malt, yeast, caramel, toasted, dark fruits and plume. Flavour is malt, caramel, yeast, toasted, dark fruits, plume, sweet, oak, wood, sweet and a little bitter.

couple years ago all the local abc liquor stores knocked the price down on these to $1.99 - so I drove around and bought all of them.  thirty or so.  yet somehow I didnt manage to get a rating in.  with that preface - bottle.  dark rich brown pour with a large beign head and tons of retention.  there are little brown floaties on the side of the glass.  spicy aroma of light tobacco, bread and dark fruits.  think I always notice the texture first with these - perfect medium palate with consistent lively carbonation and nice warming alcohol in the finish.  sugary caramel malt taste with pepper spices, plums and cereal.  still a great beer.

I was really excited to finally try this since I was a bit disappointed by Rochefort 6 and flabbergasted by R. 10... A hazy dark red pour with a typical stable and frothy head. The aroma reminds me a lot of the empty wooden barrels of red wine in my uncles winery, together with light caramel and whiskyish notes. Definitaley a citric component too, not sure about its origin. The flavour is... Wow, really amazing - mouthfilling, warming chocolate/walnuts, dark, ripe fruits and again delicious sweet caramel. Light roasted malt in the finish, together with a nice bitterness. The carbonation is medium but very adequate, complementing the mouth-coating creaminess this beauty leaves behind. This is similar to Rochefort 10, yet a gem on its own - more drinkable and less annihilating alcohol-wise. Love it!

Aroma: Plums, dark fruit, caramel, yeast. Appearance: Dark murkey brown, thin lasting head that leaves lacing. Flavor: Dark Fruit, chocolate, sweet caramel, yeast, a little spice. Palate: medium body, creamy, lively, astringent, with some alcohol. Overall Impression: This beer is very good. with a very nice flavor and good balance.

22-AUG-2009, Bottle @Henriks.
Brown, beautifull.
Very complex, citrucy, malty, I cannot describe all the wonderfull aromas.
Nice carbonation and creamy.
Perfect beer, I just think I have had to many now to give it a fair rating...
I can barely read my own notes, so definately...
Sorry Rochefort

Pours a very dark and murky brown with one finger of creamy head. 

Smells fruity, bananas and light berries. 

Tastes similar to smell, very complex with those same hints of fruit and other light spices and bread. 

Mouth is thin to medium bodied with high carbonation. 

Not bad, not a westy 8 but not bad.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2012 FRESH: Pours copper/ruby with a large but rapidly diminishing head.
Aromas of vanilla, honey, cinnamon, pears, yeast. Very perfumy. Bready, sweet cookie dough. Alcohol is just noticeable as a pleasant, slightly spicy note. Later on figs/prunes and caramel become apparent. There is so much going on here!
Similar flavours, but not as much complexity. Alcohol is much more apparent, especially in the harsh finish.
Carbonation is too high for my liking, but otherwise mouthfeel is good.
Absolutely fantastic aroma, its a pity this didnt follow through to the flavours.

AGED (3 years): Amazing aroma as before, more concentrating on honey, toffee, caramel, and chocolate though. Very complex. Flavours seemed to have dried out, but the alcohol is reasonably well integrated now.

Pour a hazy cola brown color with a creamy, tan head.  Aroma is of baked banana bread, rasins, brown sugar, carmel, and yeast.  flavor is of toasted malts, banana, chocolate, yeast, licorice, carmel, rasins, dark fruit, and a lttile port charcter. has medium body and swetness.  high abv is somewhat noticable but not overpowering.  finnish moderatly bitter and slighty sour.  this is extremely tasty and complex beer that has alot going on.

August 18, 2009.  Got bottle from Norms Beer and Wine in Vienna, VA.

Aroma: Caramelly nose.

Appearance: Nice brown, hazy color.

Flavor:  Medium sweetness with just a taste of sour.

Palate:  Medium body.

Overall: A pretty nice and tasty beer - My first beer rating on Rate Beer!
I really wish I had written down more than numbers and "Delicious with a wonderful malty character!"  Go figure, right...
09-08-12 330 ml bottle dark caramel colour. off-white fading head. nice spicey and fruity taste with alcohol present. the 10 is a bit better I think.

Pours hazy amber brown with a fairly thin cream colored head.  Aroma is fruity and estery with a little bit of banana coming through.  Flavor is caramel, dark and light fruits, esters, and even a nice slight hop presence.  Very good stuff.

I can actually find this beer in Vancouver, Canada. Firefly and brewery creek have it. Sweet yeast smell that is delicate and enticing. The beer is dark and rich looking with a light head. The taste is complex showing dark fruit. Really enjoyable and even better its accessable.

Poured from a 11.2oz bottle into a Chimay goblet.

The color is a dark burgundy and pretty cloudy with a light brownish head. Some slight lacing.

The smell is sweet with some yeasty aroma with a malt presence that is quite unbelievable. Some licorice flavor mixed in with some bready, grainy flavor.

The taste is sweet at first and then does punch with some really nice flavoring. Good warm hints of raisins, some other dried fruit I cant quite place at this time.Flavor reminds me not of bread but of dough.

The feel of this beer is quite pleasing. It is light, a bit tangy but well balanced

33cl bottle poured into a Rochefort Trappist glass.  Dark brown with two finger creamy lasting tan head.  Aroma is musty at first, then dark fruit and hints of yeast.  Flavor is roasty with notes of dark fruit, licorice, slight alcohol.  Medium carbonation, smooth, medium body.  Finish is moderately bitter with hints of malty sweetness and a small dose of warming alcohol.  Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a dark copper with an off-white head that sticks around. Wonderfully smooth palate with flavours of toasted malt, chocolate, toast, raisins, pudding with undercurrents of port or muscat. Has a really long finish where the complexity of the flavour becomes even more apparent. A sensational beer, just like the "10", which considering the abv, is dangerously drinkable.

Bottle.  Pours a mahogany brune body with a tan head.  Chewy sweet chocolate malts, dark fruit plum and raisin notes.  Hints of ash char and and mineral notes.  Hints of spicy cinnamon caramel and vinous notes.  Infinitely complex and enjoyable.  My favorites range 5 to 8 years old.  What a phenomenal beer.  I raise this glass to the top 100.  The rating is for a 2002 vintage bottle consumed in 2008.  Amazing brew!
rich dark pour with a large off white head, plenty of great lacing...nose is dried fruit some chocolate...sweet flavor, great finish
05.08.2006, o,33l Bottle. Brown colour. Aroma is dark-malty with some spices and fruit.

Poured coppery with not much head.  Beer was thick with lots of interesting little floaties. Smelled citrisy/spicy. Had an effervescent feel and a fruity complex taste. Could not taste the alcohol but it did have a dry finish. Very enjoyable.

Bottle (330ml). Poured muddy dark copper with a good sized frothy, beige head which lasted extremely well. Spicy, complex aroma with notes of wild yeast with freshly baked cinnamon bread, honey oats, allspice, caramelized dates, boiled sweets and preserved apricots. Flavor was incredible, with strong notes of black pepper with sweet wholegrain bread, almond flakes, dried mixed fruits, fermenting peaches, cinnamon with a warming superb finish. Full bodied with medium carbonation, a warming mouthfeel, and a fantastic length finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2013 33cl bottle bought in Belgium. Frothed over as soon as it was opened and subsequently poured a bit cloudy and lumpy. Deep red-brown with very little head, nose is vinous, plummy, toffee-malty, notes of orange. Initial taste is woody with loads of alcohol, hints of port, aftertaste is dry with burnt caramel and hops. Re-rate, this one poured almost clear with a lasting beige head, fruity and toffee nose, rich and dry-bitter over a warming and orangey body, still a touch of toasted caramel but much more harmonious this time.
Pours a reddish copper with an off white head. Aroma is bready malt, floral hops, and fruit. Flavor is sweet malt, dark fruits, a bit of spice, and a semi-dry alcohol finish.
I think I paid $6 for a 4 oz. Sample at the Biere Mondialle, I wonder how much it will cost for me to visit Belgium to try this again?

Bottle at PIB. Cola brown pour with light tan head, light lacing. Aroma is bready and full of fruit: grapes, apples, plum. Flavor is much the same, slightly vinous and with a nice roast to it. Full bodied mouth and very pleasing all the way down. Cant wait to try the 6 and 10!
This beer has a very sweet and fruity aroma with hints of flowers and herbs. It has a sweet, spicey flavor of dried fruits, herbs and hops.

Huge foamy light colored head. The actual body of the beer was an opaque dark brown.  I was actually surprised at how grapey and wine like many of the beers characteristics were. There were a multitude of aromas of sour and astringent fruit, soft malt, grapes, and dankness. Flavors were of fruit punch, malt, cola, and bitter spices. Creamy smooth mouth-feel.  Alcohol like its big brother is impeccably balanced. Not really my style of beer, but theres no denying its pedigree. This is a classic that isnt quite as good as Rochefort 10. However, it stands apart on its own legs as a amazing brew. Salud!
Pours a lacing beige head with a hazy brown body like cola.  Smells astringent and a little fruity.  Flavor is roasted malts, dried fruits, toffee, and yeast.

Love those Belgians. Murky brown swill-looking ale with sediment pours into Trappist glass with speckled tan head. Aroma is sweet bread, light baked apples, chocolate, licorice and earthy undertones. Taste is plum and figs, dark malt, licorice and spice, brot, with a long finish. Starts complex and bold, gets smoother the more you sip. A true classic.

Pours dark brown with a 3 finger head. This beer looks good. Aroma is bready, pears & other fruit. Taste is fruity, bready, chocolate. & very smooth. The alcohol is hidden well & silky smooth. I want more to age.

33cl bottle, dark brown with creamy beige head, strong aroma of dark chocolate, licorice and fruits (plum, peach), roasted notes, spiced flavor, medium body, finish with spices and some alcohol, not as expected but really complex

From Firefly.  Poured out a very dark brown beneath a creamy beige head, perhaps two fingers thick.  Aroma was spiced and also featured some darker fruits, perhaps raisins or plums, hence the resulting sweetness to the taste.  Mouthfeel was solid and smooth, and nearly too sweet at the finish.

nose of yeast and some pit fruits, raisins specifically.  appearance is dark brown and nearly opaque. flavor is of hops and alcohol that sizzle and dance on my liips and palate.  a burn starts then fades quickly to a smooth end that is not dry.  high ABV for an 8 but comes across as it should on that arbitrary scale.  a mellow beer that comes in like a lion and out like a lamb, world class.

Bottle at the Beer Engine. Pours a dark, murky brown, with a thin white head. Loses appearance points for containing gross-looking wheat flakes (which are tasteless, though). Fantastic taste though. Very dark and complex. Hard to describe, but thoroughly recommended.

Amber / light brown color, solid off white head with nice flowery smell - Very nice malty taste, fuity taste from hops, the high alcohol level very nice hidden - very nice and complex beer with a long lasting aftertaste

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 .33l bottle bought in Luxembourg City. Poured very dark brown with hints of red. Off white head was huge but left quickly. No lacing was a minus but the vast amount of sediment was a plus. Very cool. You can smell a ton of spices and alcohol. Flavor of alcohol was strong but the spices and grapefruit feel  was nice. Great beer. I cant wait to have the R10 later today.
Bottle at the Beer Engine.  Pours thin murky river color.  Off white head.  Pale IPA flavor.  Really strange and soooo different from the 10.

This is a still a great beer, but just cant live up to its big brother R10.  

For $6 cheaper a beer, Ill sadly drink more R8 then R10.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2010 7/21/09: Pours dark translucent brown, big flakes of yeast sediment, thin off-white head that will just stay there for half an hour.  Smells of overripe peach, sugar, and alcohol.  Taste is of strong alcohol, spicy dark malty bread, a bit more burnt than a standard Trappist. A tad bit boozy in the aftertaste.  Rerate 10/20/10: Much better than my original rating.  Since having the rochefort 10 and other Belgians, I have been on a quest to brew a dark beer with some of the same qualities of its tastiness.  After drinking both of them together, I feel that the 8 has the beautiful breadiness of the 10 without the darker crystal malts and sugars to mask it.  It is both delicious and also necessary to understand before one can successfully recreate the 10.
bottle, dark brown-rediish misty with medium head, but quite some carbonation. this is a good beer, very complex long aftertaste all kinds of aromas. yet, very drinkable!

Bought in Dec 05, drank in August 06 - no worries about this being an old, irrelevant beer review, It will be constantly updated. Ive got a dozen of these suckers cellared.
Looks like rootbeer. Has a 1/4", very thick tan head. Excellent 360 degree lacing. Tons of muck and a good amount of granual like sediment. The aroma is awesome. Intense spice, dates, burnt sugar, soft liquid banana flavouring, I swear I can smell candied orange rind. Dont drink it yet...keep smelling...ahhhh. It just keeps changing. So very comples. The 8 has an amazing blend and balance of the spice and fruit. Tasty yeast and seems almost meaty. THere is a good ammount of alcohol along with the caramel, licorice, plum or date, oranges (weak).... I think thats it. Incredibly smooth and full bodied.
