The harsh spice seems to turn soft - soft harsh spice that has turned soft, sweet and chewy yeasty stuff. Mild but lengthy aftertaste that has left my mouth soft. How many times did I type soft? Hard bitter last sip with all that sediment that ended up getting a bit sour. The last bit of mud at the bottom of my glass after the final pour of the remaining sediment gave it a murky brown / orange colour. Hello heavan.
Pours a beautiful dark red-dark brown into a Belgian chalice. Nice sweet aromas. Tastes like oak and cherry. Very smooth finish with an ever so slight hint of alcohol at the end. Nearly perfect.

Pours a dark brown, cloudy, creamy beige head. Nose of raisins, yeast, malt. Taste is sweet, malty, mild fruit and alcohol taste, finish is warming. Texture is very creamy. I cant wait to come across a 10 now.

Pours dark brown with a fizzy off-white head and constant bubble realease. I poured this beer and let it sit watching the head grow for about 10 minutes. Aroma is cherry, caramel, and other mild fruits. Taste is smooth and roasty with no bitterness. Very rich beer, sweet and alcoholic.

Pours deep beown with a nice small head. Taste is deep with a nice fruit and carmel flavor infused throughout. The smell lingers and allows you to relish the flavors you soon enjoy. Since the 10 can be hard to get (it is my fav) this is a great beer to drink as you wait for the next 10.
Massive meringue head (as expected), deep brown colour. Has a multi layered complexity about it. I get dark malt, raisins and a yeasty taste. Cant really go wrong wit Trappistes Rochefort

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a bunch of floaters and a one finger beige head.  The nose is light fruit and caramel.  The taste is earth, light chocolate, fruit and caramel with some light booze.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Its good, but I expected more since the 10 is one of my favorite beers.

Bottle. Almost opaque brown orange with a meidum foaumy beige head. Aroma is raisins, dates, plums, roasted malt, brown sugar, spices and alcohol. Flavor is brown sugar, dark fruits, apples, roasted malt, yeast, alcohol and hops. Fizzy carbonation. Full body.

Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours dark plum / brown with a firm off white head.
Aroma of dark fruits, banana, yeast and some alcohol.
Tastes of caramel, banana and malt.
Pours cloudy deep brown with a huge creamy off-white head. Weak fruity aroma. Taste is certainly not weak at all, here are rich dark fruits,sweet malts and warming alcohol. Decent one!

Very dark hazy brown with tons of effervescence bubbles floating to the top, very nice crown was floating on top it started about an inch tall then reduced to a thick skiff that was constantly replenished, walls of lacing was left behind. Smooth sweet banana aroma with tons of earthy spicy notes the 9.2% is not even noticeable. I think Im picking up some subtle milk chocolate in the aroma, such a good smell Ive been sniffing for 30 minuets now and the complex aroma is still intriguing me. First sip caught me off guard it was a little harsh but felt thick and creamy. The alcohol is noticeable in the flavor but barely, lots of earthy malts and touches of spice with tons of banana. There is no after taste but something in this flavor is reminding of a frosty from Wendys. This is a very tasty high quality & complex brew but its only a mere shadow compared to its big brother the 10

Pours a cloudy brown with a huge pillowy head that sticks around indefinitely.  Aroma is weak, vaguely of a Belgian abbey ale; Just a little brown sugar, bread, and fruit on the nose. Flavor is tasty, but just par for a trappist Belgian; Nothing new or extraordinary; sweet breadiness, yeast, brown sugar. Not too profound, but very drinkable. Very creamy, as is to be expected. Mouthfeel is very nice; Perfect fizz coupled with cream and thick viscosity. Not nearly as good as the 10, but a decent substitute for which if necessary. Overall, very good minus.

Pours a cloudy reddish-black with a creamy off-white head.

Tasted this one a month after trying the 10, which was clearly far superior...but the 8 is still worthy of a taste.  Thinner, lighter, and perhaps more crisp, the sediment seemed to permeate this 8 far more and clouded some of the malt and fruit flavors.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2017 11.2 oz. bottle split with Boo; from Liquor Barn (Fern Valley); best by 2020. Aroma: Moderate fig preserves with toffee; lighter leather and orange liqueur. Appearance: Murky garnet brown with a creamy tan head that stays for the duration. Flavor: Fruity, fig jam-like notes up front that quickly shift into toffee with leather; orange liqueur shows up more towards the finish, which lingers and doesnt entirely hide its strength. Palate: Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: A classic that should never go out of fashion. Id take this over most any hoppy beer given the opportunity and budget to afford either.
Possibly my favorite beer, every time you drink it you get another dark fruit flavor.   Can buy this for just over one euro a bottle at my local supermarket so theres always one in my fridge

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Translucent deep brown, thin cola like head. Some nice caramel and winte3r spice flavor. Carbonated finish, with some lingering sweetness. Warming but alcohol not overt, very nice clove and brown sugar finsih.

330 ml bottle in Belguim, This is not the type of beer I normally like. However that beng said it had a nice brown color with a light brown head with perfect lacing. Aroma of brown sugar. Alcohol not well hiden bt it grows on you when you drink it. Over all a great beer but not something that I want to drink all of the time.

Bottle - I was expected to be knocked off my feet by this beer, but it was really underwhelming. First off, it looked dead in my glass -- a syrupy amber with suspended floaties that dont move. It looked solid. The smell, admittedly, is incredible. Theres toffee, plum, even a little menthol (?) -- its big and sweet and reminded me of a barley wine. The flavor is pretty good, too -- sweet malt, dark fruit, and candy. Theres a good deal of booze in there too -- its a little hot. The body makes it hard to taste the beer -- its syrupy and the carbonation is jacked up. It was hard trying to pick out flavors between the bubbly assault on my tongue. All in all, a big disappointment. This was a good beer, but nothing like I was expecting.
11.2oz bottle. Really good. Nice creamy head. Pours dark. Alot of complex flavors that change as it warms. Very minimal alcohol taste despite the 9.2% abv.

POOR THIRSTS A PERFECT 8 !
Having already had the Trappiste 10, this was always going to be difficult. Probably a good idea to have both together but regardless this is a splendid beer. The pour seemed thinner than the 10, and the head still buoyant. The taste is malt, coffee, chocolate with a hint of sharpness that the 10 doesnt have. I cant split them though. Both fantastic beverages, even with a heavy cold the flavours pour through
great beer, alcohol is a little too present unlike the 10 where it is well hidden. Its good but not great.

Brought back a bottle from Belgium. Pours with a thick white head that disolves quickly. Looks chololate brown, almost like a dark iced-tea. Has a rich caramel / alcholo smell about it. I can taste caramel flavors, hints of chololate, has an addition hint of musty or something old, but in a good way. Perhaps not too unlike an ESB?? Good beer, but I dont think its a 100 rating.

Weak but nice aroma of malt, wood, lemon, pine, and thistle. Well balanced and complex. Muddy brown, with a thick firm tan head. Musty old flavor of candied pears, toffee at midpalate, perfect balance. Chestnuts appear when warmer. Nice transitions. Alcohol noticeable, but feels much less than it is. Faint thistle finish playfully comes and goes. Remarkably well conceived and made. It would probably pair well with strong cheeses. Who could not like this one?

11.2 oz. bottle at TJs.  Poured chocolate brown with a skim of fizzy tan head.  Flavor absolutely dominated by sweet, dark fruits.  Lots of plum, fig, and raisins evident.  A very good beer, nowhere near the 10 though.
Enjoyed this much more than the 6.  complex aroma with caramel, sugars, yeast, and some fruit.  Taste is OK (aroma better).  Notes of caramel, some fruits and a little booze.  Enjoyable overall.

Have been saving this one for a special occasion - completion of an 18 month project.  Pours a dark chestnut brown with lots of carbonation.  Tan head, lots of yeast sediment.  Nose is dark fruit, alcohol, yeast, and light hint of licorice.  Taste is sticky, with caramel malt and some spice, slightly bitter, also some smoky characteristics - very subtle cigar taste.  Chest warming alcohol.  A very complex and excellent beer.

Pours murky brown with a big, foamy beige head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is of malt, caramel, yeast, sugar, and fruit. Taste starts off with a big malt flavor with lots of caramel evening it out. Big notes of banana and sugar. Lingering taste of banana and slight spice. Warming alcohol presence that doesnt take away from the other flavors at all. Body is very light due to the carbonation. Mouthfeel is very fizzy and overly malty. I was definitely dissapointed after both the 10 and the 6, but it was decent.
Huge amount of carbonation in this bottle. Cloudy moderately dark brown. Sweet aroma with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is smooth with a bit of coffee/chocolate.
Short, tan head with no lacing, dark orange/amber color.  Green grasses aroma.  Mild flavor of sour, very little sweetness to this one, but tastes very mild and hides the liquor in it well.

11.2oz bottle from bevmo. Pours a deep swampy copper color with and off white head that left some spotty lacing. Nose was sweet with candied tree fruits, candy sugar, light booze. Flavor was also quite sweet with caramel, toffee, and candied apricots.

Bottle. Pours a lovely dark chocolate brown head, with a brandy-ish hue. thick, rich, tan head with quite nice lacing. Aromas of cigar box, vanilla. Palate is rum and raisin, figs and dates, mild, rich coffee as well.  with some chocolate. Its a bit boozy as it warms,  which is unfortunate. Finish is long, and warming, with some noticable alcohol.

Bottle. Pours dark dark brown.
Aroma: Dark chocolate, coffee, pepper, dark fruits, smoke, wood and burnt dark malt.
Flavor: Malt, chocolate, coffe, smoke, brown sugar,pepper and raisin.
Palate is mediumbodied. Pleasent and quite long round sweet and in the same way hot aftertaste.

bottled, clear dark amber brown with medium tan head with a LOT of yeast sediment, aroma of raisins, sweet malt, brown sugar, sweet caramel flavor with alcohol notes that arent overpowering, heavily carbonated with residual fruit on palate, better when it warms, oddly very mellow

Pours a dark, nutty brown. Thick white head that QUICKLY dissipates until gone. Not lacing at all. Aroma strong of apples and yeast. Flavor has an instant flavor of hard apple cider. Slightly sour. Prickly/sparkly on the tongue. Very carbonated, almost like a soda pop. Body is a little light and I dont really dig the carbonation. Not really my thing.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2010 Bottle. Pours out with a creamy, almost cremecoloured head. Aromas of coffee, roasted malt and caramel. Dark-coloured. Tastes like roasted malt, some kind of nuts, intense. Finish is diminishing a little bit quickly.
Drunk again 6 oct 2010, a one year layered bottle. very nice, warming alcohol, also clove and vanilla.

Pours clear dark amber brown, with a good amout of carbonation.  Aroma of dark fruit, sugary malt, light spice.  Taste is similar with the sweet malt being the main flavor, followed by fruit, and light toffee.  Mouth is lively and medium bodied.  Overall, an interesting and very drinkable brew.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2009 Bottle from Berts bierhuis, Utrecht NL. Beautiful dark-brown colour. Very dark with a lively head. Well carbonated.
Aroma of chocolate with strawberry-green banana mix overtones. Or is it peaches? Apples too? :-)
Bitter-sour in fine balance with the sweetness. Dark milk chocolate palate with a very subtle bitterness. The hint of alcohol reminds me of bonbons. Nice beer - the aftertaste is the best: its like you really just had a piece of chocolate.
Dark coffee, pours beautifully, wonderfully complex flavor. not as good as rochefort 10 but still excellent
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet, caramel, dark fruits.  Taste is bready, spices, sweet at the end.  Fizzy coating mouthfeel.  Very good, but slightly underwhelmed.

Dark brown, small head.  Aroma of alcohol, candy sugar, sweet dark fruits.  The mouthfeel on this one bothers me.  It kind of foams up in your mouth, make it frothy.  Bread, sweet, dryness is overdone.  Caramel.  A little tart bitterness at the end, figs, plums.  Overall, the flavors are actually pretty mellow-subtle and complex.
Bottle. Pours a reddish brown. Complex aroma of fruits with hints of nuttiness. Flavor is also complex. Sweet with tones of fruitiness. A very enjoyable beer.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep, slightly hazy mahogany with a pillowy, very light tan head.  Soap, tropical fruit, pineapple, and a hint of alcohol in the nose.  Medium-high carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Soap, ripe tropical fruits, a bit of spice, alcohol, a medicinal note, and a light bitterness on the palate.  The soap keeps throwing me off on this one.  I would say this beer is okay, but far from great.  Given the ratings Ive seen I will retest, but right now I have to say this just isnt a good beer.
bottle - hazy brown beer with thick beige white head. Aroma has some sourness like wine. Complex flavour. Some caramel and spices. Alcohol detectable.

Courtesy of Chibbyman. Thanks once more. Dark reddish-brown pour with huge tan head that left a nice lacing on the glass. Sweet aroma that was slight- dark fruit, teast. Taste was also slighly sweet, thick, malty, and left a dryness to my mouth and lips. Slight alcohol. Drank this at temp right out of the earthen cellar I store the beer in.
Pours brown. Dark fruit, fig, nuts, sweet sugars, alcohol. Slight cocoa, dark fruits, booze, raisins. Dry. Excellent!

Rating #50?  Pours a dark brown, with ample light yellow styrofoam head.  Not cold enough?  Aroma is solidly of citrus and raisins.  Sweet taste, far superior to the 6.  Bananas mixed with raisins and anise and darl malts.  Yummy.  Im drinking it warmer than it was likely intended, and so I am probably missing something.  Even so, a wonderful beer.  Plenty of body and an absolutely balanced mouthfeel.  If I had more, I would drink it.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2011 From 330 ml bottle into chalice.  Pours a deep, cloudy brown.  Drinking this at around 55-60 degrees.  Not as much "silt" as the 6 had.  Moderate carbonated head mostly diminishing, but not as much as the 6.  Lacing throughout as opposed to zero for the 6.  I agree with another reviewer - the aroma is pretty mellow, more to me than the 6.  Malty, figs, raisin, alcohol evident on the palate and in the finish.    With that said this is quite an enjoyable brew - wow!  Update Jan 16, 2011.  Same purchase date as one drank May 2009.  Wanted to cellar for two years to see how this one turned out.  Trying to find much update, other than it is an exceptional offering.  I truly understand why many prefer this to the "10".  It begins with the complexity on the nose, all the way through the smooth, yet powerful finish.  No doubt you are drinking a substantial brew - outstanding!

Pours a cloudy medium brown with a large beige head, and some rather large bits of silt. Aroma is mellow, but extremely complex and ever-changing, sweet dark fruit, rasins, yeast,  toasted malt, leather, licorice, banana, and some brown sugar. Flavor is amazingly mellow and complex. Very similar to aroma, but with a tad more licorice, and light alcohol. Finish is VERY clean. This is a little bit different than the 10, more mellow.

Incredible....one word that springs to mind after tasting this beer. Pour oif deep amber-brownish colour with a large off white head. The beer itself is cloudy. Aroma of banana, fruits, grass, malts, candy. An extremely complex nose and appearance. Taste is just as complex as the aroma. Some spiciness in the taste as well as bounds of malty fruity tastes. Its hard to find the individual tastes in this beer because its all so complex. Overall, an extremely rich and incredible beer.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2009 This thing is a religious experience. I prefer it to the ten, I find it more balanced and 3-dimensional. On the one hand: This thing was all soft edges, slick in the mouth, soft rich maltiness, pruneau or something, a little bit of smooth (debittered) chocolate. On the other hand: very spicy and dry, with a firm bitterness. Unmasked hot alcohol, at one moment even too much; very warming, with phenols reminiscent of spicy cinnamon (pungent cinnamon, not powdered) and even cardamom. Oh my god. I expect the people I was staying with thought I was crazy. I was doing stuff like sniffing my sleeve to clear my nose, swirling it and covering the top to collect volatiles, rolling it around my mouth. Neither of them wanted any (!!). The 33cl at 9.3% is the perfect amount of this beer, its exactly enough to experience it. So if youre holding onto one of these - dont share.
This one bounds ahead of the 6 with dark fruits present in aroma and flavor, along with jute in aroma and notable flavor of Grapenuts cereal. Pours darker, tastes rich.

Bouteille de 330 ml. Nos yeux contemplent cette bière de couleur brune avce des reflets acajoux ainsi quun col de mousse brunâtre parfait. Au nez on découvre des arômes très complexes de chocolat, de raisins rouges, de lilas, dalcool, de fruits rouges confîts et dépices. En bouche le corps est rond et soyeux avec une effervescence faible-moyenne. Nos papilles gustatives sont submergées par des saveurs de chocolat, de raisins rouges, de fruits confîts, de sucre, de grain grillé, de prunes et pour finir on percoit une touche dalcool. Vraiment Excellent !!!!

33cl bottle in chalice. Dark brown with big head. Laces a bit. Small retention (maybe too cold). Aroma is rich, sweet, dark fruits. cherryish, Some alcohol also. Hints of raisins. Good amount of carbonation. Hints of alcohol but not too much. A bit dry on the finish and a bit bitter. Nice balance. Malty, a tiny bit spicy. Really feels like the 10 without all the warmth. Would have to have them back to back to be sure.  Rating #100 !!!

Got this bottle at the liquor barn in louisville yesterday and popped it last night in the hotel room while waiting for the news to come on.

Appearance - deep dark color with alot of freaking head geez.
Typical for belgiums I guess.

Nose. Well excatly what you expect from a very good belgium dark ale. Reminds me of westy 12 and abt 12 on the nose/

The mouthfeel is of spice and plums and raisin. Very freaking smooth

Drinkabilty this is a beer that could hurt someone very easily.

Belgiums are not my favorite style and I could only do one of these but from an abstract review this is a very good beer if you like the typical belgium strong ales.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-22-2009 06:12:39

Wonderfully pungent aroma, hints of pepper and tobacco with fruit backtones, thick off brown color with thin white head.  Full of flavor and alcohol is apparent, with dark fruit flavors and a thick chewy texture.  Must try!

11.2 oz bottle served in a snifter. Pours a cloudy, sediment-ridden, dark brown with a large bubbly off-white head. Aroma is figs, prunes, and bread. Gains complexity as it warms. Medium-full body. Flavor has prunes, malts, and brown sugar. Finish of dark fruits lightly seasoned in whiskey.
This is an Excellent brew!  It has a wonderful flavor and appearance.  This is a must try for everybody!!  Just bought the 10 and cant wait to try it.

330ml bottle into tulip glass. A dark brown opaque ale with a medium-sized diminishing beige head. Nose of burnt sugar, dark fruits and spicy hops. Full bodied with tastes of fruity sugary malts with a hint of liquorice and a satisfying bittersweet dry hop finish. It is not as sweet as the aromas would suggest. Smooth on the palate with a seductive drinkability. Nice.

Bottle. Cloudy brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma: Malt, berries, apples/pears, caramel, almonds, alcohol, a hint of phenols. Taste: Malty, but with a rather light body, berries, lightly roasted, mild coffee, almonds, caramel, apples/pears, salmiac, brown sugar, lightly medicinal. Lively carbonation. Complex, and not a bad beer at all, but it really doesnt do it for me. Westvleteren 8 is much better.

Reddish brown hazy amber color, with frothy off-white head. The aroma is reminiscent of Rochefort 10. Black currant, blueberry tartness with moderate sweet cheese feel. The flavor is somewhere between the two other brews form the abbey. Grapes, berries, sugar candy flavors. Coriander, liquorice and slight alcoholic warming feel in the finale. More dense texture than the Rochefort 6.
Poured brown with a tan head. Aroma of fruit, spice, and caramel. Mellow fruit followed by caramel and cinnamon.

Location: First try was out of a bottle Nov 08 at RFD


Overall Impression: 
This one is a really, really top quality beer, Id put it just a smudge behind the its brother the 10.

I think this beer is very underated, the ten is very good, however this beer is much easier to find and is almost as good. I actually found some that already aged 3 years and were cheaper than the new ones(this beer ages well).

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2016 33cl botlte.
cloudy caramelly brown, thick light brown head.
sweet hoppy and well rounded aroma, like a good hoppy barley wine.
flavor is sweet, strangely hoppy, bitter from alc. malts, sugar. dark fruits, nice, but not totally balanced, and not worthy a score of 4+ imo.
(2009-06-04) 8,4,7,3,15
(2016-02-10) clear dark orange, smoioth offwhite head.3, aroma is malty and slightly belgian yeasty. quite mild, but i also have a cold right now, could play in.sweet spicy notes, wild yeasty notes. 8  Flavor is sweet malty, spicy, very complex, if i blind tested this id say it was a sweet tripel with lots of depth and a bit more malts than usual. Flavor is very rounded, which takes the beer to a whole new level, and the belgian yeast is adding some crispness and spicyness that is just great. 8,4,8,3,17  A lot of taste compared to alc. and alc. is well hidden.

Pours a hazy dark brown with some floaties and a big beige head. Aroma is alcohol, figs/raisins/plums, chocolaty malts, rock sugar, yeast. Flavours are more of the same, but the chocolaty malts dominate more. Carbonation is a bit lively, feels prickly on the tongue. Alcohol well hidden for the abv, but there is a slight hint of it in the finish.

Pours dark brown with thick off white head. No lacing.  Aroma was thick with alcohol until it warmed. Fruits, sugar, figs all present. Finish is sweet, but a bit alcoholic as well. Flavor was flat overall.  Some fruits and mild caramel sweetness but nothing discernible.  Im suspecting I got a bad bottle.
just like it says. little brother to 10. rich deep dried fruits, leather, tobacco, malt sweetness. great beer. love the whole line

Damn, I love the aroma of Rochefort. Little to no alcohol in the aroma, just pure Belgian complexities with lots of dark fruit, yeast, candi sugar, and little to no bitterness. Hints of banana and cloves are also present. The flavor is similar with just the perfect amount of alcoholic warmth. Masterfully crafted and delicious.

Bottle split with Ryguy. Pours a dark, hazy brown. Nice carbonation, sick sediment...mmm yeasty. Tastes delicious, lots of flavor - raisin, nut, yeast. Oh Wait! I see something.... there is a fetus in my beer! up no, just yeast sediment...but tasty like an unborn fetus.
(33 cl bottle) Dark beer with quickly disappearing head. Tastes like the Rochefort 10, but much lighter, less packed.

330ml Bottle  Trade  Douglas88
Aroma: Strong Belgian aroma with lots of yeast.   
Appearance: Dark Brown in color, cloudy with a thin head.  
Flavor: Had a Belgian yeast flavor and then it went flat on me.  The spices where not there.  This was very flavorless.   
Palate: Dry finish, with a decent Belgian Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Ok this might be others brew but not mine and this was in fact lifeless and flat.  Sorry this will not be my top 50.

Poured cloudy dark brown with a slight red tint and a three finger white head, there was some yeast sediment in the bottle.  The aroma was sweet and malty with peppery and fruity citrus notes.  The flavor was complex with malty chocolatey, spicey, peppery and raison notes.  It was sweet with a light hop bitterness.  The palate was just awesome with the very lively carbonation.  Overall this was a rich, complex beer, there is lots going on in the way of flavor and aroma and texture.  Very well done, this is what a 4+ beer should be.

Finally getting around to rating this.  Pours a nice reddish, brown hue with quite a thick head.  Aromas waft up of bready sourdough, bakers chocolate and spiced nuts.  Quite a bit of carbonation hitting the palate.  Great complexity between the candi sugar and various malts that play off each other.  The finish was a bit towards the dryer side finishing a bit more clean than I was expecting.  Not as intense of an experience as its bigger brother, but still a classic.

A: Dark brown chestnut hue that poured with a nice solid head which dimished rather quickly. There was spoty lacing and some floaties bouncing around in the glass.

S: Sweet dark fruits; prunes and figs mostly. There is a boozy rum type aroma mingled in with some bready yeast.

T: Dark fruits and rum up front. Some spices with hints of chocolate covered cherries in the middle. Malt and brown sugar finish it out along with just a tad of pipe tobacco.

N: Nicely balanced. Fairly complex brew that is balanced and ever so enjoyable.

D: This one is getting pretty rare around here. I stocked up and plan to enjoy one from time to time over the next year
100th rating.  Pours dark with a big foamy head.  a great beer.  dark fruit.  alcohol.  enjoyed more than the 10.  but lookking to try the 10 and 8 back to back before i pass judgment

Dark maroon pour with a big fizzy light beige colored head.  Smell is cherry cough syrup, belgian yeast, syrupy malt and perhaps a hint of nuttiness.  Taste is much drier than the smell leads on, with slight cherry and red fruit maltiness but it really isnt sweet.  Finishes rather abruptly with no aftertaste and a champagne like feel in the mouth.  Incredibly high, fizzy carbonation that makes it hard to taste much.  After swirling to flatten it out, there still isnt much flavor, honestly but a faint raisin quality is there.  A light bit of alcohol, but not much.  I have no idea what people see in this beer...
Huge caramel and grain aroma. Sweet and dessert-like but not a bit cloying. Creamy, full, smooth body. Complex grain, fruit, vineous character. Amazing.

Pours a very dark ruddy brown.  Off-white two finger head that dissipates slowly, but leaves little lacing.  Aroma is dried fruits.  Flavor is sweet, with cherries, raisins, toffee and oak.  Carbonated, champagne-like mouthfeel.  Alcohol is a little too present, but an excellent beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2009 Pours a hazy brown (sometimes chunky).  Yeasty aroma with burnt sugar.Taste is yeasty with rum-raisin, fig, caramel/burnt sugar, a bit of grape nuts.  Nice hops balance and dry finish.  A good brew. (rerated 9/09)
Bottle - pottles a very dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of sweet fruit and yeast. Cherry and alcohol flavours with a dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Pours murky dark brown with a thin white head.  Spicy and earthy aroma. Flavor is roasted, earthy, nuts, bitter malt and belgian spice with a touch of alcohol.  Finishes dry, mouthfeel is a little grainy.

330 ml. bottle. Pours a thin head of good duration over a murky brown (SRM 20) body with much flocculated yeast....nose of fruits, fig, cherry, spice, clove coriander, bread, yeast....tastes initially of heavy carbonation, then sweet, then multiple fruits especially cherry, finishing slightly tart...mouth feel is quite light, partly carbonation, partly alcohol. The finish is the best part of this ale.

Bottle  - in the actual abbey in Belgium, and here as well from local retailer. I initially tried the beer in Belgium with out knowing much about trappist beer - just a lucky connection with a friend who knew a monk at the abbey. The initial experience was amazing. Dark brown pour with a nice head. Complex aroma with caramel and malt. Great mouth feel, and great finish. At the time, the best beer I had ever tried, hands down. Bottles here have not produced the same "nirvana" feeling, but a great beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2009 Botle 33cl. A very good trappist beer. It smells quite the same as the Rochefort 10 but with less alccol. Personally I prefer to get them young, more sweet. Once old the taste is more acid. Very complex aroma, taste is sweet with fruits and a bit of caramel. Anyway its a great beer.

Pours a dark brown with lots of sediment and thick tan head.  Aroma of dried fruits and roasted malt.  Flavor is strong with a warmth, almost too complex to describe, but Ill try.  I taste the raisins and dates, the chocolate, and a slight sweetness with a lot of alcohol warmth, but no alcohol taste.  Definitely a beer worth having again.
Bottle at Café Gollem, Amsterdam, 14th March 09. Cloudy reddish amber. Rich, warm malts and a lovely finish.

330ml bottle, dated L230512.  Pours a robust and dense dark brown, with a thick and creamy two finger head with plenty of carbonation.  Has a strong, sweet smell of raisins, dates, and dark sugars with a hint of molasses.  A slightly acidic smell with little alcohol and a nice spice factor, as well.  Tastes of dark fruits and rich spices.  Has a malty sweetness with a slightly bitter smooth finish.  The alchohol is well hidden for its higher content.  An all around wonderful beer.

Bottled 11.2oz. Malty, sweet, aroma with notes of raisins and dark fruits in general, and some hints of citrus fruits. Malty, sweet taste with notes of plums, raisins and citrus fruits. Ends Medium- to full bodied. nice ballance but it hits hard with the alcohol at the end.

Pours darkish brown, large foamy head.  Im a bit sick at the moment, so my nose is not functioning optimally.  What I could detect was sweetish with perhaps a little dark fruit appearing around the edges.  Taste is fairly standard for Belgians similar to this, which is always a good thing.  Delicious beer, which Ill have to try again when Im fully able to appreciate it.

Ill quantify this description by being open about my "beer novice" status.  However, when my novitiate introductions to "good beer" are limited to Belgians (i.e. Chimay Blue) and the like, I think Im doing okay.  I excitedly imbibed Rochefort 8s in Cleveland (at Melt Bar and Grilled, where they also have 10s available) this past St. Patricks Day, having heard legends and tales about these beers from Ratebeer, Beeradvocate, and elsewhere.  I wasnt disappointed.  Served in its intended glass, the 8s aroma instantly whispered of rich darkness, fruit undertones, and a syrupy alcohol burn (all of which were enhanced when I took my first sip of the dark, reddish-brown elixir).  An initial burst of effervessence, quickly tapering off into a smooth, lasting alcohol burn that, while present, didnt distract or delay the other flavors - dark fruits, dark sugars, caramels, and an overall sense of depth and complexity.  A head that lingered without being overly frothy.  While I enjoy my Chimay, this took the experience of that beer and amplified its awesomeness to a further degree.  A truly delicious beer, which I understand to be a weakling in wonder next to its older, 10 brother.  I cant wait to venture forth into further Rochefort experiences.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy brown with a big beige/light brown head. Aroma is hops with a bitterness which doesnt feel like its coming from the hops. Hay. Candy-like notes as it warms as well as a more distinct hop notes. Flavour is bitter citrus hops with malty/fruity notes. The hops and malt seems to have a small battle for supremacy going on, but it makes for a nice effect. Spicy and liquorice notes.. Finish is bitter liquorice. Remotely grainy, dry and a bit fruity. Feels a bit cloying. Creamy/milky notes as it warms. A bit too much carbonation. A nice beer, but I think it lacks something. Could be more potent in the flavour maybe. Also, should be less cloying. 16-03-09.

Nice pour!  Brown Tea color, with a nice big head and good lace. Aroma of tobacco, raisons, licorice, tea leaf, and hints of chocolate and coffee.  Subtle flavor compared to the nose. Definite licorice spice, almost mint!  Starts off with subtle dark fruits, raisons, moving to licorice and sarsaparilla root! This melds into a hint of peppermint leaves finishing with white tea and candy sugar! What a journey!

33cl bottle @home
Bought @ systembolaget, Örebro, Sweden
Cloudy, nice head,  a lot of taste.
Bottle. Apperance; dark brown with some yeast in it. nice head. Aroma; Very nice fruity with a nice fruity flavour, but not as much as the aroma. Want one more please.
bottle..brown..i believe 10s are alot better.. kinda a tough drink compared to 10.. solid flavoured throughout though..bitter end

Date: 26/2/09
Beer info: Bottled in brown 330ml bottle 9.2% abv BB 25 09 13

Sampling Notes:
Served lightly chilled in chalice.
Pours pretty much perfectly! Dense rocky pale tan head atop a murky, effervescent, chunk-laden, deep mahogany body.
Interesting and deeply complex nose; plenty of earthy spice in the foreground, clove, cinnamon, pepper, possibly even nutmeg! Has a citrus zestiness about it, a tobacco leafiness too, leading onto more malt driven aromatics of brown sugar and bread/cookie dough. Faint vinous red/black fruits emerge with warmth.
Lucious velvet-like texture, length is very good maybe not as much as the 10, low creamy carbonation. Body dries out eventually but very well hidden alcohol.
Fruit cake-like body, with all of the trimmings! Brown sugar, dough, almonds, clove and cinamon, brandy, sultana, dark cherries and blackberry, a bit of lime and bitter citrus rind seems to lift the palate. Goes down warming, somehow the alcohol alludes all other perception. Lingering dryness with a mishmash of flavours once again reminding me of fruit cake.
Once again a ridiculously complex beer from those crazy monks at Rochefort. Definately need this one to breath and warm up a bit before tasting, it smooths out and becomes far more coherent...and delicious.

(12 oz btl) Poured dark amber w/ a fine off-white head.  Lively carbonation kept head around for some time.  Due to a lousy, pour, had lots of large yeast particles.  Aroma primarily phenolic (cinnamon, clove, allspice) w/ a hint of apple.  Malt is toasty w/ hops lending a peppery earthiness.  Finishes w/ green apple.  Slightly metallic.  Fizz adds a little harshness to the warming alcohol.  Rather crisp and finishes on the drier side.  Not as complex as I expected and somewhat watery.
Bottle.  It is almost identical to the Rochefort 10. Smells of fig and plum, maybe some apple. Very well balanced beer. Better then the 6 weaker then the 10.
very enjoyable nice chocolate fruity aroma and flavour easy to drink but still light alc. taste. great beer...

This was my birthday treat.  Amazing. Layers and layers of flavor, chocolate, nuts, dried fruits, and a touch of licorice. Finishes with an alcohol tinged yeastiness.  The finish is nice and long and very warming. Great for a cold night!  Near perfect.
Pours dark brown with a nice head.  Fruity and chocolatey aroma and flavor.  Great beer.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2017 ((((((( ... The   Sun and the Moon  fuck   every time someone drinks a Rochefort 8. ..Pour  this into  its own  goblet glass  ....    float away somewhere sublime and never come back !!!.

Served on 2/24/09 in 400ml Czech Pilsner @ 35 F.  This beer is very smooth, right below the Rochefort 10.  I would say its just under the 10.  Aroma of hay, grass, herbs.  Appearance medium/light brown, very pronounced frothy head, light sweet, no bitter, light body, thin texture, avearge carbonation, long finish and extremely smooth.  Top beer in my books.

I had been drinking Lite all day and wanted something good. Found this at Milltown. Poured from bottle into signature bulb-type glass. Deep brown in color with flavors of brown sugar, and maybe fig or prune. Very rich but not overly so. So good, I will have to try the 10 when its available.

My first rating at ratebeer. The overall experience from this beer was a suprise. Allot better then I first remembered. The colour is a dark brown colour which I cant see through. Lots of delicious foam that has an excellent malty smell. The first taste was very deep and lots of different spices. Chocolate and cognac first comes to mind. The aroma is deep and round and feels great on the tongue picking up different tastes. However after a couple of moutfulls I realise there is something missing to bring out that perfect score. All in all though a briliant beer! I got the 10 in the fridge, I really hope its as good as this one.

Abundence of aromas including chocolate, a bready roasted malt, and a beerish chewiness smell.
Cloudy dark broth color and had dark brown sediment at the bottom of the bottle. The off white head dissipated to nothing.
A chewy chocolate roasted malt taste and has an alcohol flavor and warming thoughout.
Close to full bodied, resinous, and has crisp carbonation.
This is like a good winter warmer, Belgian style.

Lots of creamy foam overdark amber cloudy beer. Aroma of bittersweet chocolate and cognac with a bit of pepper. Sweet malts and alcohol with just enough hops to make it fly. Rally very subtle candied fruit, licorice and gin. Every sip is better than the last. Velvetymouthfeel and the finish is licorice that tapers very smoothly I would make this my favorite of the 3

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 Colore marrone scuro con la schiuma marrone chiaro.Gusto potente,al palato percepisco un sentore di caramello e frutta,e ha un buon equilibrio di dolce e di amaro.Una belga superiore alla media che è già altissima e una birra tra le mie favorite di sempre.

Bottle.  Pour was a rich dark amber brown with thick one inch carbonation.  Aroma was very malty sweet with  tons of candi sugar.  Flavor was also malty, niutty with some pleasant yeast funk on the aftertaste.  A very good beer!

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a minimal off-white head.  Smells like grapes or cherries, very appealing.  Incredibly smooth taste, chocolate covered cherries comes to mind.  If I had to guess I would put this at 1/2 the alcohol content that it actually is.  This is a tasty beer.   I cant wait for the 10 thats sitting in my fridge!

I enjoyed the 10 more than the 8, but this beer is probably more approachable.  The tan head was not as thick as I had anticipated.  Very smooth and thick like one would expect of a Belgian ale.  The high alcohol content was apparent only from the label as the strong flavors hid it well.

(Bottle 330ml) poured into a goblet, hazy deep amber near brown, with a tan had that sticks around, nicely effervescent.

Aroma is earthy, grainy, sweet dark brown caramelized sugar and molasses, sour berries and cherries some rum and brandy like character.

Flavor is deep, faint vanillas and chocolates with sour cherry, peppery floral alcohol.  Hints of coffee and cream.  

Mouthfeel is perfection for a belgian, medium full, yet dry with a combined effervescence from bottle conditioning and alcohol.  

A top notch belgian and overall excellent beer.

(Bottle 330ml) Poured cloudy reddish brown.  Beige creamy head nearly vanished.  Great sour cherry/black forest nose.  Body and nose malty.  Brandylike, fruity flavor, almost kirschwasser finish.  Very complex mouthful of ale.  Excellent beer.

Bottled (0,33) 2008. Colour is cloudy brown,  quite a lot carbon, short lived head was creamy and brown. Aroma is sweetish, dark. Taste has toffee, and faint layers of fruits, berries and alcohol in it, all nicely balanced. Aftertaste is long, but pretty mild.

Smell of ripe dark fruits, figs, raisins.  A bit of phenols.  Pours a very dark amber, with an off-white head that clings to the glass in patches.  Taste is complex, ripe dark fruits, rock candy, malty, hiding the 9.2% ABV very well.    Love this beer!

Very good, but still far inferior to the Rochefort 10. Not nearly as complex or intense flavors. Dark brown color with a beige head.  Aroma of candi sugar, dark fruits, sweet malt, and yeast.  Similar to the others in the series flavor-wise: dark fruits, brown sugar, creamy malt, and of course alcohol.  Really smooth and fairly full on the palate.

Dark brown with light tan foam. For me this beer has everything I like, a powerful taste, some fruits and caramel feel, and a good ballance of sweet and bitter and sour, but not too much. 
this is one of my favorite beer
alcohol, bread, caramel, semidark,clear, rocky head, frothy, white foam, very bitter, medium sweetness, full body, slick feel, thick feel, famous beer
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: Ok, yeah so I finally purchased a full bottle of this stuff. Lovely muddy brown color with a bubbly light brown head. Wonderfully strong aroma: fruits, yeast, and happiness. The taste of the beer is mildly dry with a bunch of fruit flavours. Not sweet, well maybe a little... more spicy than anything. Medium bodied. Hops are subtle. Mild bitterness. Very smooth and alcohol is not detectable. Quite good, but obviously so.

Pours a dark caramel brown with slightly greenish tan highlights, lots of smallish tan yeast particulates and a 2 finger creamy tan head that has sort of poor retention. Aroma is caramel, plum, gorgonzola, cola, lemon, herbal and grassy hops. Flavor is caramel, toast, yeasty bread, plum, overripe oranges, white grapes, earthy moss like notes,  grass, a little white teaand a touch of licorice. FInish is clean even though it is a little yeasty, comes off as slightly spicy and salty with an herbal hop character. Body is medium thickness, and slightly sweet with a fairly dry finish, hides 9.2%abv very well. My only possibly gripe about this beer is that it is slightly over carbonated, though without that it may be too thick and alcoholic. Fantastic stuff really.
33cl bottle good strong taste rich fruitiness touches of chocolate and strong alcohol flavour taste light and easy to drink very good beer
Pours an unappealing cloudy brown with small head that dissipates almost immediately. Aroma is of yeast and apricot. I found the flavor to be unbalanced with too much sweetness and alcohol presence.

I only had very small pour of this one from the end of the bottle.  I got a bunch of globs of yeast in the hazy brown beer with a decent amount of tan head.  The aroma is heavy heavy of caramel with a bit of apricot, cheese, gooseberry, and long leaf teas.  The flavor is similar to the smell - very strong in caramel and dark fruit.  The Rochefort "harmony" is again present.  The mouthfeel is a bit thin for such a sweet beer.  Id like to try this one again - I wasnt as impressed with this as with the Rochefort 6.

This Abbey ale has a subdued aroma, is slightly sweet up front, rich in the middle, and slightly spicy hoppy in the finish. It has complex, aged and balanced flavor, with dried fruits, vanilla, figs, and even, dare I say it, slight cola.

I really tried to like this. But....rough pour into snifter gave this a huge frothy white head. Otherwise looks like brown poopwater. Sweetness and maybe some spice or bread on a rough swirl but not very much here. Creamy carbonated mouthfeel but not a whole lot in the flavor depot either. Finishes dry. Seems simple. It is nice and warming and kind of creeps up. ABV invisible.

Very dark but still obviously brown a small but lively off white head that seems to refresh itself constantly. 
  Rich and fruity aromas pervade through roasty malts. Raisins and black grapes.  With a light smokiness through hints of brown spirits. 
 Heavy dark malty flavours with great fruity notes.  Robust fruit like guava or something of that sort.  Very deep and complex. 
  A little fizzy but smooth, thick and heady. 
Very boozy but a great beer. Deep flavours, exquisitely crafted.
Bottle. Hazy brown body with a small off-white head. Aroma is dark fruits and spices. Taste is burned sugar/caramel, dark fruits, yeast. Alcohol is well hidden.
Hazy lightbrown coloured beer (poored in with some yeast) Medium off-white. A sweet yeasty aroma bit roasted and herby. Full sweeter palate. Finish is bitter sweet, (hints of caramel). Top beer.

Bottle black in color, good one finger head. Aroma of dark fruits and some spices. Also some yeasty earth aromas as well. Taste is a little spice, fruit, maybe a light touch of chocolate. Once it hits your tounge, lots of small carbonation bubbles come alive. Unique texture.... still creamy smooth. Alcohol is hidden well. Overall a good beer.

33cl bottle. A murky, reddened mahogany coloured Trappist with obvious sediment and a bubbly, quickly dissipating head. Plummy, red berry aromas with a background of alcohol. Dried fruit aromas with a bready quality amidst plenty of red berry notes and a noticeable alcohol content.. The finish gives a lasting sweetness with a whiskey-like bitterness. A light and sparkling palatte texture with a warming feeling in the throat.

Bottle.A muddy brown color pour with lively carbonation and a two finger offwhite head.Aroma of wine grapes,cherries apples and oaky vanilla.Flavor is dry and fruity at the start,as it warms you get more of the sweet side of the malt,some brown sugar and a touch of peppery spice.A crisp mouthfeel. Very good !

12oz bottle, nice turbid and cloudy brown color with a puffy head,. Smells malty, some spice but not much. The taste is unlike almost any other beer I have had, so strange. Gummy, spicy, malts, Dr. Pepper. Quite different but Im not sure its my thing. The alcohol is well hidden which makes it quite easy to make it through the glass.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-04-2009 03:49:06

Sweet malty aroma, pours a coppery brown with a tall river-pollution looking head. Im thinking this one has been filtered through a chain link fence. Lots of particulates in there. Slighty fruity flavor with notes of dark fruits and lighter fruits such as apricots, figs, prunes and some peach. Mild hints of spice like nutmeg and perhaps coriander.
Finishes well with a slightly sticky palate. pretty good  Belgian.

Pours a nice deep brown with a creamy, tan head. Some floaties in there. Roasty, sweet malt nose. Some yeast, some chocolate powder, some fruit. Flavor is complex and fruity, lots of dried and dark fruits, and great belgian yeast character. Creamy, well-carbonated palate. A bit of spice in the finish. Alcohol is not detectable and its very drinkable for 9%.
Inga kommentarer för tillfället. Inga kommentarer för tillfället. Inga kommentarer för tillfället.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2014 Served in a Chimay glass, actually I thought I had a Rochefort glass, but I couldnt find it. Consume date is 2013, I have to buy another bottle to to age, it sure will get better. Dense and creamy brown head that to my surprise faded too soon, with a lot of floaties. Hazy brown colour. Aroma: cocoa, figs, raisins, barrel aged wine, plums, vanilla. Mouthfeel is just warmness, like a brandy. Taste:complex, its different with every sip, figs, apricots, cocoa, vanilla. Hard to say everything that goes on in this beer.

Dark amber/red with a tan head that turns low, dense and fluffy.
Absolutely beautiful, complex nose. Milk chocolate and roasted coffee malt with raisin, maple syrup and pine. A leathery yeast is prominent, and the perfectly strong alcohol carries all these flavours to each corner of your skull. The aroma is almost a meal in itself! 
The flavours are simply amazing. That obvious leathery yeast with raisin and caramel. There is a spiciness of pepper and aniseed that tingles the lips.
Rich toffee flavours mix with the roast malt and mild coffee to make milk chocolate. 
Very full bodied, and the alcohol and spice give it that glorious, warm finish. Awesome.
Not my favorite of the Trappist, but the 8 is the best among the Rochefort herd.  This beer is a little too sweet for my taste.  Not a bad beer, but not a must try!!

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2009 [330ml bottle liberated from Belgium by Lee - cheers mate!] Pours deep red-brown with a rather dirty beige frothy head. The moderate carbonation is irritating and really doesnt suit the style. Smells of chocolate, port and some metal.  Fortunately the metal doesnt carry through into the flavour, which is raisins, chocolate, banana and port.  Despite the strength, these flavours are not wiped out by an alcohol burn - this is a well balanced beer.  Despite the too-high carbonation, it is actually incredibly smooth to drink.  The sweetness does get a little sticky by the end, and it could do with a little spice or bitterness to cut through it.  Nevertheless, it is a very good beer - but it still falls short of some of the rave reviews it has received here.

bottled. Nice dark cloudy brown color, with a nice tan head, but goes fast and keep a nice lace until finish. Aroma is sweet with notes of nuts and chocolate. Flavor is pretty much the same just with some bitterness. Mouthfeel is dry and bitter letting a bitter sweety flavor..

Bottle.  Pours a solid dark mahogany color with lots of yeast particles.  I tried to avoid pouring the sediment into the glass but had no such luck.  Thin beige head.  Light aroma of yeast, fruit, and some buttermilk biscuits.  Flavor is dark berries, dried fruit, yams, squash, and a little alcohol.  Medium bodied with a dry aftertaste.

Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Sweet aroma of malt, toffee, dried fruit and spices. Pleasant complex flavours of malts, spices and dark fruits. The alcohol is hidden well. Warm and bitter finish. This is a sensational beer.

Bottle from Binnys in Willowbrook, IL.  Pour produced a opaque nut-brown body with loads of sediment.  Hints of alcohol in the nose, along with some dried fruit.  Heavy mouthfeel, with a sweetness that fortells the alcohol warmness at the end.  Palate is fruity with caramel notes, followed by faint, bitter aftertaste.  As for the alcohol, it is evident, though not annoyingly so.  I think this is fine, and will keep you through a winter night, though I guess I set my expectations too high.

Bottle from Sandbar, Manchester.  Dark opaque mahogany colour, so dense that light doesnt penetrate, with a thin coffee coloured head.  Aroma only hints at the alcohol and is mainly rich fruit - figs, raisins and a touch of banana.  Huge flavours - figs and raisins again, apricot and mango with chocolate and muscovado maltiness all overlain with a lovely touch of vanilla.  A subtle touch of spice comes through in the long finish.  Wonderfully smooth on the palate, the creamy smoothness completely masks the high alcohol content.  A beautiful experience and is far from overshadowed by its big brother.
UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009 Silky smooth. Creamy head settles and lasts throughout. Alcohol hidden well. The fruit flavours are rich, intense and delicious. Luvvly Jubbly.

Bottle. Somehow I never rated it until now even though it is one of my favorites. Pours with a brown color and a medium head. Aromas of mainly dark fruit and prunes or figs. Flavor is very nutty, with caramel.
Nice medium body with just the right carbonation. Wonderful beer, goes excellent wiht strong cheeses.
&#40;Bottle&#41; Flawed sample though the the bb date is sometime in 2012. Pours brown with rough head. Aroma is caramel and flavour ditto with some alcohol. Sadlly Nothing more.

Murky brown cloured beer with some yeast particles floating. The head medium sized, firm and beige in colour. The aroma.. Where would i begin? It´s vinous, sweet like a port. Almost wine gum-like. Definately there are fruits: I found at least apricot and prunes. Lovely vanilla scent is clear when this gets warmer. Less nutty in the finish than the big brother, but there still is some. There´s plenty of malts, maybe honey and a floral and slightly spicy hopping. And some alcohol. The flavor is sweetish from malts but not like caramel, but more like ripe fruits. The finish is long and  bitterish with balancing fruitness and some spices. The alcohol is present all the way but its fits the picture. The palate is medium to full bodied, smooth like silk and a bit sticky in the finish. Aclohol is totally absent, which make it also deviously easy to drink. R8 is a very rich, complex and tasty beer without being too hard or mysterious.

Pours a dark murky brown with some floaties this time.  Slight boozy flavor but not overpowering. I wish I didnt have a cold because it is really effecting my senses. Dark fruits, raisin plum, caramel and malt. Relatively mild for 9.2 ABV.

Bottle. Dark brown bit hazy body with a medium off-white head. Lots of overripe fruit, spices and malt in aroma. Flavour is prunes, raisins, oak, caramel and lots of malt. Bit alcoholic feeling in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 Id had this a few times and it had never lived up to my expectations. Seemed like they didnt travel well. Clearly i was wrong! This one was in perfect condition!

BB:29/04/13
Pours murky, red/brown with 2 fingers of off-white head that persists for the duration. Aromas of caramel, honey and dark fruits as well as a slight hint of chocolate. Palate has great depth, sweet bread, nuts, caramel, figs and raisins. Despite richness never gets sweet. Has a very creamy mouthfeel.
Finishes with low hop bitterness. Great length due to abv spice and earthy yeast charcters. Subtle, balanced and super complex.

Smells heavily of bread, apple, peach when I open the bottle, sticking my nose in the glass is much subtler fruit some dried fig, vanilla, cotton candy. It really teases the nose with a just-out-of-reach sweetness. Pour is brown  opaque with a quick settling creamy  head, slight lacing with beautifully dense bubbles. Very fine carbonation like a good champagne. Tangy on tongue with lots of lemon-lime citrus flavor and slight toasted malt. Again there is a teasing sweetness, cotton candy and tropical fruit but not quite. Each sip is refreshing a light but with a proper finish. I can see why this is rated so highly really a delightful beer.

Takes me back to a time where this, Westy, and La Trappe were the main beers to buy at the Sharp Edge...  Anyway, pours a muddy brown color, complete with suspended yeast particles, small tan head.  Big aroma, cherries, dark fruit, bready yeast.  Perfect mouthfeel, not too thick, nicely carobnated.  Tasty, spiced, nutty, lots of malt, touch of cola.  Biting, mildly funky finish.  A standout beer.

Smooth aroma of figs, vanilla, bubble gum, yeast.  Dark brown pour with plenty of sediment left in the bottle.  Huge creamy head.  Hugely complex taste of brown sugar, chocolate, dark fruit, again the bubble gum, vanilla.  Perfect palate, as smooth and full as you could ever want.  The alcohol is present and warming.  Just a tad bitter in the followthrough.  I am totally impressed.

Bottle served in a trappist glass. Effervescent dark amber liquid topped by a dense off-white head. Smells of raisins, warm vanilla, brown sugar. Taste of spices, some fruit, alcohol. Tastes nothing like it smells which is a bit disappointing. Warmth and dryness is created by the alcohol. The carbonation is very prickly, it almost stings a little. Interesting and different, but I think I would have liked it more if it tasted the way it smelled.
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2010 Dark plum color, light tan head.  Big mouth, full taste of malt with raisins and berries.  Bittersweet finish.  A classic.

Bottle.  Poured into a chimay glass.  Pours a dark purple/brown with a lasting off white head.  Aromas of dark fruits, cherries, plums, raisins, and some heat from the alcohol.  Flavors is rich dark fruits, spice, yeast, alcohol.  Very nice carbonation.
Pour a nice dark brownish/red with a long-lasting tall off-white head. Nice aroma and flavour of dried fruits, caramel, chocolate, malts and yeast. Definately deserves its high rating.

Warm. Brown/dark amber with lasting head.  Caramel port wine woodsy earthy aroma with a tiny hint of alcohol.   Toasted caramel spicy yeasty port earth and wood flavors with a hint of mint.  Medium body and medium/medium-high carbo.  Beautiful soft mouthfeel probably because it’s room temp.  Deliciously complex.

reddish brown with an offwhite head 
nice hazyness
smells malty, fruity and of some hidden dried raisins
tasts fruity ( dried raisins) and malty, and even a bit of hidden nuts and has some warm alcohol
aftertaste fruit malt bittersweetness, warmth
a really, really good beer but i prefer the rochefort 10

Poured hazy amber brown with some biege head which lasted. Aroma is mainly fruity, predominantly raisins, with interesting flowery and yeasty hints balanced with maybe a touch of alcohol harshness. The palate is wonderful, medium to full bodied with plenty of light fluffy champagne-like carbonation. The flavour is rich and complex; agian dark fruits, raisins, dominate but there are other softer and sharper fruity flavours combined with dark malt and some subtle alcohol bite leading on to some pleasant bitterness but a long complex fruity finish. Overall an excellent complex beer, but not a session beer.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 Pours a hazy dark brown with some yeast sediment and a giant, thick, off-white head that dwindles down. Aroma is yeast, alcohol, and not much else. It is difficult to really get a specific flavor out of this- maybe flowers and cotton candy but overall very muted. Taste has a lot of brown sugar, dark fruits, spice, and warming alcohol. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Very dry and alcoholic aftertaste- like a gin and tonic. Very complex and excellent.
Bottle pours hazy brown/red. Aroma is sweet. First taste is sweet dark fruits with alcohol hidden very well. Really like this one and compare it to chimay.
A great beer as expected.  Any beer from these monks is a delight. This was malty as they come. very much a sipper

Bottle at Pub Italia in Ottawa. Deep grape-like colour, with a slight beige head. Can only fault the head for not being as large as I expected. Otherwise a beauty. Excellent flowery nose. Intricate flavours rush the mouth as you taste. Floral grape, sweet malt, other assorted fruits, quite an incredible rush. Finishes surprisingly clean but ale-like. A wonderful experience.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Yup.  Darkness  fruits.  Plums, prunes, yums, and awesomeness.  Apples, apricot, honey maybe?  Complex and badass.

bottle thanks to bhops.  deep brown pour with a nice cream head.  nice nose of malts, grapes, syrup and chocolate.  quite easy on the palate with a fruity, malty flavor and a highly carbonated finish.
Pours a hazy dark brown color with a nice active tan head. Aroma of malts and fruits. The flavour is sweet, malt, apple, yeast and raisin. Very smooth and well-balanced. Outstanding.

Bottle. Cloudy dark maroon color with a forever lasting big white head. Overwhelming nose of raisins, plums, yeast, and black licorice. There’s far less flavor than aroma as it comes across delightfully smooth and sharp with a hot finish. Not the biggest flavor for a Belgian strong, but a delicious one with a warming, sticky finish.

Bottle, BB 09.07.13. Dark brown colour with a foamy, lasting tan head. Aroma of malts and fruits. The flavour is sweet, malt, apple, yeast and raisin. Very smooth and well-balanced. Alcohol is hidden well, but has still a nice warming aftertaste. Medium-bodied and not much bitterness. Very tasty and complex brew.

Pours a hazy dark brown color with a nice active tan head. Aroma is candi-sugar, belgian yeast, bread, rasins, dark fruits. Flavor is molasses, vanilla, yeast, fruit, rasins, caramel, spices. Lots going on in this beer, it’s hard to pinpoint everything. Outstanding.

Very cloud orange/brown pour.  Aromas of varied malts, fruit, slight alcohol.  Rather yeasty, but not in a bad way.  Malt, raisin, bread flavors, solid medium body.  Very clean finishing.  I really don’t care for very many Belgians, mainly because I find them WAY overcarbonated and closer to champaigne than beer.  This one however, was excellent and closer to an old ale style.  Though I do prefer the 10.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Getting notebook online. Bottle. Lots of yeast, fruit, and spice flavors. Very warming mouth.

Aroma is sweet fruit - raisins and plums. Pours a thin, dark brown with little head. High carbonation, very bubbly and lively on the tongue. Taste is the same sweet fruit plus a cereal malt note,bread, yeast, and a touch of  stout-like roastiness. Almost tastes like cherry cola. There are so many layers of flavor in this beer and all are subtle. Alcohol is well-hidden. Little to no hoppy bitterness. Very short finish with no aftertaste. Thin body. Good, and remarkably drinkable for its ABV.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2014 I have seen and heard a lot about this beer but was somewhat skeptical. Usually the highly rated Belgians are flat beers full of alcohol, thin and cola tasting. This was definitely not the case with this beer. There was a good amount of carbonation, a healthy head and an opaque cherry wood hue. The smell was a spicy carrot cake and the initial flavor was sweet molasses and ginger. The aftertaste wasnt lingering or alcohol laden for a beer of over 9% ABV. Caramel and syrup gradually became more apparent, almost the palate of malt extract, very delicious. This is one of the most complex, varied beers Ive tried. Looking forward to the 10.

Dark brown color with a foamy off-white head. Rich and complex aroma with brown sugar, caramel, raisin, vanilla and a finishing touch of sweet liquor alcohol. Fresh spicy and very interesting flavor with combinations of vanilla, liquorice, herbs and a sweetness from dried fruit finishing with a alcohol warmth. Mouthfeel is full, thick and quite strongly carbonated. Didn´t want the bottle to finish that fast...

330ml from Forest City in CT.  Settles a dark brown chestnut with a pearly beige head.  Aroma of barley, grapes, dry wine, and bread.  Palate has a nice substantial thickness to it, complemented by prickly carbonation.  Upon sipping, I immediately recognize this is a beer about subtlety:  unlike most other beers of this ABV, Rocheforts flavors are content to simmer, hint, and layer.  Consequently, it is hard for me to put my finger on what I am tasting.  OK, so there is definitely bread, brown sugar, and dried fruit.  But there is much more.  I can see where people are getting cherry and vanilla notes from the body.  By half way through the bottle, I had begun treating this beer more like an Old Ale or Barley Wine.  It is earthy, old, and mellow.  Notably, if you give Rochefort time to sit, it responds by revealing all of its character.  My opinion:  tasty, but not on par with the RB rating.

330m Bottle:  Sweet aroma of fruit, berries, caramel, malts, dried fruit, light alcohol, and light chocolate.  Poured brown in color with a medium-sized, tan head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Many particles.  Sparkling.  Medium sweet flavor.  Tastes of malts, dried fruit, beef, sesame, spices, and a hint of yeast.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Sweet, malty finish.

It opens with an aroma with hints of dried berries and humid cellar. The flavor is suprisingly fresh considering the high alcohol percentage - although the aftertaste is a tad too sweet for my taste. I truid it along with chocolate, but I prefer it on its own.

Pours dark brown/amber, thick rocky sustained head, aroma of alcohol, dark fruits, currants/dates/raisens, some dishwater.  Flavor is spicy/alcoholic, sweet malts/crystal malts, caramel, dark fruits.  Really nice trappist.

Pours a muddy orange/brown with a head that grows about an inch and then shrinks to about a quarter of an inch and stays there. Aroma is of dark fruits (plums, strawberries) vanilla, and chocolate. Tastes of dark fruit, chocolate, and vanilla. Great ballance of sweet and bitter. Very nice mouth feel. Good beer!
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2008 Dark brown, CO2, sweet, creamy, caramel, roasted malts, dark fruits, vanilla, yeasty, little alcohol, little dark chocolate, little spice.

2 years aged, warm bottle. Dark ruby brown, huge beige head. Very spicy, little soapy nose, pineapple, coconut, herbs and candi sugar. Intensive spicy flavor, liquorice herbs, dark sugar, roasted malts, alcohol burn, little cellar. Medium bodied, strongly carbonated and alcoholic palate.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2013 big creamy off white head, very dense. Colour is very dark ruby. Aroma i yeasty, dark fruit winelike. Flavour is sweet, warming, alcohol, yeastiness, Brown sugar, jam, dried fruits, caramel, hay, slightly earthy.
P: Lively carbonation, medium/full bodied. 
T: good, but no way near the 10.

Rating #250, mini-milestone.  Murky earth brown pour with a heavy building carbonation to lift up a finger of pillowy smooth whitish-tan head with lasting retention and mild collapsing lacing that holds the glass longer than the center of the head.  Aromas of alcohol soaked prunes, cherries, plums, candi sugar, dark pit fruits and dark mahogany and cherry wood highlights.  A light body of maltiness highlighted by candi sugar and hints of cherries.  Very sweet finish with hints of smoothing yeastiness and vanilla.  Retains the bodyand feel but with slightly less taste complexity than the 10, while I feel like the Westy 8 loses too much body along with complexity compared to the 12.

Finally got around to reviewing this beer that i’ve tried so many times before.

Appearance: Dark brown with a thick, impressive lace.

Aroma: Banana marshmallow, raison, alcohol. Yummy!

Flavor: Coffee, malt, liqorice ?, tofee, yeast

Palate: Smooth carbonation and very creamy.

A really complex beer but despite this it goes down very easy. Not as good as its bigger brother but still damn good!

Bottle. Aroma  almost like wine with grapes, raisins and a bit of dark chocolate. Clear dark redbrown colour with nice soft beige head. Flavour very equivalent to the aroma and sweet. Rich carbonation. Well balanced.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 Poured a finger of white head which diminished quickly but left some wonderful lacing. Medium particles were suspended within a gorgeous deep caramel brown body. Smelled of burnt sugar and a light bouquet of flowers, not too strong. The tase was quite above par; an amazing array of fruits and spice that hid the alcohol perfectly. The palate was fizzy and light, the tase lasting nicely. Nice with rasin bread!

BB 12/27/2012...rich copper/woody amber with lots of clumpy yeasties and a soft off white head which deposits some spotty lacing. smells of piloncilla/brown sugar/candy, cooked golden raisins, chocolate, nuts, lots of graininess, spice and grassy/floral hoppiness. lots of spice on the palate makes the alcohol apparent... flavors of cinnamon, flowers/hops, raw sugar, wood and watered down pureed golden raisins with a prickly finish from a high level of carbonation. medium body. as the carbonation settles down it gives a slick texture that coats the tongue. so like westy 8 at this age...
Excelente cerveja, aromas de caramelo, trufa. Encorpada, notas de álcool bem distintas. Pouca espuma.

Pours a reddish dark brown colour with a tan head. Reasonably cloudy and head did not last for as long as I’d anticipated - perhaps due to an average pour. Initially flavour is malty, with fruits and spice to follow, ending with smooth toffee and chocolate flavours. These chocolate and caramel flavours come through stronger as the beer progresses, and the raisin and spice become more subtle. Beautifully smooth for such a complex beer, alcohol well hidden. Lovely and warming on a cold day.

0.33ml, pours a dark brown with a pale beige head.  There is so much yeast in the glass it’s doing backflips with the carbonation.  After a few sips, the head is spotted with the yeast and looks like little specks of cinnamon.  Amazingly complex beer - malt, dark fruits (raisins, cherries, plums), spice, toffee, liquorice... alcohol on the finish.  This is a fantastic beer...

Bottle.  Cloudy brown pour with a fantastic frothy large tan head.  Great lacing.  Aroma of plums, yeast and raisins.  Full taste with caramel, yeast, malt, and dark fruit present.  Nice even but full finish.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Bottle. Hazy black with thick head. Complex flavor, dark and malty but also a (strange) sweet afteraste. Too much carbonation.

300713, 330ml bottle. Light brown thick head which lasts very long. Dark brown color, cloudy. Interesting aroma of berries, spices  and leather. Fizzy and little bit oily palate. Flavours of vegetables, liquorice, some alcohol. Sour.

Bottle, Ale Cellar, Darlington. I’m somewhat surprised by the relative dearth of dissenting voices amidst the sea of universal acclaim which this basks in. Personally, I don’t think this is a patch on the 10. I can appreciate that there is quality here but its just lacking the complexity and depth of its big brother. It could be the licorice element which stands out a little too prominently for me  - I’m not a fan of Licorice at all so points lost there. The slightly menthol/medicinal tang which I detected, also I’m not big on either.
Its good, just a litle disappointing when compared to the 10.

330 ml bottle. Reddish-brown color, huge tan head. Slightly yeasty, medicinal aroma with alcohol and hops. Big taste with a touch of chocolate, herbal hops and warming alcohol and a glowing malty finish. Prickly carbonation, full body. Very complex and quite nice.

Rich burgundy color under a billowy, buff head.  Warm alcohol nose, full of spice and dark berries, acrid and phenolic, sweet caramel.  Mild toffee sweetness, smooth but full acidity, menthol and alcohol strong in the finish with an aftertaste of chocolate and licorice.  Creamy, big and fluffy.

Decadent and a bit hotI wonder if those phenols will fade.

33 cl bottle, best before 30 July 2013.

330ml bottle. Marked 300113, 08:02. Pours murky dark brown with a very fizzy head, virtually no head for that matter. Smells of malty sweet plum, nice, clean, sweet, slightly spicy. Tastes fruity sweet with some spicesand malty of course. Plum and some mint and spice. Medium body, fizzy carbonation.

Spicy aroma, the taste is fruit and caramel, very soft and complex. The little brother of rochefort 10 is lighter and easier but still not boring by any means. Too bad it is too expensive here to have on a regular basis as a session companion...
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 Stunning deep amber sedimented pour. Intense caramel start leading on to honey/ caramel/spicy middle and alcoholic and spiced finish. Lovely.

[Bottle] Gusher. Pours a murky brown with lots of floaties and a huge beige head. Aroma is very nice. Figs, raisins, caramel, and banana are some of the more prominent aromas. Thinner mouthfeel than its big brother, and flavor is a little lighter. Still a touch of alcohol in there. Plenty of dark fruits in the flavor, raisins, maybe some spices, and a nice earthiness. Lovin it.

Bottle.  Poured a hazy, moat water brown/green color with a small off white head.  Aroma of spices, raisins and dark fruit.  Flavor was malty with candied sugar, spice and liquorice notes.  Medium body with mild carbonation and a good mouthfeel.
brown and murky. huge beige head. Deliciously spicy. pepper and sweet mild chili.or something..

R8 is foggy reddish brown with a beautiful really great light beige creamy head. Strong sweet aroma of spices, fruits and raisins. Malty, fruity, salty, liquoricy taste. Smooth soft and balanced body. Alcohol is totally hidden.

Rating #100!!! 330mL bottle from regional wines. Pours a dark deep ruby with a fizzy tan head. A strong nose on this one, dominant raisiny fruity aromas, not unlike a barley wine, theres some spice buried under the fruit; probably cinnamon, a bit yeasty smelling too. Sweet fruity raisin flavours drenched in caramel and roasted malt dominate the flavour. This sweetness is balanced perfectly by a light hop bitterness. The caramel and malt sits on your tongue for some time after, begging for another sip of this extraordinary beer. I almost don’t believe the ABV of 9.2% as I don’t detect any flavour of alcohol at all. A simply amazing beer, well deserving of it’s 33rd placing in the Ratebeer top 100!

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2016 creamy offwhite large head. excellent lacing. mostly lasting. reddish-brrown thick muddy body. aroma: heavy roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, alcohol, fresh plum, cachaca from Minas Gerais, wood, toffee. Initial flavor: moderate sweet (mal, red fruits, jam, caramel) and salty hints. Final flavor: light bitter moderate sweet and salty hints. palate: watery/oily texture, lively carbonation, light medium body, moderate alcoholic finish.

July22nd,2013 large frothy light brown head. excellent lacing. fully lasting. flat thick orangeish-brown body. aroma: moderate malty, dark chocolate, orange, earth, alcohol. if and ff: moderate sweet light bitter; long duration. palate: medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, metallic light alcoholic finish. delicado dulçor achocolatado e maltado, disfarça bem o alcool, o dulçor traz também a leve presença de laranja no background, 140 s

9/23/09:essa Belgian Strong Ale belga é um dos maiores ícones do estilo. Despejada no copo, já expõe ótima aparência. Sua espuma inicial é pequena, de coloração marrom-claro e moderada formação de colarinho. A longevidade é reduzida e seu corpo é opaco, de tonalidade castanha. O aroma também é delicioso. Farejam-se notas de chocolate escuro, trufas e uva-passa. Seu sabor inicial é levemente amargo e salgado, sensação esta última que se mantém no final, de média duração. No paladar, convivem um corpo médio-leve, de textura aguada, carbonatação suave e final metálico e levemente adstringente - nota-se ainda uma certa dormência na língua.

Bottle best by date is 3.23.2010. Hazy light brown with a frothy tan head. Estery aromas of grape juice, cherry. Light/medium body. Relatively weak flavors of rootbeer spice with earthy caramel and sweet rye bread. Nice flavor just not enough of it.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: SEP 5, 2012 (bottle) pours a hazy ruby-brown colour with a frothy light beige head. aroma of figs and dates, raisins, sweet spices, heavy gletschereis bonbons, caramel and dark fruit, with a hint of alcohol and dark bread. flavour is mostly the same, though the spices are slightly subdued, with dominant notes of caramel, lightly roasted mellow malts, yeasty cake dough, herbs, bubble-gum and dried fruit, alcohol is not detectable. medium-bodied with fizzy carbonation.

Almost as good as the 10, brighter and more lively with an amazing aroma of bananas and complex malt layers. Often a very fizzy, slightly agressive body but with a unique mind blowing finish. Bright and at the same time complex with loads of character. The beer that converted me to.. beer.

bottle thanks to DrHomolka.  Pours a dark brown with a large tan head which produced good lacing.  The nose on this was funky.  Smelled like dirty socks.  Not sure if this is supposed to be this way or this has gone bad.  Yucky smell.  Taste was not much better, but at least drinkable.  It tasted funky and hard to pinpoint.  Mouthfeel was medium with lots of carbonation and some alcohol warmth.  Will try another to re-rate in the near future.

Pours a dirty plum color from the bottle with a soapy light tan head of foam and MASSIVE sediment.  Smells like a medicine cabinet and tastes of anise, raisins, pears, and rubbing alcohol.  Bitters as it warms.  Complex and agressive, but not nearly as drinkable as the 10 in my opinion.

Pours a deep opaque brown with slight off-white head. Sediment is noticeable in the bottom of the glass. Nose is very mild: slightly malty. Flavor is of hops and something else that I cannot put my finger on. Finishes relatively clean. Not too shabby.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Dark, cloudy brown with lost of yeast sediment. Small head that perdures. Aromas of dark fruit and roasted malt that lingers. Notes of dark fruit with slight alcohol aftertaste. Very fizzy. As good as it’s father. A+

On draft at A La Mort Subite and from the bottle purchased at Cheesy in Prague. (Damn that’s a stupid name.) On draft, obvious sediment; from the bottle the first half-glass pours a clear dark amber with a Persian carpet of lightest beige on top. The nose has notes of stewed oranges, wine reduction, but also something bready pulled straight out of the walk-in. In the mouth, candied fruits dusted in cocoa. My notebook from the tasting at Mort Subite reads: "Dark choc.-scented alc.; inhale, exhale x2  still tasting the fruit (peach, orange, coconut  am I just thinking fruit salad & Grandma?) Sediment in the bottom of the goblet." I wanted to say I like this better than Rochefort 10, but then again I’m an idiot. It’s still pretty good though.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours a dark clear brown colour with a good size head, that lasts.
Very complex smell that I can’t specifically put my finger on, noneless it’s brilliant.
Flavour also very nice, can pick out raisins, pineapple and pear, but I tasted the beer too cold so I could be mistaking here.
Goes down great, no trace of the alcohol, definitly one of my favorites!
Pours a murky brown color with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of fruits and malt.  Tastes of fruit, spice, malt with a bit of alcohol in the finish.

Had this beer many times, this stuff just keeps amazing me. Pours very deep dark brown, like dark chocolate, with a creamy beige head. Aroma is imo the only "flaw", it could have been stronger. Subtle aroma of dark fruits, mostly malts and dark chocolate, some alcohol. Flavour is soft, malts, lots of dark chocolate, some dark fruits and a bit of alcohol. The beauty of this beer is that you don’t have to work your way through a load of sugary sweetness like with so many other dark strong ales. Soft and creamy mouthfeel, nice lingering finish, full bodied.
bottle 33cl, aroma of figs, fruity, the peel of oranges, look darkbrown, the taste of fondant chocolate, a bit sugary
Well balanced and very complex taste of raisen and caramel.  A little too much carbonation for my taste, but that is the style.

330 mL bottle.  Pours red brown with a small white head.  Aromas of dark fruits, caramel, hint of alcohol.  Flavor is a combination of caramel and dark fruit with touches of black licorice, bread, hops, and apple.  Raisin finish.  Excellent flavor profile, very enjoyable.  A little better than my recollection of Rochefort 10.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Poured a dark coffee brown with a small tan head.  Smelled of brown sugar, rice, and smoke, with a hint of banana. The taste was dominated my burnt chocolate and a bit of malt. The mouthfeel was a little more fizzy than I expected, but it worked.
Overall a decent strong ale, but cant stand up to #10, or a handful of better strong ales Ive had recently.
