UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 Cloudy brown, sediment, with big, foamy beige head / Date & caramel nose / Medium to full body, big malts without being cloying, and good finish / Flavors of tobacco, caramel, dates, figs, and milk chocolate / Flavors are a bit cooked, but otherwise very good.

330 ml bottle. Hazy dark brown colour, thick and lasting off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits, apple and sweet malts. Spicy flavour of sweet malts, with alcohol warmth in the finish. Soft and foamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 Awesome dubble.  This is dark and not as sweet as I thought it would be...more of a dark chocolate burnt carmel flavor.  This is a very nice beer I would not mind having more of.  Re-rate, just brought a case home and I’m loving this and it’s awesome complex finish.  So much going on with some dark fruit and dark sugary flavors.  Nice beer!!!

An amazing beer.  Great color with light lacing.  Smells great with low hop aroma.  Warms you up nicely but not as much as the 10.  Well worth drinking if you can’t get the 10 or are looking for something lighter.

Bottle. Much like the description says. It is almost identical to the Rochefort 10. Smells of fig and plum, maybe some apple. Very well balanced beer. Better then the 6 weaker then the 10. Still a great beer and a must try.

Had this in Gent Belgium. The aroma of this beer is very interesting. lots of dark fruits as well as some banana and other spices. The Flavor is similar to the aroma. very fruity but well balanced, This is one of my favorite beers and I always keep a bottle or 2 at home.

I drank this one too fast with my PBnJ, I know that it had notes of candied fruits, baking spices and more..., appearance was perfect with a fine soapy head that lasted for quite some time, dark reddish brown body and fine effers, flavor was awesome with my sandwich, balanced with the peanut butter and marmelade, LOL... palate, creamy, oilly  and tickley on the tongue... Im going to have another one, and savor it the next time ;>)

I found it to be very drinkable such as settling in for an afternoon of football sitting back in a comfortable chair, perhaps with your computer in front of you as you watch the games.  What could be sweeter than great football and a really good solid beer that after a couple you know youve been drinking beer.

(Bottle).  Beguiling fruit-filled aroma.  Gorgeous mahogany color with a robust head.  The flavor is spectacularly complex, both earthy and fruity.  Leavened with lots of carbonation, and finishes seemingly forever.  Nigh unto perfect.
Great dark brown color and interesting off white lacing. Another complex beer with a bit of a hop finish. Carbonated a bit higher than a Dubbel and very similar in profile as the 10. Outstanding beer

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2008 Something about the flavor puts it JUST below the 10 but as far as I can tell the 10 is the best beer in production right now.  Same beautiful textures, colors, and complexities as the other Rocheforts but at a better price tag.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2014 Pours dark with a thick white head.  Aroma is ripen dark fruits and malts with a little bit of yeast.  This beer goes down super smooth with a fruity taste, grapes stand out.  It finishes with a caramel-chocolate taste.  This is truely a great beer and one for anyone to try.

IT HAS A STRONG FRUITY AROMA AND POURS FULL OF CARBONATION. A LITTLE EXPENSIVE AT $5.99 A 12 OUNCE. A NICE TREAT BUT TO EXPENSIVE TO HAVE EVERY DAY . ONE OF THE WORLDS BEST BEERS YOU MUST TRY AT LEAST ONCE.
Wow. Oulala. One of the best beer ever made. Nice beige foamy collet. Aroma of dark fruits, cacao and caramel. Very complex taste. Almost better than the 10. Should ask for my belgian’s citizenship.

Bottle.  For some reason I get banana bread, and  fermented grape alcohol, highly malty profile in the aroma.  Pretty decent pour as expected with this caliber of trappist ale, large foamy off-white head with some brownish particulate from the bottom of the bottle, murky and mahogany in color, satisfying lacing.  Taste is complex, it doesn’t really register till it hits the back of the tongue, in the middle there is instant of leafy bitter hop, then sweet raisons, wine alcohol (which I’m usually not a fan of but tonight it kind of worked, too prevalent than it had to be though), and minor licorice, a puckering sweet dark berry, finish with toffee malt, aftertaste linger is perhaps the best part the experience, rather full bodied and strong.  To say I didn’t enjoy it is a lie, but I was slightly disappointed, the complexities just didn’t go together quite as i would like, still a very worthy beer though.

Ugh.  Why do I find it so hard to get my hands on an un-oxidized Trappistes Rochefort...  It’s painful too cuz I can just tell from the flavor profile that it’s good when untainted :(.  We’ll give this one another try at some point I guess.

Very nice beer, tastes almost the same as the 10 but less intense.  Everything is toned down a bit, for the price I would just buy the 10 any day.  Less fruit n the nose, less sweet taste, even the head seems a bit lighter.
Very nice, as are all the beers from Brasserie Rochefort. Yeasty flavor, bready. Pours a nice brown color. I can’t put it up there with the Trappiste Rochefort 10, but it’s a damn good beer.

[Archive, the sad part of it, seemingly]

Toffee aroma, not much head. Brown.

Pours a murky brown color with nice size head. Aroma is similar to the 10 only slightly lighter. Taste is very good much like the 10 but more fruit flavor and not the chocolate notes like the 10. I prefer the 10 but this one is close.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2009 Bottle. So I didnt put a lot of effort into rating this one, but after 1500+ other ratings, its probably alright. Already rated the 10 and the 6, and, well, this one smells like a Rochefort, same earthy yeastiness, yeasty breadiness, same rich fruitiness, just in between the other two. Lots of figs, apples, raisins, pears, prunes, etc., some nuttiness, lots of toffee, its a Rochefort, nothing Im going to say is going to change anything. I will say that I dont understand why some folks prefer this to the 10 because to me the 10 is magic, and this is just a breath away in pretty much every regard (hence my numerical rating of 1 point less in each category than the 10). ...Rerate Ive basically decided it smells and looks as good as the 10 but falls short once it gets in the mouth in terms of filling the mouth with all goodness the 10 does.... Its awesome, enough said.

Sampled from bottle: pours a murky brown colour with a medium sized beige head. Aroma is pleasent, raisins, fig newtons, black cherries and soft chocolate malt. Mouthfeel is creamy, rich, with soft noticeable alcohol taste running along the palate. Flavors are semi sweet, caramel malt, dark fruit and soft spice.
Not the best of the trappiste ales but definitely worth a try.  Ranks somewhere between Chimay and Achel

Cloudy chestnut brown color. Aroma of cocoa powder, toasted nuts and dark fruits. Toasty and chocolaty malts accompanied by light yeast esters and hints of cherries in the finish. Lively carbonation and some nuts in the finish.

Light chocolate brown pour and a soft brown/tan foamy head.  Aroma is a deep dry fruit with just a touch of sweetness wafting in as well.  Was just a bit watery on the front of the palate.  Mild fruity flavors (consistent with plum or raisin, but not overbearingly fruity) and a sweet malt flavor.  Very clean finish.  Excellent beer.  The 10 is better, but the 8 is also an exceptional beer.

Pours a ruby-tinted brown. Smells of mottled berries with cocoa.  Lots of malts in the taste accompanied by chocolate, along with lighter fruit accents. Definitely some alcohol hints, which just had to it’s complex character.

Bottle BB 05/09/12. Pours hazy brown-amber with thick lasting head. Very nice big aroma of flowers, fruit and bread. Slightly woody and nutty, roses, lilies, strawberry. Burnt sugar, soapy perfume. Very nice!
Flavor is medium big with high carbonation and malty, fruity sweetness. Chocolate, hazelnuts, strawberry and warming alcohol. A hint of pineapple. Finally some bitterness from alcohol and yeast. This is simply put a very great beer.
Cloudy with a slightly off red color.  Head is tan, large, and it lingers.  Carmel enhances the sweet flavor with a strong alcohol presence.  Sweet maltiness in the aroma as well.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex, balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew, a topper!
Strong fruity yeast aroma. Dark amber color with a large tan head. Light beginning with a fruit malty and lightly bitter middle finish. Palate is slightly creamy but light for the alcohol.

[#200] Did the Rochefort 10 for number 100 so this seemed fitting for 200. Pours opaque brown with a thick off-white head. Very bready, yeasty, malty aroma. None of the fruit I was expecting. Very creamy and smoothe on the palate. Flavor is more of that bread and malt with a bit of a hay component. I can see why people love this, but for my palate it just doesnt blow me away. It is a pretty young bottle though.

Pours brown tinged with yellow.  Has a 1.5 cm dark tan head.  Decent lacing.

Smells of hops, dark bread dough, cooked green peas.

Mouthfeel is slick, but it puckers the tongue, drying it out a bit.

Taste is roasted malt, cocoa, white vinegar, whiskey, and some high alcohol notes.  Aftertaste is very sour citrus.  Becomes mustier as it warms.

Not bad.

Bottle...  Poured foggy ruby with a beige head, nice lacing.  Aroma of sweet, roasted barley-malt.  Subtle palate with a sweet acidity and a stern malt profile with some hops too.  Slight alcohol for a satisfying finish.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown, slightly lighter than the 10, with a frothy light tan head.  Aroma of delicious apple, pear, raisin, and yeast.  Flavor of apple skins, awesome combination of light fruits, with a full, rich creamy palate.  Light alcohol burn but certainly not as boozy as the 10 (which I love, but youve got to be in the mood for boozy).  It took me awhile to decide if I liked this better than the 10 - not as flavorfully complex perhaps but I do love those light fruits.  The mouthfeel is simply incredible.  Almost perfect and my favorite Belgian Strong Ale.
10/5/9/5/20 (4.9/5)

Update 5/1/09: So Ive had this beer several times since my original rating and find myself not as impressed as the first time.  This is a really tasty beer, but it is no longer my favorite.
8/5/8/4/18 (4.3/5)

Good carbonation, Thick foam that stays long time. Semi dark appearance with a spicy smell with traditional belgian fenols, and complex mixtures fruits. A sweet caramell taste with spices. As the beer gets warmer the alcohole is obvious together with apricots.

I had quite high hopes for this beer, and to be honest, was slightly dissapointed. I was certainly not wowed. Pours hazy brown with lots of residuals. Aroma is of fruity yeast, apricot, and spice. Evident, but not profound. Flavor is of cider, fruit, cherry, and nuts with some fruity esters in the back. Malt is evident and quite complex, but not as hard hitting as I was hoping for- much more subtle. Palate is really quite incredible- prickly at first, but subsides to become incredible smooth and unassuming. Not world class in my opinion- I definitely need to try this one again and intend on doing so in the near future.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2009 Rich on the nose of yeast, hops and honey. Luxuriant and long lasting head, with some lacing, and dark teak body. Fully rounded flavour, with the alcohol perfectly blended and balanced. Great beer.

Color is hazy dark brown. Beige head is thick, cloudy, long-lasting and lacy. Aroma is very complicated: spicy, salty, sweet syrupy, roasty malty with a bit alcohol. Flavor is very nice and soft: salt licorice, spicy, sweety and syrupy malty with pertinent hoppy bitterness. Full bodied, soft, foamy carbonated and a bit alcoholic, warming palate.
Aroma of.. i dunno, slight fruit.  Excellent palate, flavor was non fantastic. Was not impressed on the whole, but its not my favorite style

hazy brown pour, smallish head. aroma of yeast, clove, some ginger, sweetish malt, citrusy aroma of orange or apricot. Incredibly smooth palate, flavor is very unique, hints of apple cider, black cherry- very mysterious and complex. Not many beers can baffle me like this, but in such a wondrous way. Beer is hard to place, but incredibly delicious.

Bottle poured a dark brown umddy color.  Thin off-white head that presents no lacing.  Sweet spicy aroma.  Some dry roast character in the finish, mostly sweet spicy and bready.  Very carbonated with a biting tingly feel.  I do not like the strong carbonation on this and the 6.

Slightly bready aroma with lots of apple and raisin.  Yeasty.  A touch of apple cider.

Good size creamy off-white head that doesnt die.  Light lacing.  Cloudy brown body.

Relatively sweet.  Lots of fruit - raisins, apple, dried fruits - with a pleasant brown sugar sort of malt body.  Very well integrated.  Nice finish.

Medium/full body with a wonderful creaminess.  Medium to low carbonation - very pleasant for this beer.  Low alcohol presence.  Very drinkable.

All in all, a very tasty beer.  Not as complex as the 10, but a great beer nonetheless.

Murky orange/amber color with foamy white head.  Apples, dark fruits, brown sugar aroma.  Syrupy and full bodied on the palate.  Not as good as the 10, but still one of the best beers I’ve ever tried.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2010 Over-carbonated (likely due to bottle conditioning), cidery brown appearance. My expectations were initially skewed for this one as I thought this was the Abbey Dubbel version (Roch. 6). Aroma begins feintly yeasty and malty , and stronger aromas never really develop. Mildly fusely flavor with winy yeasty notes and twinge of yeast sourness on finish. Lacks the complexity I would expect and desire of a beer of this style, though otherwise, this is a very good Belgian Strong Ale. Well crafted--especially considering the knock-you-over-the-head alcohol content! Re-rate: 5/17/10: Viscous auburn-tressed amber. Candi malt presence with higher crystal malts and hints of bubblegum. Just ok.

11.2oz at John’s Spirits.  WOW!  Talk about bang for your buck.  I tried this side by side with a comparable trappiste and the difference was very evident.  Dark brown to the eye with a thick(ish) off white head, slight lacing, sweet and deep to the nose, and a full, robust fruity and nutty palate. 9.2ABV hits you after 5 of those ounces.  A new favorite!

moreburnt than expected smell offwhite head
great body, it does have an alcohol kick, great malt
nothing special looking, mellow yet back off throat crash
odd late aftertaste great carb quite sour alcohol taste fades as it warms
Does not live up to the hype, is really good but not the best of even the few I have tasted, $5.00 a bottle is pretty steep for this.
Bottle at de Boom in Alkmaar. Nice dark brown color. Full-bodied, fruity beer with a sweet smell. Just like the Rochefort 10, you don’t really taste the alcohol, you only feel it afterwards.

11.2 oz. into pint for lack of trappist.  Dark nut brown pour with an off-white fizzy head that fades pretty quickly.  Smells sweet like apricot and caramel  hard to nail it down to be honest.  Tastes a bit funky: nuts and berries with a weird subtle tang  good but weird an no where as balanced as the 10 IMO.  No alcohol flavor.  Light bodied on palate with some soft fizzy carbonation.  Overall: solid, but splurge the extra dollar and get the 10!
Hazy brownish colour with medium white head.Aroma of dark fruits feels vineous with strong hidden alc.Well balanced and tasty brew with soft finish.

Bottle from swedish monopoly outlet.
Muddy brown with tan head. Vineous and spicy. A bit too much alcoholtaste. Not quite as good as #10, but almost
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice off-white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, sugar, toffee, dark fruit and alcohol.

POured a murky brown color with a small off white head. Aroma is of dark fruits mainly and alcohol. Flavor was kind of bland with notes of candy suagr, dark fruits and lots of alcohol. Just did not enjoy this much, way too boozy.

very nice on the nose, smell plums/raisins and other subtle fruity tones.  found the carbonation to interfere with my enjoyment of the beer.  Seems to linger forever.  As it warmed got significantly better.  Nonetheless I was disappointed overall.  Perhaps I was expecting too much.  It is a quality brew but I have had others I enjoyed more.  I was anticipating more flavour especially after the aroma.  prefer struise pennepot

Bottle, picked up in some random grocery store in Bruge. Chunky deep brown, persistent thick light tan head. Mexican chocolate, coriander seed and gingerbread aroma. Cocoa powder, buttered walnut flavor. Massive peppery carbonation. Clean dry finish with just a faint linger woodiness. This has been one of those beers I cant believe it has taken my so long to get around to tasting, and now that I have, was indeed good, but a little disappointing overall. It tastes like a beer in its awkward teen stage: beer that is not young enough to have the brightness of fresh beer, nor old enough to have that soft unity of maturity. Lots of sass, but still doesnt know what it wants to be when it grows up.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 0.33l bottlle.

Pours deep muddy brown with a large foamy tan head fair ammount of carbonation.  Smell is sweet and alcoholic, taste is complex, raisens, malt, cherries, fairly sweet with an alcoholic finish.  An excellent truly enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 Dark brown and hazy with a frothy head. Aroma of cherry, chocolate, malt and currant. Subtle and complex with lots of different notes vying for your attention: spice, chocolate, toffee, walnut, malt and dried fruit. Soft mouthfeel and gentle carbonation with a lingering finish. A first rate Belgian.

Appearance: Dark brown, cloudy. Nice amount of head, creamy.
Aroma: Pretty malty. Raisins.
Taste: Malty, raisins. Bitter.
Info: 330ml bottle, 1/3-2006, 85/300

Pours brown in color with ruby highlights.  The most impressive thing is the frothy half inch head that is still there several minutes after the pour.  This beer looks good!  Very carbonated and creamy feel.  Taste has a certain spice going on.  Not as much dark fruit as the 10, but still noticeable.  Very good beer that I could drink regularly. This is far from a knock, but I prefer the 10.
Not as great as the 10...but still a phenomenal beer with good flavor.  Goes great with a hunk of Gouda or Gruyere Cheese and good conversation.

Another incredible beer from the St. Remy monks.  It pours the typical slightly red brown color with a tiny amount of off-white head.  Big flavors in this beer including candy sugar, dark fruit, milk chocolate, caramel/ toffee, and bourbon.  Phenomenal.

bottle.  dull, murky brown with a big frothy head.  aromas of candied fruit and bananas.    flavors of big raisins, floral hop bitterness, some boozy notes, a very crisp, sweet maltiness.  Highly carbonated, and somewhat soapy on the palate.

Pours dark, cloudy brown with a cream-colored head. Aroma is clean, fruity with mild hoppy flavor and smooth malt.
Excellent, very drinkable, very tasty...

Pours very dark, cloudy brown with a big, pillowy cream-colored head. The aroma is clean and fruity: banana, berries, mild hops, and smooth malt. The flavor has much the same character as the aroma, but with a yeasty foundation. The hops are a bit more present than other Belgians, and it makes an interesting complement to the rich vinous flavors. Altogether its very tasty, and it makes me want some aromatic cheese to eat with it.

Bottle, Cloudy brown color with an excellent lasting head.   Aroma of plum and raisins.  I believe it has little too much carbonation.  Definitely has  some dark chocolate mixed in with aroma.  Excellent beer all around.  Complex in nature and well balanced.
UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 33cl bottle - Heavy strong flavour with a very pleasant herbal aroma with notes of red berries. A definate favorite and in my top 3.
Bottle. Dark brown with a nice head.  Not as much flavor as the 10 but still good.  Alcohol is a little more present than the 10 even though it has a lower ABV.  Good stuff though.

Bottled. Color is hazy brown, huge thick  and foamy head with nice lacing. Nose is fruity and licoric. Aroma has fruits, yeast and and  alcohol comes through. Flavour is fruity , yeasty, with  hops. Nice but 10 is much better.
pours nice dark ruby color.  very little head.  small amount of cloves in the aroma and flavor.  a bit too carbonated for my tastes.  not worth the $$$.

Pours blacker than the ace of spades, with a succulent white head that keeps on coming. Aromatically it seems earthy/fruity with a subtle chocolate overtone. The flavor is outstanding. Chocolaty and sweet, the alcohol sorta jumps out at you initially but then just blends back in with the plethora of well crafted flavors. Very nice brew!

What a great beer...wow.  Nice brown puor.  Aromas of chocolate, dried fruit, sweet syrup, wood and high quality malt.  Flavor is so well balanced it is hard to think there is much better.  Rich and creamy....YES!

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2009 Bottle, cellar temp.  Dark, beautifully muddy pour with huge beige head.  Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, caramel, dark fruits, malt... all balanced very nicely and not too sweet.  Tastes of bittersweet chocolate cake.  Good call, gueuze is god, in saying that it smells and tastes like German chocolate cake.  I also thought it had a nice fruitiness (a little plum, summer fruits) without being overly sweet. Some mild floral notes and doughy yeast.  Alcohol was very present on first smell and sip, but that subsided very quickly, and this had a surprisingly light feel considering how dark and cloudy it was.  Much closer to the 10 than to the 6. Great beer. Sooo good.
Bottle in Brussels,  Wonderfully dark brown.  Very sweet nose.  Nutty, fruittcakey taste (and almost texture).  Superb.

33cl bottle- approx 65 degrees F. One finger head, subsides in a minute. To me, smells exactly like german chocolate cake, icing and all, with emphasis on the cakey part. Tastes like velvety cake soaked in alcohol, the alc is very evident in the nostrils right away. Mouthfeel is initially rich but tails off somewhat watery with hop bitterness coating the tongue and finishing hotly alchohlic.  Only lacks the ripe dark fruits of the 10. Very good.

Pours a murky brown with a thick and lingering tan head. A lot of sediment. Aroma of citrus, cherries, spices, and Belgian yeast. Very dry taste going down. Spicy at first with the alcohol lingering. Intermediate flavors arent pronounced at all, maybe some nuts or figs, but nothing as strong as the spicy lightly cherry overtone. Complexity kind of leads to a plainness when nothing jumps out as amazing.

A thick tan head, a deep red color, some lacing... its going to be good! Incredible aroma, Im almost unable to discribe what it smells like, surely chocolate, dried fruit, some roastiness. Figs, nuts,  and malt. Very round and warming without the alcohol taste. Just a bit less complex than the 10. Do we really deserve this?

A strong ale that looks like a Belgian Dubbel.  I had this about a week after I had a Leffe Brune, and I have to say that I thought the Brune was a better beer, even though the alcohol content was not as high.  Its fruity, not as much yeast aroma as other Belgians, brown in color.

pours a murky reddish brown, smells of fruit and alcohol, the flavor is heavily carbonated and very malty, with hints of all kinds of fruits and spices, this has a very complex flavor and you can pick up different flavors throughout drinking this. Very amazing ale!

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 (Belgium) Pours a med-brown color with a lingering med-white head. Tons of sediment and some carbonation in this ale !!! The aroma is of dark fruit and brown sugar, taste has a creamy malt / spicy flavor. The finish is robust, and the 9.2 % for the most part is hidden.  Overall this is a good beer..... Get some !!!

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2010 Bottle.  Ive been waiting to try one these beers for awhile.  It did not disappoint. It pours dark caramel brown with a think head and a lot of carbonation.  The sweet flavor of dark fruits is well compliments by the high alcohol.  Smooth and complex, with an excellent mouth feel.  This is the perfect Belgian Strong Ale....Ive tried so far.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2008 Poured to a murky brown color with a thin tnnnish head that lingered thru mid glass and left okay lacing. Aroma is dark fruit overwhelmed by alcohol as the beer warmed. Taste was a semi-sweet malty dark fruit, again with a lot of alcohol, whcih carreid over into the finish as well.

This was a good quality beer, but the alcohol was a little too dominant for my liking in a beer.
Cloudy carmel brown colour with a light tan head. Faint malt aroma. Tastes like an old musty building when cold. As it warms the malt, spice and nut flavors come forward. A realy great beer.

Alcohol content nicely hidden, very easy to drink and quite flavorful, i meant to buy the 10, but accidentally bought the 8. Nevertheless for 3-4 bucks a bottle quite an excellent beer. Ill be trying the 10 in a few days.

Bottle from 2004. Average size, nice creamy light brown head. Hazy brown body. Aroma of banana, raisin, ficus, port, brown sugar, earth and vanilla. It has a full body, creamy with a soft carbonation. The flavor has a long duration is heavy sweet and light bitter. A very, very good beer!

This is definitely a cousin to the Rochefort 10, not a sibling as so many people try to compare them as.  I initially caught a huge cherry whiff as I poured but as it opens I am left with more dried fruit, herbs, and hard timbers.  Body flavors are interesting... Im getting a lot more bitter candy than I expected.  Some robust copper and brass pipe is coming through, not quite as complex as I had come to expect.  Palate is a bit hot (alcohol) but good carbonation and a long finish makes up for that.  There is also some serious mouth-watering acidity that I think would pair very well with various cuisines, definitely a high-class brew.
UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 Great palate and mouthfeel.  Not boozy at all.  With that being said.  Not too flavorful.  A bit of dark fruit and sugar rings through on the flavor. ABV is hideen well.

Bottle. Damned good! After that beer I think that almost Estonian beers is not beers -  they are something like a beer. So spicy aroma, nice red-brown color. And flavor! And aftertaste! Haven´t words.

My assessment might also be biased, because this is the first true Trappistes beer that I ever tried.  With that said, I nearly cried when the high-quality liquor store in town told me that it was no longer available for purchase in the state of Texas.  Apparently the type of bottle that it ships in is now illegal in Texas.  I cant imagine how thats possible, but that is what the manager told me, and a second store confirmed it.

Let me just say, I have a distaste for most Belgians.  I dont know what it is, whatever the reason, this beer is the prime examplet.  I feel almost sorry rating such a highly regarded beer so low, but I couldnt even bring myself to finish it.  I normally would think it might have been a bad bottle, but like I said, certain Belgian beers just have an awful off-taste to me.

Dark Carmel with light carmel head.  Wonderful, sweet malt aroma with hints of carmel and cocoa.  Bright flavor that is a bit of a surprise after the aroma.  Fizzy, grain, dark current and holiday nut  flavor.  Has quite a bite that actually left the edges of my tongue numb for a short time.  Well worth the ratings it receives.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 33cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa). Pours a dark brown to black with a creamy two-finger tan-white head that dissipates quickly leaving lacing on the glass. Aroma: malt, barley, hazelnut, and spice. Flavor: oakey, earthy, caramel, toffee, coffee on finish. Medium to full-bodied, with well-hidden alcohol of over 9%. Excellent trappist ale.

Big foam with a very malty aroma with chocolate and coffee. Color kind of a dark tea but thick. Taste shows lot of hop, coffee, spices and bitter that comes at the end and stays there. A bit carbonated and slightly light on the palate, which makes it rather easy to drink. Lacks balance.

11.2oz bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a firm off-white head.  Aroma is light, with scents of roasted malt, spices, and fruity twinge thats more hops than dark fruit.  Taste is creamy and full, with a flavor that starts out as sweeter syrupy hops, some dark fruit, caramel, and molasses before opening up into a dry finish of wood, spices, and a twinge of warming alcohol.  Unlike Chimay, Bernardus, or any of the other Belgians, there doesnt seem to be much difference between this one and its big brother the 10.  While its still delicious, it cant help but feel a bit like a somewhat less mature version of the 10.

I ordered one of these off the internet at was pleased. It poured a dark cloudy brown with a long lasting off white head and had sediment at the bottom. Smelled of fruits with a hint of spice. Nice carbonation. The mouth feel is kinda watery. Tastes of fruits like oranges and a hint of raisin, malt, and grains. It is slightly sweet, but in my opinion should be a little sweeter. Ends on a dry bitter note. Nicely done brew overall, but I wish I could try the next best Rochefort 10 to see what all the hype is about.

Bottle: Had this many times but havent rated it until now, pours a murky brown with a frothy, light tan head, sweet aroma of dark fruit, taste of dark fruits, caramel and yeast, very smooth and excellent Belgian brew.
Bottle. Brown color. Really fruity and sweet flavor with lots of caramel and raisins. Complex trappist beer but not as good as its big brother.
Dark Brown with a slight amber orange burnt colour when held to light. Strong, and sweet, with carmel and nutty notes, slightly hot.

Rochefort Trappiste 8
9.2% abv
$4.99 discounted due to 02 09 2008 serve by date
trappist glass. 
11.2 fl oz bottle

First: Very cluttered deposits, surely due to age. Does not hurt the taste very much if at all. In pouring, the color went from rather clear red, to a ruby, to an inpenetrable dark brown. Head was fleeting at best, though hangs on to a thin film. Again, likely due to age. Notes of cherry, alcohol, nuts, yeast, and peach. A very layered set of flavors, and very nice. Hoppy and aromatic. Whiffs of dust and cardboard. Nice lacing. Palate is crisp, sandy, and subtle. Long lasting fruity finish. A very nice beer. I think that a fresher one will do even better. 

Aroma 9

Visuals 4

Taste 8

Palate 4

Second A very good beer, though a fresher one would do better, Im sure. Certainly worth its praise. 

Overall 17

Bottle. Dark brown with a golden hew. Aroma and taste: lots of dark fruits such as raisin and prunes, malts, caramel and yeast. Good filling body with a low carbanation.  Complex but I don´t find it as good as the 10!

Opaque tan/brown body with large white head. Nose of burnt berries, dark chocolate, bread, and a little alcohol warmth. The taste has sweetness in  aforementioned fruit, but it tastes champagne-like, almost carbonated, and with a huge alcohol presence. For me, it contradicts the other flavors too strongly.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 (Re-rate on 2008-12-21, Bottle BBE 301713) Dark brown and cloudy. Quite big white head. Malts and anis in nose. Full bodied palate with quite high carbonation. Malts, anis, light bitterness, chocolate, sweetness and hint of fruitiness. Malts and anis in aftertaste.


(Bottle at Hilpeä Hauki on 2008-02-23) Dark brown with hints of red. White browish small head. Malts and fruitiness in nose. A bit stinging feeling in palate that changes towards dryness. Malts and frutiness in taste. 8-4-7-3-13

dark brown with mild tan head.  more carbonation than i expected.  flavor of some dark brown candy sugar and a finish that is dry with peculiar aftertaste.  this may have been a bad bottle, because it just didnt compare to rochfort 10 and wasnt all that good.  i must try it again

Bottle. Pours muddy brown with thick head. Pleasant fruity aroma with hints of malt. Taste is sweet of some fruit, difficult  to describe, though. Does not leave a distinctive finish. It is quite lighter than the 10, but still very drinkable.

Turbid tobacco-spit brown. Frothy, homogeneously-bubbled head. Inviting bready, plummy aroma, lightly fruity and spicy, some figs and milk chocolate. Flavor rather surprised me, as I was expecting this to be rather sweet. Instead, I get a rather dry, roasty, hoppy flavor. Raisin and brown sugar, some rather prominent ethanol, a rather dusty graininess, and a spiky, rather orangey hoppiness. Long, lingering bitter aftertaste that Im not overly fond of.
bottle, prune malt nose with muddy turbid brown color, good khaki brown lingering head, bubbly champagne body, flaovrs of maple sugar and candy, fruit

UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 dark mahogany color with a white, thin, dissipating head. Aroma is muted with traces of cinnamon, malt and hops. Taste is sour and and has some barley notes. Doesnt last long and has a lot of carbonation.

-----

Bottle:  Deep mahogony in color with a medium-thick head of medium-sized off-white bubbles.  There were aromas of raisins, chocolate, orange pulp, plum and dark caramel.  There is a lot of carbonation in the mouth keeping this very light and fresh.   The flavors remain on the "dark side", similar to the nose but lack a bit of concentration.  I love the 10, but this just feels like a watered down version, which should be expected but leaves me wanting more.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a decent tan head.  Very mellow beer.  Seems to be a little over carbonated.  A lot of aroma and flavor, mostly of bread and yeast.  Nice amount of spices and a little fruit.  Cant wait to try the 10.

Bottle, pours a dark brown with a nice tan head that lasts.  Aroma of dark chocolate covered raisins.  Flavors are big and complex as you can imagine... my biggest strike against it was the mouthfeel... seems over carbonated... had a bite to it that didnt come from the alcohol...  the alcohol comes through on the end, but its not a bad alcohol bite... the bite on the front end was bad for me.  A big step down from the 10.

A dark brow pour with a very smooth texture.  I think it may have been a bit too chilled when i first tackled it but the flavors really opened up as i worked at it.  Found this to be more complex (though a bit tougher to drink) than the 10...I need to buy this one again
Bottle from whole foods in hillcrest. Some yeasty bread dough. Some mellow hops. Very smooth, very good.
bottle.  Pours dark brown with a slight amber hue and a tan head.  Aroma of bread, yeast,spice, and dark fruit.  Flavors of belgium yeast, pepper, and spice.

A- Pours a murky brown, letting no light pass through. A huge light brown head initially tops this brew then fades to a nice 2 finger head.

S- Smells of grapes, raisins, dark fruit with a hint of alcohol that stings the nose.

T- Very light however hugely complex in taste. Yeasty and earth with hints of spice. Small amount of dark fruit tastes along with a distinct alcohol warming.

M- Perhaps a bit overcarbonated. Medium bodied.

D- This is definitely one to sip on but for the ABV it is very drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 33cl bottle from Systembolaget. It poured an dark red-brown, almost black color with a medium foamy head that settles down slowly in the glass. The aroma is sweet and smells of alcohol, malts, raisins and dark chocolate. The flavour is fruity and bitter and tastes of alcohol, yeast, malts, raisins. It has a suprisingly short aftertaste.
Pours dark cola color, mildly fizzy, generous off-white head.  Smells and tastes of spice, ripe fruits, and alcohol.  Wish I could find the 10 around these parts...

Pours a deep, dark orange with a great Belgian head. Smells sweet, very fruity - almost overpoweringly so - but the flavor makes up for it. Has the smoky licorice notes of a stout, along with a bit of plum and black cherry. Great brew, but its lacking a bit of punch - Im excited to try the 10.

Dark cloudy brown color.  Off white head.  Aroma of yeast, dried fruit and brown sugar.  Nice flavor, good amount of carbonation and little alcohol burn.  Somewhat spicy in the flavor.  Very good beer.  Would like to try this with Chimay Blue to see which I like better.

my 400th rating and b-day bottle!!!!!!! pours a dark brown with a one finger tan head. aroma is Belgian yeast, raisins, and bread. has a medium body with good lacing and great carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma with some hops. a very smooth and tasty Belgian strong. lively carbonation and the only alcohol present is a little warming effect going down. i dont get into Belgian beers to much but this one is a keeper.

A very pleasant beer. Not a very strong nose. It does not have an assertive personality but it sure hides its alcohol well. The question for me is why would I drink this when I can have a Rochefort 10 instead.

Pours a dark brown with a burgundy highlights and a rocky, beige head that diminishes to a thin cap of bubbles at the surface. The nose is exceptionally complex, so much so that I have difficulty pulling out individual notes. My best shot at describing it would be: spice cake, light chocolate, and a combination of peppery, floral, and fruity spice notes. Medium-bodied with assertive, fine carbonation and a dry, spicy and moderately astringent finish; chest-warming alcohol follows the swallow. The flavor more-or-less follows the nose with a lot of pepper and a flinty, dry finish. I can appreciate this one as a well crafted beer, but I have an aversion to heavily spiced brews. This one is just way too spicy for my liking. Perhaps with a bit of age, it would mellow. The date code on the front of the label reads 160812. I assume that means August 2012. Ill keep my eyes open for an older bottle and give it a second try.

Pours a medium amber-brown with a creamy tan head that lasted and left nice lacing.  Great aroma of chocolate and ripe fruits, with some spiciness and malt.  Flavor is amazing, malty and fruity giving way to some alcohol on the finish.  A truly great beer.

Pours a reddish brown color with a beige foamy head. Good carbonation and a thick head that seemed to disappear quickly. Slight floral smell with some fruit and spice. A little bitter aftertaste with a definate alcohol feel. Overall a great beer. Dont be surprised by the small size it packs a kick at 9.2% alcohol.

Good bubbly head on a burgundy purple colour,good carbonation.Aroma,plum raisins,caramel notes,figs,cinnamon.Flavour,figs,plum,raisins,cara taste,cinnamon,very melloweasy drink,great flavours,has a medicinal feeling to the throat,bloody good.Finish is mellowspice/herb sweet.

Pours a slightly reddish brown colour, with a creamy beige foam, not as lasting as the foam of its weaker cousin, the 6. The aroma goes for dry fruits, malt and some burned wood. As it goes dense into the mouth, the flavors start to appear gently. Dark fruits, roasted wood and malt, faint coffee and chocolate. The aftertaste throws a large bouquet, mainly lightly bitter, with roasted malt and some fruitness to it. Although it not stand long, the alcohol feel sticks and makes the experience quite outstanding. Long live to those wise trappists monks. / Derrama um marrom levemente vermelho, com espuma bege cremosa, não tão duradoura quanto a da prima mais fraca, a Rochefort 6. O aroma trás frutas secas, malte, algo de madeira queimada. Ao passar densamente pela boca, o sabor se solta gentilmente. Frutas escuras, madeira e malte torrados, um pouco de café e de chocolate. O retrogosto carrega um largo bouquet, vem levemente amargo, com malte torrado e algum sabor frutoso. Apesar de não ficar muito tempo, a sensação do álcool continua, fazendo a experiência fantástica. Vida longa aos sábios monges trapistas.
I am a big  fan of abby style ales, and this one is  definately a good beer.

Appearance: Pours a lively, clear, reddish-brown body topped by a large, off-white head.

Smell: Lightly spiced aroma with notes of caramel, breadcrusts, six flowers, dried fruits, a bit of booze, and freshly brewed white tea.

Taste: Flavors of toasted bread and sweet carmael with brown sugar-coated bananas and a hint of dried cherries. Savory yeast character. Slight bitterness, but its generally on the sweet side throughout. Toasty finish with a hint of that warming booze.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. After some fizzing, after some fussing, it settles to a medium carbonation.

Drinkability: This is a very good beer, I wont lie to you.

*liked it, may buy it again*

smell: nice fruit after a hint of banana. very warm soft fruit malts, hint of booze. smells very nice! app: nice garnet amber magic goodness. nice head. flavor: nice brown malts up front then banana then red fruits and berries. nice clean finish, GREAT BALANCE. a lil bit of booze in the finish that adds a sharpness. this is a grand belgian. touch to many nanners and a lil sharp on the booze.  palate: lil bit carbonated nice and smooth though. like the silky feel.  OA: really good for a belgian, wish it had more brown malt flavoring, .. but.. this is really good. i find that the slower i sip it the better it tastes.
This beer is also great as 10. I actually see no difference or just a little bit in flavor but its great and those two are definititely the beers I could drink every day, 10 of them or more :)

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2010 Pours a murky brown color topped with a thick foamy head.  The head does taper off a bit, leaving a thin layer the rest of the way.  Still leaves a good amount of lacing.  Fruity, faint spices, malty aroma with a touch of belgian yeast.  Extremely smooth flavor with a rush of sugary dark fruits, slightly spicy with slick malts.  Maybe even some caramel somewhere in there.  A long, tasty, gentle mouthfeel.  9.2% and I hardly know its there.  Very nice.

Bottle - Murky red/ brown with orangy highlights when held to light.  Tan head and lots of  sediment. . Fruity aroma and flavours of dark roasted malts with dark fruits and caramel. Moderate carbonation and slightly effervescent/frothy on the tongue. Well balanced.  The Rochefort 10 has the edge but this is a great drop all the same.

Cloudy reddish brown colour with a nice size light beige head. Lots of sediment. Medium bodied with average carbonation and moderate bitterness.  Flavours quite sweet, fruity, malty...Alcohol in the fairly dry finish.
Very nice! 330ml bottle.
pours brown with nice off white head,hints of dark fruit,plum raisin on the nose as well as yeast.malt is sweet but nice balance,cannot tast the alachol.very nice beer.

I think this beer is a textbook example of the style....great plum and raisin flavors.......smooth estery alcohol  aromas
good stuff

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 Pours dark brown, with a light tan and creamy head. Tan sediment is present in my glass. Aromas of roasted malts, sweet fruits and Belgian yeast fill your nose. Malt flavor is sweet, bready and nutty. Fruity notes are of plum, golden raisin and fig. The alcohol is well hidden, but still noticeable. Well balanced with a medium body, nice carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. Exceptional Trappist ale.

Bottle poured into a chalice produced a huge fluffy tan head it takes a few minutes to settle down to a thick lace. The body is a hazy dark brown 

Aromas of dark fruits, spices and malts fill your nose. Some nice bread yeast and a light alcohol whiff follows

Flavors of raisins plumbs and spices dance across your tongue along nice warming effect from the alcohol

Good mouthfeel on this one nice and bubbly on the tongue from the carbonation 

Awesome drinkablity I sipped away at this for about a half hour and enjoyed every drop will gladly grab a few more of these

11.2 oz bottle. My written description is probably unworthy of this great beer, but here goes.It poured a mahogany brown, with no head. I noticed hints of fruit, belgian hops, and a bit of alcohol in the nose. What I tasted was a delicious blend of caramel, fruit, and hops that is marvelously carbonated.It ends with a delicious smooth sweet finish. This is a great beer, and definitely one of my favorites.

Very good trappist !
From bottled 330 ml. Yesterday @ the Anker, Zele.
Dark fruits aroma, bit caramel, spice, yeast, sweet. Flavour spices, complex,  and sweet. 
Fantatastic good.

Bottled. Pours rich dark mahogany color with a tan head that overflowed the glass and hardly shrunk in the couple minutes it took to clean up my desk. Many floaties. Rich, roasted malt aroma with a very pronounced yeastiness. This is another beer I could simply smell for an hour or so; it seems to have many different subtleties and they even seem to change around a bit. The taste is somewhat spicy, somewhat roasty, somewhat floral, somewhat nutty, somewhat minty and somewhat sweet. Very dry finish

Deep brown, thick foamy khaki colored head (great lacing left behind).  Rich caramelized plum and chocolate cherry aromas layer on soft molasses and warm golden raisin tones.  Dark fruit and musty brown sugar flavors balance over hints of red licorice.  Rounds outs well with nice herbal-like finish.   Medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation throughout.   A very good brew for sipping anytime...

Aroma is sweet, malty yet fresh, perhaps with a touch of vanilla. Colour is almost opaque red-brown with a thin, creamy head. Taste is slightly sweet, malty and a really clean finish. For 9.2% ABV, its well hidden. A gem.
Bottle. A dark brown beer with a good head. The aroma has fruity and chocolate notes. And the flavor is very complex with notes of fruit and chocolate.

(3/17/08) Bottle at Gollem in Amsterdam. Dark brown color with a medium off-white head. Aroma of malt and dark fruits. Sweet and fruity flavor with some caramel, yeast, spices and a bit of alcohol in the finish. Medium to full body.
Foam Rangers tasting. Dark and dirty brown pour. Nose is a barnyard of caramel, toffee, plums and cola. Flavor is much the same, but with some nice spices.

Wow.  Pours a reddish-brown color with a thick tan head.  Aroma is complex, sweet and malty - like fresh bread - with a noticeable alcohol smell.  Wonderful in the mouth.  Great body and balance, sweet and spicy and malty with a definite alcohol presence.  Finishes with just a little aftertaste.  Overall, Its wonderful.

(Aged for 3 years)- Pours a dark, murky, dirty brown color with a light tan head. Aroma is fairly aggressive of alcohol and musk, also traces of caramel, vanilla and fruit. The flavor of this beer is Amazing. I could not defie this beer in one word. It is smooth, crisp, explosive and it all balances out. It has notes of malt, plum, yeast, honey and spices.  Very Well Done.

Drink by 050912. Not much new to be said. Cap pops due to the carbonation when opening. Powerful, toffee-ish aroma. Long-lasting head. I drank it slowly (the strong flavor and carbonation slowed me down) and the last sip was still foamy. Rich, dark fruit flavor. A bit like a chocolate fig cake (if such a thing exists). Alcohol is noticeable, but not harsh. Warms my rib cage.

330ml brown bottle poured into a Chimay Goblet.
Hazy dark brown with hints of red. A nice thick tan head with small bubbles as a top hat. Looks like an A&W commercial. The head eventually recedes to a half finger.

Sour and malty with a bit of toast on the nose followed by caramel sweetness, almost like cola. Light yeasts present as well.

Fantastic palate. Spices, caramel and malt all balanced perfectly up front. Alcohol cuts in for the finish and leaves minimal aftertaste. The transition from sweet to alcohol reminds me of a bananas foster.

Heavily carbonated with medium body. Nice smooth brew.

Best Ive had in this category. Will be back.

11.2 oz bottle.  Clear brown pour with a red tint.  Thick head.  Nice strong aroma.  Very fruity and sour with malt and hops.  Grainy yeasty flavor with just a touch of sweetness.  Fruity raisin notes and a hint of chocolate, toffee, and molasses.  Pretty good, but the alcohol is a little bit overpowering.  Good body

Pours a deep burgundy with medium brown head and high carbonation.  Aromas are of prunes, raisins, and caramel.  Nice alcohol balance with burnt flavors of dark specialty malts, and complexity from Belgian yeast and some sweetness.  Very pleasant!

330 mL bottle - big cream head fades to a thin layer; dark brown and hazy around the edges; aromas of bread, dates and sweet malts; very rich aromas overall; texture as well is rich and creamy that is slightly reduced by the carbonation; mild flavors-wise to me, but really loved the nose

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2013 330 ml bottle froma trade with paco. pours brownish red with a mid sized tan head that is everlasting. aromas of raisons, sweet candy, and trappist yeast. flavours are wonderful dark belgian with dark fruit in the mouth and that great rochefort yeast quality. the yeast strain in this is what sets it apart from other belgians. supurb in everyway. /////////////////// The current LCBO shipment is fresh and hop, endlessly complex, and just fucking amazing. Stunning beer.

Bottled. Cloudy brown pour, with a largedense, rocky, tan head. Aroma of raisins, candied fruit, rum, canned brown bread. Flavor is sweet malt with soft alcohol notes, fine balance. Finishes dry with a hint of alcohol. Wine-like mouthfeel, nicely carbonated.

Rochefort, Belgium
Bottled
Complex with yeasty fruit and roasted malt
Drinkable but with so many notes
Unique
Ja den er betemt god, en rigtig dejlig blød og fyldig, kraftig kloster øl som de kan lave dem i Belgien

Pours with a large, creamy, off-white head with a murky, dark brown body. Dark fruits (raisins and candied figs), belgian sugar, light floral hops, and light yeast on tap in the aroma (albeit the aroma is a bit weak). Some alcohol upon letting the beer come to temperature. Sheets of lacing down the glass, the head has great retention throught the entire length of the beer. Taste is nutty, sweet, and raisiny with the alcohol upfront. Creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation.

bottle with michael @ the billet. hi hi i wish i could decipher my notes./ i may have been a bit drunk by then. but i must have liked it. still can read sweet, medicinal, liquorice and devine. and hell, i had it before and it is yummy stuff any time :-)

Bottle. I will start by saying that this bottle was not right. The beer is much better than this. Looked and poured fine but the taste was rough with nothing like the flavors it should have. It was not bad just not right. Look for a re rate in the future.

11.2 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a big frothy head that does not disappear.  Vanilla and fig flavors, very complex.  Sweet aroma, molasses undertone and somewhat fruity.  Full bodied.  This is excellent and rivals its big brother.
The bottle looks really good, the beer in the glass is incredible! Very fine foam. Tastes strong, but not alcoholic. Really, really good!

Had this one in the basement, and poured into a snifter at cellar temperature.  Poured a murky red/brown, with a light brown frothy head, that quickly dissipated and left no discernable lacing.  Aroma was strong dark fruit (plums and dates), with hint of molasses and smoke.  Flavor very sweet and heavy, with light acidity and bitterness.  Full bodied and syrupy, with mild carbonation.  Strong alcohol.  All in all, very strong, sweet, and heavy...obviously a quality beer.

Big beer. Pours a cloudy brown color. Hints of apple cider and fruity yeast. Taste of creme cherry soda and yeast with a heavy wine characteristic and a slight earthy tone to it. The body is medium and  thinner than expected with lively carbonation. Overall a good beer. Maybe not for everyday but definitely special.

Poured into a snifter. Dark cloudy brown with nice amount of bubles. About 3/16 inch of head that stays throughout the tasting. Nice legs on the glass.Malt aroma, some fruit, but full bodied malt flavor and very nice finish. Very nice beer for $4.99 a bottle.

Pours a very dark brown (murky I guess) with a heavy light tan head. Lots of bubbles.  I was a little worried at first because Ive been striking out with every Belgian Strong Ale Ive had after the Chimay Grand Reserve (which is tied for my favorite) but
this one is really good. Im glad I bought it.  Hop flavor is low.  I cant smell very many hops either.  Very well balanced overall.  This is better than the $40 bottle of Scaldis Prestige I had.  I drank this out of a tumbler.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2009 Bottle. Pours murky dark reddish brown, with big, quick disappearing head. Sweet aroma of malt, fresh bread, some dark fruit. Full bodied, big maltiness with hints of sweet fruit -- figs? Finish is all malt, bready, yeasty. Palate is big and sticky. Delicious beer.

Pours a ruddy clear brown, copper tinge, with a medium, but quickly dissipating head.  Very, very sour on the nose, as if it was apple/cherry. Very thin and bubbly on the tongue, with very minor residual sourness initially picked up on scent (mainly in the rear center of tongue). A little yeast is detected (probably due to my poor pour). But, generally, very, very good, and  its packed a sneak-up wallop. Ive had this aging in my fridge for two years... yum (Bottle Pour 3/9/2008)

L180412, Candy aroma. Brown with nice beige head. Vanilla candy is first thing that comes to mind, banana as well. Very well blended, like an alcoholic desert. Leaves mouth full of wonderful taste that lasts.
Bottle. This is an excellent beer. Actually ranks right behind its big brother. The sour after taste did cause me to lower my score a bit. Otherwise, great beer.

Pours dark brown and murky with lots of sediment  and a persistent head with thick lacing, a little brown yeast in the middle...(?)  An aroma of fresh bread with some malt.  Malty rye taste with a slight hint of raisin and grapes.  Distinctive Belgian sweetness.  Full-bodied mouthfeel with a lingering palate and sticky aftertaste.  A fine ale, perhaps too much activity in the glass for most though.
Very light and soft for its high alc content. I could have done without the slight sourness at the end, but otherwise an excellent Belgian Strong Ale.
Pours a nice brown color with tan head.  Aroma is very yeasty.  Tastes of chocolate and fruits.  Decent beer, but not as good as I was expecting.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 Pours dark brown with a thick, lasting one finger head.  Aroma of toffe, chocolate, dark fruits, and yeast.  Extremely complex beer with notes of vanilla, toffee, and chocolate.  Has a strong vineous quality.  This beer has a lot going one. Very smooth finish.  Exceptional beer.

One of the best trappist ales I have had.  Dark nut brown poor with a medium sized head.  Crisp finish with out being overly sweet like some competitors.  I can only imagine what the 10 must taste like.

The bottling code on this one was L050912 08:21, indicating a bottling date of September 2007. The 9.20% ABV beer poured a dark (rootbeer) brown, and even with an easy pour developed a thick foamy beige head. Lots of sticky lacing is left as the head drops. The aroma has notes of banana, clove and yeast. The taste of the Rochefort 8 is malty and complex, with hints of vanilla, milk chocolate and brown sugar. Theres a slightly bitter aftertaste though the beer finishes cleanly leaving little behind. The mouthfeel is highly carbonated.
Bottle. Very strong ale. Chocolate flavors, leaning a bit towards the burned side. Spicy. Decent, but not what I was expecting.

Pour down the drain!
I dont know why so many people like these beers? Is it the percentage of alcohol that fuzzes the clear thoughts? The appearance is of a bad dull brown colour which doesnt appeal to the appetite and has a smell of bad yeast. The taste is even more alarming. So I couldnt stand it and even my son, who drinks everything alcoholic couldnt stand it.

Thanks to Karel for sharing. Beautiful burgundy red with medium beautiful lacing tan head. Amazing aroma of dark fruits, caramel, sugar, spice, yeast, sherry, brandy, and alcohol. Beautiful in the mouth. Strong dark fruits again, with brown sugar and molasses throughout. Quite spicy and sweet. Amazing complexity, yet so easy to drink. Very effervescent mouthfeel. This beer is a classic and a must try. My favorite of the Rochefort lineup.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a chocolatey brown with a very good sized fluffy slightly tan head. Not a lot of lacing at all. Aroma is raisins, chocolate malt, banana, molasses, peach. Flavor is ripe fruits, chocolate maltiness, plum, sarsaparilla, ginger. So good. Chewy and sinuous, and crazily drinkable. An awesome beer.
I really liked this one.  In a chalice.  Umm alot like the comparable chimay... but cheaper.  Indulged in too many high end beers that night but this was the finest of the evening.

Fell in love with this beer in Belgium 02 (although must confess cant recall whether it was the 8 or the 10). On trying again in Melbourne recntly, must confess it didnt wow me like then, but I suppose Ive had a lot of great beers in between. Still deliciously chocolatey though with a lovely burnt fruit pudding feel. And while the alcohol is ridiculously prominent, really complements the package.
Nice belgian ale, strong and sweet. Pours dark brown color with frothy head. Nice sweet smell with sweet taste and aftertaste of alcohol. God I love this beer, and I finally rated all the Trappistes!

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2008 Pours brown, not ruby. Sweet nose, aroma of mainly dark sugar and other sweetness.
More carbonated and alcoholic than Rochefort 10 or Chimay Bleue. 
Fantastic mouthfeel.
Would drink again :)
I tasted this beer before I got my account with ratebeer, so I cant really remember all the flavors.

Well this was a pretty bad experience.  Has a terrible biting alcohol taste.  I can only how much worse the 10 would be. Tastes as if somebody dropped a shot of vodka in a Budweiser.  Just not my style at all and I dont see the appeal.  Probably never will.  Palate be damed.....

Freaking fantastic...better than I remembered the 10. Pour was dark brown with just beautiful pillowy head. Head was so nice that I took a break to put my daughters to bed, came back 10 min later and it was still there. Aroma just leapt out of the glass...plums, chocolate. The flavor was as rich and full as a quad, as light and crisp as a trippel. Plums, dark fruit, a touch of chocolate...yet strangely light and refreshing. Mouthfeel was thick, perfect level of carbonation. Truly great!

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a hazy deep plum color with an off white 1/2" head. Not much lacing. Flavors of dark fruits ( raisins, dates, plums ) and some dark chocolate. Some alcohol burn, especially as the brew warms. Pretty good, but I dont see what all the hype is about. At 3.8 I felt I was being generous.

12 oz bottle, served cold into a wide mouth glass (though sadly not a trappist). 

Pours dark cloudy brown with a huge lasting head. Not alot of carbonation, very intense deep flavors, raisens, nuts, fruits. The finish is strong in alchol but warming and the fruit notes linger. Like a fine wine, a really good belgian strong.

From bottle : Pours a cloudy dark brown, with big 2 fingers of white rocky head, that has wonderful staying power.  The aroma is unlike any from a Belgian Strong that i have smelled.  Dark chocolate with alcohol, and a smell of wood that i cant put my finger on what it is for sure.  Sweet fruits start to come out of the aroma has the beer warms a little.  Taste is very mild, not much alcohol burn at all.  Almost a roasted like flavor in the beginning, with dark fruits and some chocolate.  The aftertaste is alcohol and chocolate.  Medium body with a smooth feel in the mouth and going down.

Sötét vörösesbarna enyhén "zavaros"színű barnás fehér habú ital.Illatában egyből érezni az alkohol és az édességét.Gyümölcsös,marcipános,rumos összetett íze van aminek csak a végén érezni a komló keserűjét és az is hamar lecseng.Utóíze is sokáig megmarad ennek az igen testes sörnek.Hideg estéken szépen felmelegít!

mahogany color and unclear look, 
Fruit-like flavour, definetly my favourite beer in the whole world, Good taste, but not too hard, like the rochefort 10, or too soft like the rochefort 6. Alcohol percentage makes sure you dont need to drink a lot of them.

yeasts on bottle, so experts advice to leave it for a month or 2 before opening, so the alcohol percentage rises a bit more...

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Talk about good!  So full yet so delicate - a masterwork that many have noticed.  Nice slightly fruity aromas and palate.  Very gently spiced - not the harsh spices that brewers claim in order to excuse sharpness.  Gives an odd illusion of a glazed meat in its full sweetness.

Bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Pours a mahogany color and very, very cloudy. Persistent head. Aroma of dark fruits and citrus. Tastes like a fine loaf of bread. Malty and sweet and light and effervescent. Excellent!

Very similar to the 10...dark fruits and a wine sweetness on the nose with the dark fruits continuing all through the flavor. Alcohol is not as much as the 10. Overall, while the flavor is not as intense as the 10, this is still a great beer.

33 cL bottle and magnum bottle at Kerstbierfestival 2007. Pours deep brown, slight murky with a light brown head. Aroma is distinct chocolate malty, quite fresh fruity towards citrus fruits and mild yeast. Flavour holds the same distinct fresh citrus fruity hops note (does become a bit cloying towards the end) to a smooth delicate yeasty and malty chocolate malt base. Quite complex yet clearly lighter and more accessible compared to the 10. Ends with a nice lingering fruity and malt driven complex finish.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 Fantastic ale. Smooth finish, great color and head formation. Malt and caramel aroma was very pleasant. One of my favorite drinks.

330ml. bottle. The color is dark brown with a thick beige head and a lot of lace. The aroma is malt and sweet caramel. The taste is also of malt and fruits, like raisin and other dried fruits. The aftertaste is just the right amount of bitterness to make it an almost perfect beer.

Bottle 33cl. Pours dark with almost no head, soft carbonation, strong alcoholic aftertaste, is it because of the unmalted grains in there. Tastes like dark beer with a shot of whiskey. Maybe the bottle isn´t good anymore. Have to re-rate this one another day.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2009 33cl bottle in Rochefort glass. Pours dark brown with a slight tan head. Fruity aroma. Nice lacing. Complex flavor of malts raisins, figs, caramel...great brew. Seems to get better as it warms. My favorite beer so far, cant wait to try the 10.
This beer pours a rich golden brown with a luscious creamy tan head. Wonderful fruity aroma with a spectacular complex flavor. My new favorite!

This beer is one of my favorite.
A dark brown colored beer, with a strong creamy beige head. A fruity aroma and its significantly complex. Tastes of dark malts, yeast, spicy. It has chocolate and toffeeish notes. For this one you can wake me up in the night.

Pours a rich golden brown with hearty tan head.  Nice aroma of fruit and almonds (or hazel nuts?).  Very nice taste of berries, nuts, (caramel?).  Not too sweet, finishes warm and slightly sweet with barely any bitterness.  One of my favorites.
11.2 btl from fuourwinds.pensacola...like a litte leaprachan you got to grab these when you see them...almost a shame to drink it...almost

Poured into my Rochefort goblet. This beer is the color of that brown waterproof wood stain and nearly as thick. Gritty hazy body with a monumental tan head. That famous Belgian lace is everywhere here.

The aroma is really complex. Booze soaked fig, spicecake, brown sugar, and yeast.

Taste is also very complex. Dark malt and yeast provide a foundation while several flavor notes dance upon it, including caramel, raisin, fig, pepper, exotic nuts, caramel, chocolate, and peat.

Mouthfeel takes a hit because its too carbonated. The 6 and the 8 have this problem, while the 10 seems to have it under better control. The carbonation is distracting, yet fine enough to make the beer go down quite smoothly. Great full body.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a brown and unclear beer, with an offwhite and fizzy head. Nice fruity aroma, with notes of raisin and caramel. Very nice balance in the flavor. Flavor is fruity and with notes of nuts. The mouthfeel is heavy, yet refreshing. Overall this beer gives impression of very good and skilled handcraftship and dedication to make good beer.
This is my favorite beer Ive drank to date. Wonderful aroma that you can smell from five feet away. Great full bodied beer.

A dark, cloudy, brown colored beer, with orange-red flashes in the light, topped with a strong, thick, off-white head. A strong perfumed nose, slightly soapy, but with plenty of dark fruit aromas. The taste is sour, again slightly perfumed, definitely floral, rose petal and violet, then sweet fruit flavors, with is accompanied by a strong alcoholic kick that gives a spiciness to the sour finish.

Pours a dark wood color with an off-white frothy head.  Aroma is clean and sweet, not all that complex though.  Flavor is mildly sweet, nutty, try finish, warming.  Not a bad beer, but not nearly as good as I was hoping.
bottle. pours dark with a nice fizzy head. great aroma and a nice rich mouthfeel. has a great punch of flavor to back up its looks and aroma
Bottle. Dark, brown with creamy, white head. Aroma has fruits, raisins, and caramel. A full, rich body. Nice round mouth feel. A very nice beer!

Dark brown with a tall fizzy head that dissipates to a layer of creamy bubbles laying on the top.  Aroma is sweet, lots of dark fruits, some brown sugar, and yeast.  Flavor has a creaminess in the front, plenty of sweet malt, and a caramel finish.  An absolute treat.

Dark nut brown and a thick tan head that slowly went down. Aroma of chocolate and plum, faint alcohol. Bitter finish at first and then at the end mellowed out and was extremely smooth. Moderate carbonation. Nice, but not as good as the 10

Delicious.  Color is a little bit dark muddy and the flavor is not as intense as I had hoped... but this does not disappoint. The aroma is a gentle chocolate/fruit and the flavor lingers sweet.  Easy to appreciate this one.

Was dumped into a trappist glass and foamed right up with a nice sudsy and thick tan head. the color was dark nut brown and a bit cloudy. the aroma is nice and floral, with some hints of dark fruits and mild hops. I personally like the intial fruity and bitter combination. It also has some nice carbonation, but the finish is a bit watery with not much of an after taste.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, dark caramel colour with a bit of sediment. Drink at an almost ambient temperature to unlock the flavours. Enters with notes of maple, raisins, and rounds out to a robust yet sublty fruity bouquet. Easy on the nose with a brilliant smell that entices the palate. Very nice beer.
slightly preferred the 6.  High alcohol blurs some of th edges here, and a little more yeast flavor/aroma comes through as well. darker and fruiter than the 6 as well, loses some of the herbal notes

Bottle.  As a fan of strong belgian ales, I looked forward to trying this beer.  The beer pours a dark, cloudy brown with a thick tan head.  Aromas of plum, chocolate and yeast dominate.  The first swallow might be a bit of a shock, but the beer mellows to a slightly sweet, delicious ale that is perfect for slow, easy drinking with good friends and fine conversation.
Pours hazy dark brown with one inch thick tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit.  Taste of plums, raisins, and chocolate.  Good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2010 Bottle. Pours dark, murky, muddy brown. Plenty of sediment pours out with the last few drops and some rests atop a lasting beige head. The aroma is quite sweet. In the foreground there are plums, raisins, ripe berries, and caramel. Lying a little beneath is chocolate and fresh bread.  The flavor is very subtle and complex, nothing jumps right in your face and demands attention. There is a delicate balance of fruit and chocolate cocoa powder, which combine to make a perfect bittersweet flavor. Yeast and spices are also present, and lead to a refreshing and dry finish.

Dark opaque brown with lots of sediment, off-white medium head that leaves lace. Smells like plum/prune with some alcohol. The taste starts sweet and finishes dry. Alcohol is well-hidden until the very end.
delicius beer. almost as good as the ten. lots of sweetness balanced out with with a nice sweet finish.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 [Rated 1.16.08] Dark mahagany pour with fine head.  Wonderful nutty aroma of cookie dough and a tiny bit of vinegar.  I see why some people like this the best of the three.   More flavor than the 6 but a little more mellow than the 10.  The flavors dont seem to be as deep and complex as the 10 but are still very good.  Lots of sweet and dry nuts, spicy malt, and I do taste a little plum in the finish.  Extremely airy body, slightly sticky finish. Fine carbonation keeps it light and tingly but not too extreme.  Hides the alcohol a lot better than the 10 also.  9.5.9.5.18 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

[Rerated 3.15.09]  So for a mere 1.25 Euro I received a 15cl pour of this at ZBF, who could pass that up?  Unfortunately, everyone who tasted it around me thought it was quite off, a sugary mess, obviously very young, so this begs for a rerate. From bottle,  pours a clear glowing reddish brown that is way too dark to see thru with a small thick fizzy dense patchy froth.  Fantastic aroma, quite rich and doughy, dark fruits, bitter and yeasty draws parallels to the westy.  First taste is very dry with a touch of alcohol, bitter, then sweet and nutty.  This is quite fantastic and Im glad what I tasted at ZBF was not completely representative.   Flavor again has similarities to the westy 8.  As is warms flavors become nearly burnt toffee, candi sugar, alcohol blends nicely, nutty, doughy, with a bitter dark fruit plum yeasty finish, almost licorice. A tad too much alcohol and flavors maybe too subdued.  Full mouthful, medium/full body with sharp abundant medium fluffy carbonation, a bit too airy at first but then it settles down.  Im starting to think that I actually like the 6 the best??? oy (I have a few aging so maybe itll make its way back into my top 10 in good time)
9.5.9.4.17 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .[rerate L# 250613 which would make this a mid 2008 bottle, so about a 1 1/2 old, opened 1.15.10]  Okay, so this is really one of my first experiences with aged Trappist beers and I can start to see the way this is going to work... I assume this might be similar to a barley wine situation... have to get them over that harsh oxidation hump... maybe.  Seems to bit sweeter and quite round, fruity, near cloying, less character than before, enormous amounts tobacco in both the aroma and flavor.  Lots of protein floaties. The body on this aged 8 is absolutely perfect, fluffy, full, medium viscous, great soft abundant carbonation... really nice.  Much better as is warms, the tobacco is so interesting but its all starting to brighten up a bit and it actually pretty damn tasty.
Beautiful carmel head that lingers.  Sweet plum with a slight orange spice .  I really like this beer I cant wait to try the 10.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Poured from a bottle.  Poured a deep brown color with nice rising bubbles with a thick beige head that left nice lacing.  Aroma of spicy yeast, some fruits including plums and some a bit of orange, finishing with a hint of brown sugar.    Nice smooth, semi-molasses sweet entry that leads into a yeasty finish with various dark fruits coming out .  Nice and smooth.  Definitely a nice beer.

330ml bottle 
9.2% ABV 
The beer was clearly marked 9.2% as opposed to 9.3%.  I tried this beer on December 28, 2007 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto.  The beer poured a dark brown with a huge generous brown head that lasted and lasted.  The aroma was very yeasty with some dark fruits and spices.  The mouthfeel was full bodied with some mild carbonation.  The flavour was very malty followed by some yeasty tones.  A very good beer, but not as good as the 10

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 330 mL bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown with large light brown head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, with hints of fruit and maybe bubble gum or candy.  Flavor is complex, with tastes the same as in the aroma.  Mouthfeel is fizzy and smooth.  Well-balanced body that finishes remarkably clean and smooth considering the alcohol content.
This beer is for 90% the same like the 10. Just more alcohol. Very good beer!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Pours chocolate brown, almost opaque, with a thick, enduring head. Intricate lacing all the way down.
Aroma is of cherries, yeast, and certainly some alcohol.
Some fruity flavors - raisins, plums, figs - and yes, more alcohol.
Carbonation seems to dance on the tongue, then its a silky smooth ride.
This is truly a special experience. Treat yourself.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark reddish-brown with a pillowy off-white head.  Aroma is raisins, candi sugar, coffee, chocolate.  Flavors are raisins, candi sugar, coffee, chocolate, crystal malts, vinous, and some plum/dark cherry.  Very smooth.

Very cloudy burnt caramel color with a monstrous off-white head that never escapes the glass.  Tons of sediment, even on the first pour...and the aroma is of dark fruit, brown sugar, and red wine.   Plum and cherry notes give way to a peppery finish.  Smooth and extremely drinkable, this is a great Trappist brew!!!

Pours a dark mahogany brown with a thin short lived beige head. The aroma is deep and complex, with notes of fruit, spice, chocolate, toffee, and big notes of licorice. Flavours are just as complex, with fruit and toffee sweetness upfront, a bit of chocolate, and then a strong licorice finish. The thing that really holds this beer back is the palate, is just found it a little thin, and watery to be holding all those flavours. I like this beer, but I was expecting more.

Huge, rocky, beige head atop a cloudy, reddish brown body with excellent lacing.  Yeasty, dark fruit aroma followed by caramel malt and mild spiciness.  Continually evolving taste; from the soft, chocolatey  malt to the fruity, vinous, toffeeish flavors.  Full bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel leading to a prolonged finish with an alcohol punch that creeps up on the unsuspecting.

Pours a muddy brown colour with thin white head. Aroma is sweet, candied fruits and bubblegum. Fairly lively carbonation on the tongue leads to the beer foaming up in the mouth releasing flavours that are of dark, sweet fruits and floral notes. The aftertaste is fairly clean but the alcohol does start to dominate a little too much in the end.
I DONT KNOW HOW BEER CAN GET ANY BETTER THAN THIS! POURS DARK WITH LARGE CREAMY HEAD GREAT HEAD WITH SWEET CITRUS NOSE. THIS IS THE SMOOTHEST AND MOST CREAMY BEER I HAVE TASTED FROM BELGIUM.
11.2 oz bottle, pours dark brown with thick foamy head.  Incredibly smooth, no alcohol taste present.

pours a dark brown with a long lasting foamy head with brown swirles.  almost no scent.  very very smooth going down.  full body with a smooth creamy texture.  slight after taste of caramel.  Overall one of the best I have had.
Bottle from Bodegas. Wine taste with some raisins. Smooth beer cannot taste the alcohol in it. Definitely would buy again.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Purchased at Bodega Brewpub in La Crosse, Wisconsin.  Poured a dark amber golden with a long lasting light brown/amber head.  Tastes of wine, fruit, light hop, and flowers.  Real smooth beer hiding alcohol reasonably well.  Would buy again for sure.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2008 330 ml bottle. Beautiful cloudy brown appearance with a huge foamy head. The nose is beautiful creamy nuts and liqueric herbal perfume, some roasted grains. The flavour is very characteristic and complex, behind the roasted malts and coffe are some yeast and fruits, may be a little honey. Light carbonation. Nice aftertaste.

Pours a nearly-opaque cola brown with a huge, bubbly tan head. The aroma springs forth as soon as the bottle is opened: lots of fruit, toffee and yeast, with some spicy alcohol and grassy hops. The taste has more fruit, brown sugar and yeast, with a surprising amount of herbal hops and spicy alcohol on the finish. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and creamy, with light carbonation

Poured a cloudy brown with a huge billowing and long lasting head. The aroma is full of old fruit, yeast, and milk chocolate. The taste is nice, smooth as silk, and blending sour fruit, apple, honey, and malt. It is warming throughout, but masked and not in a way that really stands out. Very nice.
A beautiful complex beer of with a balanced sweetness, warming alcohol and heady aroma of dried fruits with a slight bready taste of the yeast coming through.

11.2 oz. brown, longneck bottle. fresh before 08.16.12. Very fresh sample. Poured out a deep reddish brown color, with a voluminous tan colored head. Very carbonated and lively. Aromas are of dry straw, dried figs, fruity esters abound. Flavors are of dried fruits, biscuit malt, slight hops. Medium mouthfeel, not too thick or thin.
Finished somewhat dry & straw like.
Decent Trappist overall.
Tasted with the #6, this is a little more pungent.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2008 330ml bottle (Bon Vivant, Riga)
Little brother to 10, very similar. The maltiness was more burnt, the mouthfeel was fizzier, and the taste had more dominant apple. At the same price - always buy the 10!
(6-5-8-4-16=3.9)
Rerate: (8-5-8-4-16=4.1)
Blind tasting (against Westvleteren 12, St. Bernardus Abt 12, Rochefort 10, and Chimay Blue)
Big flowery perfumey aroma. Soft carbonation, silky smooth palate, no alcohol at all. Very gentle mix of rich malts and a touch of perfume. Low bitterness. Incredibly drinkable.
Came 2nd out of the 5, second only to its big brother.
bottle, about 1 year old. Reddish dark brwon colour, large head. Full-bodied, hints of wild berries, caramel and coffee. Very intensive and lingering finish. A superb brew.

Maybe it was the hype of the name, but I just wasnt as knocked out by this beer as I expected.  It is no doubt a solid brew, with a gorgeous fluffy head that stays to just cover the beer and add some lacing.  I didnt really get a lot of different flavors in this.  It was simply a good, straightforward beer for the most part.  My wife sampled it and likened it to beef stew with a heavy dose of cooked carrots.  I didnt exactly agree, but think it would pair really well with that meal.  This beer does have an exceptional mouthfeel.  The amount of malt sweetness, carbonation, and hops are perfect.  It is so smooth for this high of an ABV.  You dont notice the alcohol in the taste, but you sure feel it in your head.  This is an extremely drinkable beer for this high of an alcohol content.  It is no doubt a world class brew, but it wasnt my particular favorite.  I did drink it by itself at around lunch time.  Maybe like Chimay Blue with barbecue, it really shines with a meal?  Again, not my favorite, but certainly worth a try, and definitely brewed with love.
