Nice aroma of caramel with a earthy (soil) touch, light spices, very light yeast. Soft mouthfeel, the body starts to thin; very good malt and caramel flavor, with light nuttiness, low bitterness, and comforting alcohol feeling. In the final there is some rare sweetness, a fine spicy touch, and a shade of oxidization.Mature, very good.2013-02-12, L 060606, 11½ years old, 7-4-7-3-15=36Chestnut color, with small sized head, not as compact. Mild aroma, caramel and light honey. Lean body, with some caramel flavor, very low residual sweetness, almost absent bitterness, some alcohol, very light fruity touch.Apparently the last sugars have been fermented; its a simple version of the original beer, still pleasant and with just minimal signs of Madeirization.Should be drank with the yeast deposit that increases the mouthfeel and provides very light final astringency (one point extra).2011-08-30, L 100215 10:17, 1½ years old, 8-5-7-4-15=39The aroma is almost cheesy, with brown sugar, caramel. The body is lean; there is caramel flavor, with moderate sweetness, and light liquorice impression; apparently its not mature enough. Low bitterness, and light alcohol perception too. Lacking of depth.2011-05-03, L 220715 10:38, 1 year old, 7-4-7-3-14=35Its overly carbonated, it pours a gigantic head. Initially there is some yeast smell; later followed by the expected caramel. Having lost most of the carbonation, the mouthfeel is quite soft, but the body is thinner than expected; good flavor, some malt and caramel, maybe with too much accent on the oxidization; traces of liquorice. The bitterness is already quite low, and the final is rather weak. Good Belgian, but nothing special (yet).2011-02-25, L 200912 10:30, 4 years old, 8-5-8-3-16=40Very dark brown color; generous head, reducing to a thinner layer, compact and persistent. The aroma is unusually spicy, peppery, with some malt and caramel, and Chinotto (a special citrus fruit from Liguria). The mouthfeel is very smooth (because of the initial high carbonation), then round (a bit later); there is a good flavor of malt and caramel, with clear spicy side; correct bitterness. It seems to get thinner and a bit drier in the end. Good, but it could be better.2011-01-08, L 060606, 10 years old, 7-4-6-3-12=32Dark chestnut color; small sized head. The aroma of caramel is nice and quite perfumy. The mouthfeel is quite dry and with an evident alcohol presence; the body is thin; flavor of dry caramel and some liquorice; light oxidisation. Correct bitterness. Too old.2003-05-08, 8-5-9-4-17=43Dark amber color. Aroma of malt, bread, candi sugar, lightly fruity (strawberries). Malty, not really viscous, a delicate but evident liquorice taste at the mid-end, alcohol touch. Good but not astonishing palate. I dont know exactly why, but I expected moreImproves a lot when pouring the sediment.

Cloudy brown, dense,long lasting beige head.Nose of brandy, malt,berries.Softly carbonated complex malt taste with light fruit and medium alcohol heat
This one is a keeper!!

Fantastic finely bubbled head of immense proportions atop a slightly murky red coffee colour.  Spicy aroma, a little peppery and sweet. Chocolate, nutmeg, pimento, molasses flavours are all much easier to define than they are in the jumble of vinous flavours and alcohol in the 10. Great, full mouthfeel, but a little syrupy  and a tad sweet.

Dark ruby brown witha nice off white full foamy head.  Nice restrained fruit aroma with juicy adicness.  Semi sweet malty fruity flavor with a nice crisp acid finish.  Juicy and refreshing.  Good silky mouthfeel.

This beer pours a murky dark brown color with a small head. The aroma had a lot of different things in it, but nothing I could pick out.  This is the best beer I've ever had.  It smells great and it tastes great.  The aftertaste is even better than the flavor.  Very smooth and completely satisfying.  I have been waiting months to try this beer and it was worth the wait.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2012 this was a surprise and a bit special. The aroma was a bit complex with hints of chocolate, malt and fruits. The taste was smooth, reminded me of sweets cocoa and malt, very very good, could not feel the alcahol, very nice beer, something to have again and maybe re-rate. I had Kwak before this and maybe that taste was screwing it a bit up.. thanks Eirikur!

re-rate 1-8-2012
fruits, yeast and spices in the aroma. Dark brown. Bit yeasty, some candy sugar, not as spectacular as I remembered, good nonetheless. I would also add that if this beer would be made by some other brewery and not bare this name, it would not rate this highly on this site

Thanks to Darkover for the trade. This wasn't quite as good as the "10" but still a very good beer. Pours a pretty dark reddish-brown with a very thick and foamy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, cherry, malt and cloves. Smooth-drinking, with flavors of banana, malt, sherry and chocolate all vying for attention. Great finish, if a little carbonated toward the end for my tastes. All in all another fine effort from Rochefort.
(33cl Bottle) Creamy, foamed, almond head and a cloudy dark brown body. Orange peel, spice and barley nose. Flavourful citrus with cloves. Full, smooth alcoholic finish with excellent malt and cocoa.

One of my favorite! Pours well not much nose, but as you bring it to your mouth the experiance begins! Starts off fruity and then ends with a beautiful chocolate taste that just gets better as it gets warmer. This is Dessert!
A world class beer!  It had it all.....full of flavor, body, alcohol notes....it all came together perfectly.

Perfect looking Belgian...dark ruby color with a thick beige head. The aroma was an intense fruitiness with subtle chocolate and alcohol. The flavor burst out with many fruits...berries, banana, plum...too many to name! The finish was where the alcohol came in. It left a nice warmth in the throat. Great beer.

Bottle from trade with jbrus.  Okay, so I'm rating this the same as I did Rochefort-10.  Not sure if it's because I really think it's as good, or because I was less experienced when I drank the other Belgian heavyweights, but this stuff is great!  Dark brown appearance with very small amounts of yeasties.  Delicious chocolate and caramel in the flavor along with some pears and plum.  The flavor could be perhaps amplified a little but that's my only complaint.  Classy mouthfeel.  Nice!!  Thanks to jbrus.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2003 Very musky like the 10 but a bit more dingy. This tastes as though it were stored in a very damp/dark place for a while longer than the 10. Damn, I feel like there is some class I need to take before I can really analyze this malt...so much happening here: currant, peat, mushroom, spice, and lots more. I wish I had more time to sit here and figure this out. Malty magnificance.
Very drinkable and approchable. Lots of fruity and floral flavors going on. Couldn't taste the alcohol at all. Everything you would expect from this brewer. Excellent concoction.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2003 Great beer. the taste is sharper than Westvleteren, very nice.
Very malty flavour, a bit fruity, and full bodied sweet beer.
it is quite fizzy and this is one of the best beer that i have ever tasted.

Creamy thin medium lasting beige head. Brown cloudy color. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity with light spicy notes. Flavour is malty too with ricolice and fruity tones (banana, orange) ending in a not too long candy sugar finish. Full bodied.

Rich dark brown, almost opaque appearance.  Complex rich milk chocolate and sweet plum aroma.  Flavor does not quite meet the expectations I had from the aroma.  Semi-sweet lightly bitter body finishes with some light roastedness toward the finish.  Definite warming effect on the throat, but not much noticeable alcohol flavor.  I think this beer would improve with some age.

A lovely Belgian Strong. Pours nicely with a thick, bubbly off-white head. The scent is excellent with plums and other fruits. The alcohol is well-hidden and the beer flows nicely over the tongue, tickling it with it's perfect carbonation. Oh, this beer simply defines the genre. Try it with some good belgian chocolate, it will amaze you! God, I love this beer, I've got to get some more.

Cloudy brown color with a thick dark head. A plum/raisin scent. Slightly vinous, as I've come to expect from this style. Some other subtle fruit tastes swirl around as well. The alcohol is very well hidden. I see why this beer is so well regarded.

Nice deep ruby color,fresh clean alochol,flavours of raisins,fruits, plums,figs.This is extremely complex not up to their 10 though still a desirable Ale, time for some US brewery to start making this type Ale, Highly Recommended

Dark copper brown in color.  Carbonation creates a large head that took a while to subside.  Alcohol present intitially and it has an almost liquer-characteristic to it.  This includes lots of fruits, cloves, and a creamy cocoa/coffee profile.  Not as good as I was expecting, to be honest, but a worthwhile beer.

Body is dark red and brown.  Big head typical of the trappist ales.  Aroma of brandy, cherry and other dark fruits.  Flavour is quite alcohol dominated but the fruit does a decent job of dealing with this.  A lot of malt to this beer as well.  Finish is tangy and nice.

Extremely seductive aroma, full of plums and the rochefort house character, which to me is more in the aroma than in the flavor.  Flavor is slightly less complex than its big brother, but the beer is tighter and more coherent.  Perilously drinkable and emminently delicious.
Copper-brown, creamy head.  Very little carbonation.  Some sediment, just the right amount.  Smooth, oh so smooth.  Bananas and cloves in the flavor.  I think the 9.3% is concealed very well.

Deep brown color with a small amount of head. Smells very malty, some pepper, kind of like the ocean.  Some of the 9.3 is noticable, very nice yeasty flavor with malts that taste like black forest chocolate cake.

Hmmmmmm.  Not what I expected.  Pours a minimal head with decent carbonation.  Aroma of heavy malt, chocolate and alcohol with a touch of yeast and other aromas.  Color of watery chocolate brown.  Flavor is slightly  mellow with tones of alcohol and maybe black cherry.  Not as complex as some of the other trappists.  Finish is slightly creamy and fizzy with a slight lingering alcohol presence.  A very good beer but not as good as some of the other trappists.  A little on the thin side but will have to try the 10 to compare.  As with all trappists, very complex in their tastes and aromas and need to be tried by everyone.
Inky brown pour same sticky white head as 6 and 10. Very strong yeasty aroma. Flavors not as sublime as 6, of the two I actually like 6 better. Nice long finish.
This Trappist beer is the best I have ever tasted. The dark colour is nice, nice head and a very good flavor.

Dark red/brown. Small short head. Smells of brandy, berries and chocolate. lots of carbonation in the mouth. Dark fruit, plum, toffee? Malty. Lots of alcohol apparent. Finishes slightly hoppy and WARM!! Nice!

Dark ruby red in color with a small tan head.  Aroma is of fruit/spices/ and malt, very complex.  Taste is like the 10 without the overpowering alcohol.  The figs/chocolate/coffee taste are very creamy. I found this superior to the 10, it was not as forceful in its presentation or taste, it allowed the aroma and flavors to enhance the alcohol rather than be overpowered by it like the 10.
Powerful, powerful flavor with a strong bitter 'ping' throughout.  Smooth and creaming going down.  Extraordinary brew.  Looking forward to getting ahold of some of the 10.

Beautiful cloudy medium brown ale with a tan head and great lacing on the glass.  Aroma of malt and chocolate.  Taste of dark malk, chocolate, yeast, bitter coffee, and a sour ale finish.  Alcohol is not pronounced  I was surprised that it was over 9%.  I like it, but the 10 is significantly better, which is why I have a case of the 10 in the cellar.

Pours a very cloudy, dark brown color with a big off-white head that lingers. The yeast particles floating in the beer are as pronounced as the 6. It has a subdued aroma of malts and fruits, with some yeats and a slight hint of spices. Full bodied and very smooth, the flavor is malty and spicy, with a long malty finish with hints of fruit and a slight mustiness. Alcohol is well hidden. Very nice, and better than the 6, but not quite as good as the 10.

10 dollars. Yes the beer store i frequent finally grew wise to their stock. I remember buying the 10 for 6 dollars and now its been ballooned up to 12. Its well known that i wasnt fond of the 10...however the experience of the 8 well makes up for it as the beer gods sprinkled their countenance upon me in the form of liquid orgasm. Figgy, bubblegum nose and the taste was no different...like bananas and bubblegum. A tad hihg on the carbonation and extra bubbly mouth feel. The alcohol is not even an issue as it's like a phantom...invisible to all your senses until it creeps up inside your blood stream and makes you do horrible, strange things. I'm loving these doubles, they're far mroe suited to my tastes.

This beer poured a very dark amber and formed a light tan head that left circular lace. There were small particles present due to the bottle conditioning. A heavy aroma of malt and caramel with a hint of citrus. A flavor of malt and caramel. A slight tang to the finish is present.

The little brother of the Rocherfort 10 does good.  Especially when I'm putting these back at $2 Euro/each.  Can't beat the price and the flavor is ridiculously good.  Liquid chocolate with mild spices.  Not as robust as the 10 but very enjoyable.
Nice copper, hazy color.  Very inviting sweet aroma.  Head was full with tan color.  Nice fruity hints.  Plum?  Very creamy on the palate.  Highly enjoyable.
Nice tight tan head with lacing that is there till the end.Hazey copper color. Nose is slightly spicey, yeasty.Medium bodied with a bready yeasty taste. Creamy palate with a decent finish.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2005 Reddish Brow in color.  Malty aroma.  I dont taste a lot of difference between this and number 10.  I taste fruity sweetness along with a warm alcohol flavor.  Excellent brew!
UPDATED: MAR 2, 2006 Dark brown and opaque with a big tan head. Aroma of malt and berries. Flavor of dark fruits and raisons.

09 10 07: Has to be my favorite Trappist to look at. A beautiful,dark,red with a tough,big,creamy, lasting,almost tan, head. Aromas are intenesly fruity,musty,sweet and become super musty after a while. Mouthfeel is thick but not as carbonated as I was expecting. Big body. Fruity,sweet flavors with a sweet finish as well(at first),before becoming musty. The fruity-sweet flavors are dark and somewhat port like. This is probably my fave from this brewer,being the alcohol is hidden,unlike the big brother!
Dry, robust flavor, full of raisins and caramel.  Nice winter warmer.

Looks pretty much identical to the 10, deep ruby color.  The smell is yeasty, sweat and fruity.  There are a lot of subtle notes in the flavor - apples, chocolate, grapes, raisins.  This has very well-masked alcohol.  Slightly different from the 10, but, in my opinion, just as good.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 Much more drinkable than the 10, but still looks and acts like rootbeer.  Smells is grand though.  Sweet dry fruity taste with peppery finish.  Love this one.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Coffeeish colour. The aroma is strange and quite disgusting. Too acid.
This is absolutely delicious beer.  I dont even know how to describe it, it just tastes so damn good!  I have to revisit the 10.  Right now I like this even better.

a morbid mass of dark plum and elemental living froth of almost pinkish hue..tart grape skies and musty old buildings have hints of acidic tart green olives..i sit impatient waiting for the high foam to shrink and so I bite a chunk out of the head, like a peice of cake..and i chew its chocolatey grape existence..the wetness turns to musty grapes and fermenting apples..my mind turns tart..a stream of chocolate flows rapidly..the musty surroundings shake..the alcohol relieves my stress..the warmth loosens my senses..things begin to fall in place..

Ruddy brown color, smell of malt, brandy and dark cherry.  Little head.  Great carbonation / fuzzyness on the tounge.  Flavors are pretty well balanced between malt, dark fruit and alcohol.
Excellent.
Great aroma and wonderful head retention. Smell of fruits and well hidden alcohol. One of the best Ive had in a long time.
Wonderful Trappist. Delightfully complex and full of flavor. You can tell that a lot of time and precision went into the creation of this brew. A gift from the gods!

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2014 Where and how:  LCBO, bottle 330 ml
Aroma quiet Belgian, softer than most. Floral, hint of vanilla, red apple and chamomile. Molasses with herbal hops. Rounded with Belgian phenolic yeast vibe.
 Appearance :
Top: large lasting tanned cap, rings with lace.
Base: hazy amber.
Palate :  medium bodied with lighter but not this walls. Nice bite to it (top end). 
Taste: wow. One of those "wow" beers. Seemingly just solid and after second you will realize that this is no ordinary Belgian. Soft with bubbly dryness. Silky texture with prickly heat of alcohol. All in perfect balance.
 Other notes  who says you need bold beer to be top notch?
2002 review 
Another great classic that I had chance of trying tonight. The aroma was friendly to me, slightly warm. Outside was getting dark, Christmas lights were on. The cloudy amber type look, the white head on the top, the snow outside on the street. Flavour was full of intensivity, full of complexity. There was some bitterness, some marzipan sweetness. You could notice some dry fruits as well. Very complex yet specific. Overall nicely balanced.

When pouring this beer in my glass the aroma is strong and heavy, fruits, sweet and chocolate, a beautifull head develops which remains till the beer has vanished into my body. I noticed that while drinking, the beautifull head actually cleans the glass. Remarkable...The taste is definately good, but certainly not as complex as its big brother, the number 10. Though its well balanced just like the 10. Sweet taste, alchol well masked, just in the finished its better noticed. palate could be better. Overall great!

This is the first Trappist product that I have not been disapointed by.  Generally, I find that the Trappist Ales, for whatever reason, just cant live up to the hype.  Although I had some carbonation problems, this one was quite good.  Incredible peppery, cinnamony aroma.  It was overcarbonated on the pour, but once it settled down it seemed to be OK.  Deep brown colour that turns to a magnificient glowing orange when held up to the light.  Immense, rocky, beige head.  Beatiful balance: failry sweet and fruity (I taste banana)at the begining, with a bitterness and warmth developing late.
What to say...a great beer!!!

Overly indulgent aroma, reminds me of a whole bunch of different desserts at once -- chocolate cream pie, carrot cake, chocolate torte, caramel, freshly baked eclair, vanilla pudding, and starts to show a little alcohol as it warms...truly incredible.  Deep, dark opaque red-brown in color, very solid-looking, with a fluffy, tan head, large bubbles.  Flavor is appropriately complex, with a large amount of milk chocolate sweetness, spice cake and fresh, doughy bread.  Finish is tangy, nutty, faintly fruity (tangerine??) yeasty, lightly alcoholic and longer than long.  Wondrous development, subtle nuances reveal themselves continously.  This is just a valuable work of art in liquid form.
Has a standard to live up to and does so very nicely.  Looks great in the glass and the head is perfect.

Strong aromas of dark chocolate and wheat bread.A bit sour with warming alcohol at first then flavors of fresh dark bread, brown sugar,bitter chocolate with a mild bitter sour finish.Lingering yeasty aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2004 And another update:  I tasted this side by side with St. Bernardus Prior 8.  Rochefort is a lot less viscous in comparison, but I think this actually helps me identify the complex flavors a bit more easily.  This sample had a lot of cigar-tobacco flavors which I liked quite a bit.  Update:  Elegant and restrained banana, clove, wood and grape aromas and flavors in the perfect smooth, creamy body.  I rather like how nicely the esters are restained (banana can become too much).  Hugely complex with an astonishingly long finish.

Old:  I have zero interest in being an iconoclast, but I simply could not find enough flavor in this beer to give it very high marks.  It is rather nice and well balanced with acidic tartness providing a nice finish.  Head lasts throughout.  I fear that I am simply blind to the charms of the Belgians.  Used to love them.
Its there with the 10 among the best beers in the world.

Best B4 10.09.07,33cl.:
Saturated brown color. Giant pillowy head with no signs of retreat. Smell of sloe gin and Concorde grapes with a hint of vinegar. Scent of the produce dept. A touch of brewed green tea and sour milk. Faint pineapple aroma. Chocolate and supple leather flavors joined with melon and berries. Cantaloupe joining in. Pineapple flavor? Cappuccino froth lace work. Great malt flavors. Creamy feel on the tongue transforms into a subtle alcohol bite. Chocolate and fruit flavors perk-o-late into the sinus. Front of the tongue left dry with every sip. Long dry finish. Wish it was 3/4L.

Cloudy dark brown w/ amber hue & large, fizzy head. Sweet fruity nose (cherries? brandied plums) w/ hints of chocolate & spice. Light, somewhat effervescent feel. Moderately sweet w/ a hint of sourness. Flavours are chocolatey, fruity, spicy, and alcoholic. Nice complexity and well balanced.
not perfect but a great trappist.

Soft nose, spicy fruit and chocolate malt flavor. Incredible smooth finish with drawn out fruit flavor, slight hint of melon. Could be a little more complex in the malt body but the perfect finish earns big points here for me. Better than the 10.

Deep brown body. White head, diminishing.
Malty and sour, at the same time.
Alcohol apparent. Citrus undertones...
For the price I payed, well worth it.
Cottony mouthfeel. Aroma and flavor are scuppernong grape fruitiness and alcohol. A lighter and softer beer than its big brother.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2006 rer8 (for the first time in years): this is a very young bottle (BB2011) and i was astonished to be able to smell hops! in a rochefort! vanilla-y, floral styrian smells. that plus the delicious fruity and doughy rochefort yeast and dark malts only minus the alcohol of the 10 makes it pretty much perfect aromawise. in the mouth theres roasted nuts, prunes, marzipan, melanoidins, and some warming alcohol. doesnt have the length of the 10, or the fatness of flavour. but it is extremely drinkable for a 9%er - very light and balanced. i dont know how to express that in numbers but i think im going to have to rank it lower than the 10. (as if theyre competing?!)
Soft brown, poured with a thick head that slowly faded til the end.  Sweet bing cherry malt, toffee.  Effervesent yet soft on the palate.  finished with a dry, light sweetness.
Whats to say - just a great beer. Just a notch below the 10
Cloudy brown color.  Aroma is of dark malt, yeast, fruit and some organic notes.  Alcohol is present.  Dark fruit, spice, pepper notes and nice, welcome hop bitterness.  Nice trappist ale.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2004 Great stuff just a notch below the 10.  This ale has a spicy,malt and fruit flavor.  The alcohol is well hidden for over 9%.  A very drinkable ale.  Recommended

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2008 Bottle... This beer rocks!... The aroma is incredible. So many things within the nose. Malt, spice, alcohol, citris and dark fruits, dried apricot and cocoa. This hazy, dark amber ale has a large, off-white, rocky head. Excellent lacing. The flavor is complex. Malty and sweet with hints of salt, dark fruits and spices up front. Lightly bitter and pungent on the backside. Warm alcohol flavor massages the the throat and chest. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Long bittersweet, dry finish. Excellent Belgian ale!
pours hazy brown with a noisy beige head.  fruity, chocolatey, alcoholic aroma.  more chocolate, berries and big malt in the flavour.  slow burn finish lingers.  very nice.
Looks just as Maredsous 8.  But its smells quite different.  It has a very good aroma indeed, very mixed.  Satisfyng flavour, little bit spicy.  Very nice palate.

Updated: Light plummy aroma.  Metallic?  Dark cloudy brown - near opaque, large stiff head.  Strong and easy.  Complex nutty caramel and plum flavors.  So smooth with a kiss of lip-smacking dessert wine sweetness that I couldnt put it down.  Warming finish.
A great beer. It contains all the aroma and flavours of the #10, but in a mild and smoot yet powerful way. You can drink a lot more of these than you can drink Rochefort 10.

Murky brown with a 3/4 inch tan head. Aroma is very brandyish. Raisins,plums,chocolate and spice. This is a brew you could just sniff for hours. First sip reveals that the alcohol that is so obvious in the 10 is well hidden in the 8.Flavors just blend and swirl on the tongue. I think the flavors and such have all been covered by those more verbose than me so I wont even try.Definately a world class beer. Almost forgot to thank hopsrus for this one.

#400 here boys. Hazy dark copper/red. Thin head and lace. Wonderful nose of liquor, fruit, cookie dough, spices and others. Mostly thin to medium body with a boatload of flavors. Caramel like sweetness followed by doughy malt sprinkled with spices (corriander and maybe ginger), alcohol flavors galore but not as overpowering as the 10, reminds me of a chocolate rumball. Fairly dry finish from alcohol with the ending yeast adding thickness and addional spicyness. If this had a bit more body,(flavors would be carried better) I think this could be world class, as it stands, not worth its hefty price IMHO.
dark red/brown color w/ a large tan head. Aroma of a wonderful bakery. lots of alcohol in the flavor

Dark reddish color, darker than the six.  Thick head quickly disappears.  Sweet nose with a balance of malt and bouncy fruits.  Thick roasted, coffee, chocolate taste.  The alcohol gives it an added whiskey-style kick.
Some sugary, caramelized taste in there, along with a strong alcohol kick.  Very nice--smooth yet rough, ya know?
Very good. I love Rochefort. God, I love Rochefort. This one had a blast of alcohol on first sip but mellowed out quite nicely. First beer of the day, ya know?
UPDATED: DEC 14, 2006 A complex beer in the style of its stronger brother, but easier to drink. Good.

(BB 11/10/04) Very expressive bouquet. Very spicy, perhaps hallertau. In addition to the hop nose I detect abundant fruit, candi sugar, and malt. The head is excellent and long lasting. The color reminds me of a tawny port. The carbonation level is very high, almost like champagne. The alcohol is well hidden. This brew is abundant with esters. I am almost drinking this beer too fast. It finishes long, sweet, fruity, and spicy. Rochefort 8 is a very good beer that must be tried by every serious beer enthusiast; it has all the classic Trappist characteristics. The one minor flaw maybe over carbonation.

I really enjoy the Rochefort brews, and am thrilled that theese comes in more than one version. Never the less, I found this one a bit less complex than the no. 10. The alcohol and the vinous caracter is not as strong by this one. Although it has a beautiful body with a creamy head too, the flavour is not as full as the no. 10. It has a quite bitter finish (almonds?) and a warm and intense aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2004 I am a   fan of big dark beers such as Baltic Porters, Sri Lanka's Lion Stout, any Imperial Stout, a good vintage Ale such as that produced by Traquair, and almost anything by the Titanic brewery, but I do have a little problem with the Trappist ales of Belgium. It's not that I don't enjoy them, it's just that the praise they get seems absurd when they are compared with some of the ales I have mentioned above. But this - a product of the lesser known and more difficult to get of the five breweries - is certainly a handsome beer. Full of dark flavours and aromas such as chocolate, port, red fruits, enlived with (in my young bottle - bought and laid down a mere 6 months ago) a gentle fizz or life. The after-taste is surprising dry - almost dusty or chalky, which contrasts well with the alcohol fruit of the nose. The alcohol intrudes a bit, but in an all embracing, gentle and benign manner, and not as much as one would expect from a 9.2% abv. Mix the yeast in and it produces an invigorating explosion of flavours that is quite exciting. It's a damn good beer, but does it live up to the hype? Mine is still five years from it's best before date, and it's bloody good now - but it's not the nectar of the gods. It's a good beer, quite heady, flavoursome, soft and very enjoyable (and moreish - I wish I another one!) - but one of the best beers in the world? Mmmmm. Could well be. Yes. Could well be! [4.4]  Part of the Tripel Taste Test. Conclusion: This one was the most interesting and involved. The dark bitterness was not welcoming, and this was not as attractive a drink as, say, the Floreffe, but it did reveal more.

Had a few of these in the cellar for a couple of years, and I thought Id make this number 400! Chocolate, caramel, brown sugar aroma. Hazy pomegranate in colour, big, noisy, creamy, toffee head, some floaties. Plums, almonds, dark brown bread, black cherries, and towards the middle, chocolate. Complex, an incredible range of flavours, bitter after taste, wonderful mouthfeel. Lace is very long lasting. Great tongue tingle and dry at the finish. A marvelous beer,an incredible privelege!

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2006 Rerate: what a godlike fluid this is! Dark color, with longlasting firm head. Bready, malty aroma, with hints of chocolate. Malty taste, chocolate. Long lingering palate. Hoping it to last forever...

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2004 Bottled: Rerate: Is definately a more complex beer, than i first thought. Pours dark brown with a huge off-white head. Has a sweet and spicy aroma with notes of caramel and plums. Flavour is sweet and well-balanced and the high ABV isn't as obvious, as I experienced first time I had it. Rating 23.8.02: (3,6)Had this after a supreme dinner topped with a good Cohiba cigar, a cognac and a double expresso. It migth be the reason that I was a little disappointed. Has a dark brownish colour and a good chocolate head. The head dissappeared quicker than expected. The aroma (mostly chocolate) was a little vague, but again it might be due to the dinner(cigar!!). The flavour had distinct accents of chocolate and was pleasant, but maybe a little too alcoholic. Has to rerate this under other circumstances.
Like it.  All the trappistes are unique, but this one seems more unique than most.  Very complex and smooth.
Very nice fruity aromas, with hints of chocolate on the toungue.  Wonderful.
Very seasoned and fruty a very complex beer. I had this at the official shop "Hubert". 1,5€ for one. This was great. It cant reach the 10!
A great color, lots of malt, fruit and a little spice.  The only Trappist to add spices, they "...take a little corriender".  Brother Antoine at Achel was the brewer at Rochefort.

Dark burgundy, brown head with complex fruit flavors I cant begin to identify. The flavor has some evidence of alcohol, but its so smooth, and at only 1.75$pounds in England(probably 3.00$ u.s) I dont know why I drank anything else! Awesome!
Dark red-brown color, brandy like aroma of chocolate and plums,creamy mouthfeel. I bought this bottle in June, worth saving for #500.
A dark brown beer with a good head. The aroma has fruity and chocolate notes. And the flavor is very complex with notes of fruit and chocolate. A fantastic beer that I enjoy drinking again and again.

Dark brown with ruby red hints, big bubbly beige head.  Powdery nose, spicy orange, plums, caramel and alcohol.  Quite a complex beer led by alcohol.  Maybe too much of an alcohol taste but it gives it a Grand Marnier finish.  It seemed a bit young but Ill probably re-rate it later, I still got 5 bottles waiting for me.

A rich complex and hard to describe beer. Big light tan head. Hints of fruit that mix elegantly with the sweet caramel-like sweetness. Very malty and long finish. If you find the Rochefort 10 a bit too violent, you will LOVE this one! My favorite Belgian Strong Ale!
This one is very bitter, and very strong, very in the style of many trappists..

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2006 Rating #1 (8/10/02) Bottle with a finish date of 2/13/07 brought to me accross the pond by Nuffield (8 4 8 3 18).  A dark cloudy brown color with a bubbly white head that quickly subsides.  Much drier and more sparkling than the Rochefort 10.  The aroma is a little musty with dry fruits, nuts, figs, and dates.  Fairly high carbonation with some chalkiness.  Remains dry and spicy.  

Rating #2 (7/14/03) - Bottle with a finish date of 10/2/07 (8 4 7 4 18).  A dark ruby brown color with a big foamy tan head.  Rich malty aroma with some dry dark fruits and chocolate.  Chalky, dry, burnt caramel and malt flavors with some fruits (dates).

Rating #3 (8/14/06) (8 4 7 3 17).  Bottle with a 2/10/07 expiration date.  A chestnut brown color with a silky light brown head.  Plums, raisins, mollasas, and toffee flavors.  Mildly thin at the finish but leaves a wonderful fruit and earthy flavor.

This was really surprising, especially to my mind how the aroma and flavor diverged.  To break it down to a single dimension, I thought the aroma leaned strongly toward bubble-gum and the flavor creates a sort of smokey essence (not a word Ive heard other people use to describe this one).  Sweet, yeasty, attractive.  Excellent beer.

Deep ruby color with an almost chartruse colored head.  Very complex malt flavors that didnt really seem to work together.  There was a lot of fruit and sherry tones, but not very well balanced.  I think my rating is effected by the fact that I liked the 10 so much.  Still a very good Belgian.
Very nice beer, one I like better than the Rochefort 10.  Lighter in body, sweet caramel, fruity and  brandy flavors.
I wasnt impressed with this beer at all.  The aroma was not appetizing and the flavor seemed to worsen with every swallow.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2005 Not quite as good as Rochefort 10, but still a wonderful trappist brew. The excellent aroma gives hints of banana, plums etc. The flavour and long finish is (also) very fruity and spicy. Re-rate: Less sweet and alcoholic than the 10 but with many of the same characteristics and a lovely bitter finish. Rating upgraded from 4 to 4.5 - this is a fantastic beer!
Smells like fresh hops - floral. Opaque brown almost black. Sweet dark malt taste with toffee tones and a touch of cinnamon-like spices. Full body and fizzy. Alcohol boosts the taste. Fantastic!

Fruity, cherry, apple, cinnamon, bubble gum, honey, alcohol aroma comes out of this nutbrown-red ale with the creamy beige head. Spicey, malty, toasted grain flavor with a moderate alcohol flavor. Fizzy carbonation and a moderate finish, rolling over all the tasted flavors. Very nice, well balanced and for me more likeable than the Rochefort 10

I was pleasantly surprised by the aroma of this beer, and by the dry, lower alch. body. This one, along with the 6, have made me adjust my feelings re: the Rochefort 10, which I will adjust downward a bit soon. This is really dry in the aroma, fruity, delightful, woody. Flavor is much more subtly sweet.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: opaque brown color.  Moderate head which turns in to a velvety solt bed of creamy bubbles - like the last bit of cream on top of a rootbeer float. Quite assertive at first but after sitting everything comes out.  Dates, cherries, toffee, slight licorice, wintergreen, dark candi, sour apples...Im sure there are more but this sample is gone.  Finishes very light with a hint of malt and spice.  Very smooth after it warms up.  Do not service this one to cold.
Starts with chocolate and caramel.  Moves through some fruits (white grapes, apples, plums).  A nice warm finish.  Beautiful.

This beer is a good as its big brother 10. The colour is brown with amber highlights. It has a an intense nose with chocolate milk, cloves and spice. The palate is very smooth and has great length. It is amazing considering the ABV how smooth this is. Thanks Duff for sharing.
Not as good as his big brother 10, but still a very good beer and one of the best trappists. Quiet complex, sweet, fruity.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2016 Eating dates near a roasting mechouiMerguez sausages with cinnamon, nutmeg and coriander subtly blended in... Chocolatey raisins in hot spicy breadRefined, sagacious, drinkable, and flavorful rarely meet like this...
Decent head, cloudy brown color. Dark fruit nose. Flavor is of soft fruits (plums, berries) chocolate, and even a hint of melon. Amazingly smooth.

Darn fascinating.  Nice cloudy auburn, head was sticky but thin and didnt hang around too long.  Nose is musty and sour, but can also detect hints of sweetness and cola.  Flavor is sort of three-pronged, starting with a brandy-burn alcohol kick, a bit metallic and overnoticeable.  The kick increases as it warms.  At the swallow, this one seemed plenty malty and rich, with nutty cream that had lots of plum, cherries, and peppermint candies.  As its swallowed and the flavor lengthens, the finish becomes long and toasty with a lingering sweetness of apples and pears, with a final smack of smokiness and faint chocolate.  Very complex, worthy of the Trappist label, but I do with the alcohol was a mite more muted--has a bit too much burn to it.
An excellent beer.  Nice dark color and nose.  Maybe not their best, but it is better than 99% of the others out there!

When opened it didnt go everywhere.  Looks and pours a lot like coca-cola.  The beer smells like the Firkin brew house in Loughborough.  The gas doesnt last long, and the head is quite small.  It tastes quite bitter, and its quite drinkable for a belgian of this type.  Not as good as the 12, but not too far off.
Dark brown with a big head. There is liquorize in aroma and taste. I also smell and taste lime (CaO). If it wasnt for the lime Id rate it higher.
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 A dark reddish-brown in colour.  You can taste the alcohol a bit but it is not overpowering.  Can taste chocolate and black cherries.  Nice long caramel aftertaste.
Strangely medicinal.  Didnt really feel I could enjoy these odd flavors if I had more than one.  Complex, but not as good as the 10.
Good full and fruity  aroma. Slightly sweet and full-bodied. A complex Belgian Trappist.
It is a good beer but it will allways be the little one to Rochefort 10

Rerate:Great beer, deep brown colour, nose is spicy, milky, clovey, chocolatey. Slight bit of sweet at the start, but remains dry, long spicy finish and nice rich chocolate in there aswell, and not that heavy considering the ABV, very tasty beer.
Complex beer, with a big head, liquorice flavours with a citric aroma.  Even a slight rosemary scent comes through.
I enjoyed but felt the palate was a little light.  Id really like to have a bit more complex brew, with a stronger palate.  But still this is a world class beer.

magnificent trappist ale.
dark red bronze colour, soft head, nice vinous nose of maple malt,  plums and subtle spicing.
taste lives up to the aromas  adding in cinnamon, dates and a gentle hoppiness.
the alcohol is barely noticable even at 9.3% because of all the flavours
Incredible aroma: brandy, doughy, malty, fruity, wonderful.  Nice flavour as well, but I had hoped for more.  Definate banana tones.  I look forward to trying the big brother.
Always in the shadow of....but on its own it a wonderful experience, I wouldnt turn my nose to it.

Expires 04-05, drank early enough on 05-02, a very frothy head fills the glass but then dissipates, not nearly as thick as the 10, but with the same dark brown color, plenty of sour malt mixed with a banana fruit sweetness, probably too sour, but smooth, producing a dry, bitter finish.

Mahogany coloured. Big, wonderful aroma of red berries. Sweet and softly malty. Sparkling mouthfeel. A hint of toffee. Salty finish. A very complex ale, which I actually find even better then its stronger cousin.
Not as good as his big brother 10, but very good. Almost same tast and flavor as the 10, but not that complex.

Murky dark brown red colour, quite a bit of yeast deposit in this bottle, possibly the most Ive seen so far in any Rochefort. Fluffly, small bubbled light beige head. Sweet  and somewhat less spicy aroma, fruits (grape?), flower nectar, some yeast. Palate: slightly spritzigy feel with excellent attack of the front of tongue and mouth but definitely less on the back and sides. Full malty body, alcohol well covered and dryish long finish. GERs are surprisingly sweet. Went down extremely well with a sharp cheese and smoked salmon pasta.
Very full bodied. Chocolate and coffee in the taste. Very hoppy and yeasty with a porto aroma and taste. Long hopbitter finish. Surprisingly dry and complex, inspite of its maltiness.

Almost a dubbel but with an added roast 
malts dryness and hops palate.  Like Rochefort 10 this fills the mouth with foam on impact which is an odd sensation.  Not as good as the aforementioned #10, but still worthy of a good rating.

Feels a bit too fizzy in my mouth; I poured down the side of the glass, so not much head or lace; seems like a weaker cousin of the 10. Just a bit of alcohol presence; Westy 8 is better, as is Ommegang. Still very fine, just not world class.

I paid $6.29 for the 11.2 oz bottle. Momentarily celebrated when I peeled the label off to reveal $7.99 - oops, under that one was $4.99. Then I wondered how old it was. Decided to rate it side by side w. a Westy 8. This one was the better beer. Color identical, good head, less than Westy though. Beautiful aroma of fruity yeast, bread, and a perfumy, violet-like, almost soapy fragrance that I couldnt identify, but  somehow fit. Sweet malty richness, wine, brandy, anise, chocolate. Alcohol prominent but not so much as the Westy 8. Sweet finish w. no hops present. I leave the description to ecrvich, who is way beyond me here.  Very good overall.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2016 Bottle (BB Oct 2020, so about 1 year old).

Head is initially large, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is cloudy medium orange-brown, bottle conditioned.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (cookie, caramel), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of raisin, cola, orange peel.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

I once loved this as much as anyone else, but the reality is that its just not that special. The mouthfeels of all three Rocheforts suffer the same problem...theyre watery and fizzy and unsatisfying to drink. They smell nice enough, if not all the way to great, and the flavor balance is decent enough for the styles, but again not particularly rich or satisfying. Every 4 or 5 years I try them all again, and always I am mildly disappointed. And so it is again here in 2016. Orval and Westvleteren are still the only notable Trappists.

WHOA BABY! is that a Rochefort. Damn Straight, can tell it by that Fantastic aroma, that of a fine brandy, malts and some plums, WOW. Pours a nice deep cloudy brown, large light chocolate head, and literally sheets of lace that last to the very bottom of the glass! Big malt start, the middle is medium, the finish is nicely hopped, the Alcohol definately rears its head at the finish as it warms you pleasantly. Dry, acidic, high carbonation, what a great beer!!!!!!

Excellent fruity trappist. A little dry in the mouth but nice deep fruit taste. Did not really notice the 9 percent while drinking. Dont drink this beer too cold, the label says between 12 and 14C. I noticed that the head went down quickly, maybe because of my glass, not a Rochefort glass but a Leffe one. I prefer the grade 10.

Starts off with a thick white head that lasts and leaves a lot of lacing. Has aromas of hops and esters (plus a hint of soap) lots of floaty yeast particles and flavours of fruit cake and a winey woodiness like its been matured in  a sherry butt. Aftertaste is soft and smooth with an alcoholic kick.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 Bottle bb 8.7.08
Grapes, plums a metallic vineous note in the aroma.
Bread base - on top of that cherries,  plums in madeira, nuts, marzipan - christmassy.
Phenolic citric note in the aftertaste.
Medium body, mellow mouthfeel.

Dark cocoa brown color with huge rocky light tan foam, initial aromas are cocoa, brand new shoes, vinous, figgy and Im gettin figgy widdit. Lightly creamy texture, medium effervescent. This is very very nice though a bit on the crispy side. Some yeast adds a touch of sweetness, salt and cheesyness. Flavorful but medium bodied brew. Its going way too quickly. Some light mustiness. Lightly tangy finish. Some light hints of phenol. This is a truly outstanding beer. Enjoy with fruit or bitter chocolate.

Zo schuimend!!!
Zo mooi...
Gewoon proeven

Review of a 1975 Rochefort at Kulminator in Antwerp.

This changed my opinion about how long a beer can be safely aged; at 26 years old, it had completely transcended beer and had an almost Sherry-like quality, very complex with prune/plum/chocolate undertones and wasnt overly alcohol tasting.  Very little head (to be expected) and lots of chunks meant drinking this through my clenched teeth chunky bits filter.  Was almost a religious experience tot he very end, so if you have the opportunity to enjoy a well-aged beer, I highly recommend it.
Excellent beer.  Not quite as full tasting as 10.  I tried this tonight at a great Chicago bar called Hopleaf which specializes in Belgian Beers.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 33cl bottle marked 28 07 04 drank on 1/31/02:  Muddy brown color, dark fruity taste, heavy alcohol aroma.  While it is an exceptional beer, it is too pricey here in the USA, so order it from Belgium.
Hard to find, but well worth the effort!

A simple brown in color; Large, dense, rocky head; Pleasent cheery bread aroma that warmed to something akin to an apple jolly rancher. First sip is remarkably smooth. A dryness emrges on the sides. Vinuous and maybe just a tad too syrupy- hence the low palate score. Warms beautifully. Very warming.
A great beer. Easy to drink, not to strong. And has an excellent taste.
spicey taste of cloves, nice red colour

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2005 Bottled. Beautiful spicy and fruity aroma with red berries and plum. Brown color, light brown creamy head, good lace. Sweet, spices, pepper, light bitter, very fruity, very warming that lingers forever, medium body.
The colour is a strange brown. Aroma of liquorice and nut. Taste of hazelnut, a little bit light.
Could not get past the sediment/floaters in the beer.  Also very expensive compared to other great tasting Belgians.
Fine one this is!
always a treat to have a trappist beer. i wonder if the belgians get sick of them. nice and dark. chocolatey and a bit of stone-fruit

Mine looked a bit funny, with reddish-brown sediment settling on the head. Alcoholic, brandy-like nose. Wonderful, multifaceted taste of caramel, chocolate, brandy, with a slightly nut-like bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2007 Clear russet. Pillowy, rocky, off-tan head.  Black cherries, wood, earthy yeast, bubblegum, and rummy alcohol comprise the aroma.  Feisty carbonation is firm but steadily softens. Lush malts are quickly lifted by a dry sweep of alcohol and dusty dryness.   Supple notes of raisins and fruitcake offset the dryness to a degree. Intensely rummy, but the attenuation is so high, the body suffers a bit. Finishes with lingering notes of dates, figs, and soft hints of wood and medicinal alcohol. A nice change of pace from its counterparts, but more Pilsner malt is what this really needs. Fun stuff, though.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Nice winterfriend, has a somewhat fruity taste to it.
Incredible trappiste. Very similar to a barley wine. This beer goes down smooth and warms the soul. Will be good for the cold winter stretch which we are about to take part in!
UPDATED: MAR 30, 2007 Better than the 10. Better than 99% of all beers, actually. Truly a masterpiece of craft brewing, with a bubblegummy, malty taste with few rivals.

I actually like this significantly more than the 10 which I had last night.  Nearly identical in color, but then the differences begin.  More chocolaty, fruity nose that might be less complex, but much more inviting.  This extends to the flavor and aftertaste, which smack less of alcohol (though it is still present for sure) and more of wine.  A great beer, this has me aching for more Belgians (not so easy to find here in VT).

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2004 dark reddish-brown colour with a big dense and creamy head, aroma of prune, chocolate, nougat and burnt almond, very malty, lot of carbonation, robust bitterness with a long malty and plumy finish - powerfull and balanced

My first try at this beer was when I had just started
drinking something more complex than Sleemans
Cream Ale, and it startled me into thinking it was bad.
On a second go-round, the flavours are great, but the alcoholic
taste still puts a damper on it for me.  Its still an
enjoyable once in a while beer.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2010 Dark reddish-brown colour; Similar florals to the 6 in the nose.  Denser, though, in fruitcake and especially in alcohol with brandy, chocolate and black cherry.  A big but rounded aroma.  The alcohol comes through much more on the palate, giving this a fairly muscular character.  The fruitcake is rich, the dark malt intensity high.  Yet, with the florals it has a certain style that few beers, even the big Trappist ones, have.

This is my 4th Trappist product and I can only say one thing what a beautiful product, you fall in love from this 1st sip, what a sweet, spicy taste and aroma, and you have to love the way those tiny bubbles just sit on your tongue.  Unfortunately it disappeard way too fast and only left me wanting more (too cost prohibitive), we must pay homage to those trappist for continuing to produce such fine quality beer!
